document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: 18 0 to 20 6 weeks fetal anomaly scan national standards and guidance for England
document.body:
18+0 to 20+6 Weeks Fetal Anomaly Scan: National Standards and Guidance for England

The ’18+0 to 20+6 Weeks Fetal Anomaly Scan: National Standards and Guidance for England’ document, published by the NHS Fetal Anomaly Screening Programme (NHS FASP) was launched in January. It accompanies the online resource developed by the Cambridge-based partnership of Jill Rodgers Associates and Liberating Solutions.

 

Together the document and online resource provide a wealth of information for all those involved in anomaly screening to secure the national requirements for a homogenous and equitable scanning service. In particular, the online resource contains easily accessible information about the new standards, a range of practice-based activities, examples of best practice and resources to download and can be used by individuals or within teams to support personal and service development.

 

Link to the online resource here

 

]]>

document.body:

Evidence-Based Medicine is a secondary evidence journal, containing informative abstracts and expert commentaries about the best quality research from primary care medicine.

Please not that this summary and the original research are >5 years old

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: A cost comparison of full field digital mammography with film-screen mammography in breast cancer screening
document.body:
This study for the NHS Breast Screening Programme estimates and compares the cost of full field digital mammography systems (FFDM) with conventional mammography for use in breast cancer screening and assessment.

The report states that "FFDM could potentially reduce the need to recall women for repeat screening, hence generating cost savings and reducing staff workloads.....as yet, the full costs and effects of FFDM are unknown. Further research is required to assess both the clinical and economic impact of FFDM compared with conventional mammography"

 

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: A further meta-analysis of population-based screening for abdominal aortic anerysm
document.body:
Authors' conclusions: Compared with controls, screening for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) reduces AAA-related long-term mortality by 4 per 1000 in men aged 65 years or older. Although screening for AA shows a strong trend for reduction in all cause mortality, by 5 per 1000, this is not statistically significant. 

 

Method: Medline, Embase and the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials were searched up until June 2009. Data on AAA-related all cause mortality were abstracted from the four randomized controlled trials of population-based AA screening with long-term follow-up in men aged 65 years and older.

 

Results: Pooled analysis demonstrated significant reduction in AAA-related mortality and a statistically non-significant reduction in all-cause mortality, compared to controls.

 

Citation: Takagi H, Goto SN, Matsui M et al. A further meta-analysis of population-based screening for abdominal aortic anerysm. Journal of Vascular Surgery 2010; 52(4):1103-8

 

Access: Abstract available

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: A meta-analysis of the clinical effectiveness of school scoliosis screening
document.body:
Authors' conslusions: The forward bending test alone was not sufficient in school scoliosis screening. Further research (large, retrospective cohort studies and follw-up) are needed to assess effectiveness of screening properly.

 

Method: PubMed, Google Scholar and Cinahl were among the databases searched. References from identified reviews were also searched. Studies were included according to specific criteria and excluded if they were reviews, comments, case studies or editorials.

 

Results: 775 studies were identified, of which 36 were included.

 

Citation: Fong DY, Lee CF, Cheung KM, et al. A meta-analysis of the clinical effectiveness of school scoliosis screening. Spine 2010; 35(10):1061-71

 

Access: PubMed abstract freely available

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: A multidisciplinary approach to group B streptococcus disease prevention in neonates
document.description: Powerpoint presentation on streptococcus B screening from a NSC workshop
document.body:
111-1A multidisciplinary approach to group B streptococcus disease prevention in neonates

The National Screening Committee convened a workshop on antenatal screening for streptococcus B, in November 2003. The policy not to screen was reaffirmed, but issues requiring further work were identified relating to the current level of knowledge of Group B streptococcus.

This presentation from the workshop looks at different approaches to prevent group B streptococcus disease in neonates.

 

The UK NSC policy on screening for streptococcus B has since been reviewed in November 2008.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: A systematic review of evidence for the appropriateness of neonatal screening programmes for inborn errors of metabolism
document.publisher: Journal of Public Health Medicine, Oxford Journals
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SCREENING,CONGENITAL ADRENAL HYPERPLASIA,BIOTINIDASE DEFICIENCY,MCADD,PHENYLKETONURIA,NOT ROUTINELY OFFERED,NEWBORN,BLOODSPOT (<1WK)]]>
document.body:
Authors' conclusions: The published evidence confirms that phenylketonuria should be screened for. There was insufficient evidence to assess the cost-effectiveness of screening for any other inborn error of metabolism. There was reasonable evidence to extend neonatal screening for biotinidase deficiency, congenital adrenal hyperplasia, medium-chain acyl coA dehydrogenase and glutaric aciduris type 1.

 

Method: Systematic review of the literature. Pairs ofreviewers selected papers for critical appraisal based on exclusion and inclusion criteria.

 

Results: 407 of 1,866 papers were identified for appraisal.

 

Citation: Thomason MJ, Lord J, Bain MD, et al. A systematic review of evidence for the appropriateness of neonatal screening programmes for inborn errors of metabolism. Journal of Public Health Medicine 1998; 20(3):331-43

 

Access: Full text available with NHS Athens login.

 

This systematic review has not been critically appraised.

]]>

document.title: A systematic review of the utility of self-report alcohol screening instruments in the elderly
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ADULT,SCREENING,ALCOHOL PROBLEMS,MANAGEMENT,OLD AGE,PRIMARY CARE,NOT ROUTINELY OFFERED]]>
document.description: Systematic review published in International J of Geriatric Psychiatry
document.body:
Int J Geriatr Psychiatry. 2004 Nov;19(11):1074-86.

Note: This reference is indexed in Medline, and has been established as a systematic review using specific criteria. It does not yet appear in any pre-appraised source and so the quality of the research has not been assessed.

OBJECTIVE:  to describe the different self-report alcohol screening instruments that have been studied in the elderly, and their effectiveness as screening instruments

CONCLUSION: Ease of use, patient acceptability, sensitivity and specificity must all be considered when selecting a self-report alcohol screening instrument for use in the elderly

]]>

document.title: Accuracy of carbohydrate-deficient transferrin in the detection of excessive alcohol consumption: a systematic review.
document.description: Systematic review published in Alcohol and Alcoholism
document.body:
Alcohol & Alcoholism Vol. 39, No. 2, pp. 75-85, 2004.

Note: This reference is indexed in Medline, and has been established as a systematic review using specific criteria. It does not yet appear in any pre-appraised source and so the quality of the research has not been assessed.

OBJECTIVE: to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of carbohydrate-deficient transferrin (CDT) in the detection of excessive alcohol consumption

CONCLUSION: The validity of CDT as a diagnostic tool is still questionable. If the higher values for sensitivity that some studies report can be confirmed by others it is a useful diagnostic tool in unselected populations

Please not that this review is >5 years old

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Accuracy of pulse oximetry in screening for congenital heart disease in asymtomatic newborns: a systematic review
document.publisher: Archives of Disease in Childhood Fetal & Neonatal Edition
document.body:
Authors' conclusions: Pulse oximetry is a highly specific tool with low false positive rates to detect congenital heart disease. Large, well conducted prospective studies are needed to assess sensitivity with higher precision.

 

Method: Systematic review of relevant studies identified through search of Medline, Embase, Cochrane Library, Medion and the bibliographies of retrieved primary and review articles. Two reviewers independently extracted data from eight included studies.

 

Results: Eight studies included 35,960 newborns. In all studies, pulse oximetry was performed on asymtomatic newborns. Functional or fractional oxygen saturation was measured. Oxygen saturation below 95% was the cut-off level. Sensitivity and specificity were estimated at 63% and 99.8% respectively, with a false positive rate of 0.2%.

 

Citation: Thangaratinam S, Daniels J, Ewer AK et al. Accuracy of pulse oximetry in screening for congenital heart disease in asymtomatic newborns: a systematic review. Archives of Disease in Childhood Fetal & Neonatal Edition 2007; 92(3):F176-80

 

Access: Full text available with NHS Athens account

]]>

document.description: Assessment of glaucoma screening against the NSC criteria
document.body:
111-1An Evaluation of Open Angle Glaucoma against the NSC Criteria for Screening Viability, Effectiveness and Appropriateness

This  report reviews published literature to identify evidence on whether chronic open angle glaucoma (OAG) meets the NSC criteria that are ideally required prior to initiation of a screening program.

The report concludes that "as a major cause of visual loss, OAG deserves consideration for screening despite the need to use more than one test".

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: An intervention to increase breast screening uptake
document.body:
This report was produced for the NHS Breast Screening Programme. The aim of this randomised controlled trial was to test whether a cost-effective intervention to increase the uptake of screening in the NHSBSP could be set up.

The recommendations were: " (1) An intervention based on implementation intentions is a cost-effective means of increasing uptake, and could readily be incorporated in the invitation for screening. (2) The NHSBSP should consider a “field trial” of the procedure, probably in a sample of areas for which uptake is low. (3) The key group to approach will be those invited to their first round of screening. Attendance in the second and subsequent rounds is very high in women who attend their first round, and encouraging women to plan for their first round will maximise their attendance thereafter. (4) The NHS should consider similar trials for other forms of screening."

Note that this research is >5 years old.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Annual knowledge update for vision screening in newborns & preschool children 2006
document.topics: <![CDATA[ EYES,NEONATAL,SPECIALTIES,EYES,STAFF USE,EYES AND VISION,VISUAL IMPAIRMENT,CHILD,SCREENING,CHILD HEALTH,OPHTHALMOLOGY,SCREENING,NEWBORN,PHYSICAL (<72HRS),PHYSICAL (6-8 WKS),SCHOOL ENTRY,VISION,CONDITIONS,LENS,CATARACT,OCULAR MOTILITY,LOW VISION,KNOWLEDGE UPDATES]]>
document.description: Literature search on topic of screening for vision defects in newborns and children
document.body:
111-1Annual knowledge update for vision screening in newborns & preschool children 2006

[Compiled by the Screening Specialist Library, February 2007]

 

The systematic review that has been commissioned  by the Health Technology Assessment (HTA) programme to look at screening for amblyopia and strabismus in children, (see: What is the clinical and cost effectiveness of screening programmes for amblyopia and squint in children up to the ages of 4-5 years), is not due for publication until April 2008.

 

In the interim, a literature search was performed to find citations on screening for vision defects (e.g. amblyopia, cataract, strabismus) in newborns and pre-school children published since the document Knowledge update for vision screening in newborns and pre-school entry children (Feb 2006). The last search date for this document was Dec 2005.

 

SOURCES SEARCHED: Medline, Embase, Cochrane Library, National Library for Health 

 

DATES OF SEARCH: Jan 2006 to Jan 2007

 

RESULTS: 46 citations were deemed to be relevant to  screening for vision defects in newborns and children. These 46 citations were classified in a way that health professionals involved in screening would recognise:

 

 

 

The full report is available below. The titles and links to abstracts of the relevant citations are included in the report - no quality assurance is implied by their inclusion. Any relevant good quality systematic reviews will have been entered as individual resources onto the Screening Library.

]]>

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Annual screening with mammography and breast examination did not reduce breast cancer mortality in women 40–49 years of age
document.body:
Annual screening with mammography and breast examination did not reduce breast cancer mortality in women 40–49 years of age. Evidence-Based Medicine 2003; 8:44.

This summary is based on the original article: Miller AB, To T, Baines CJ, et al.The Canadian National Breast Screening Study-1: breast cancer mortality after 11 to 16 years of follow-up. A randomized screening trial of mammography in women age 40 to 49 years.Ann Intern Med 2002;137:305–12.

Evidence-Based Medicine is a secondary evidence journal, containing informative abstracts and expert commentaries about the best quality research from primary care medicine. 

 

Please note this summary is >5 years old

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Antenatal and Newborn Screening for Cytomegalovirus
document.description: Working paper on screening for cytomegalovirus.
document.body:
111-1Antenatal and Newborn Screening for Cytomegalovirus

Antenatal and Newborn Screening for Cytomegalovirus. Report of the working party --September 2000.

This working paper was submitted to the Antenatal Screening Subgroup in April 2001. They concluded that:

"At present it would not be appropriate to introduce routine antenatal screening for CMV infection in pregnancy".

A more recent review of screening for cytomegalovirus was included in the NICE Antenatal care: routine care for the healthy pregnant woman. CG62: full guidance and also concludes that screening for cytomegalovirus should not be offered.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Antenatal screening - working standards for Down's Syndrome screening 2007
document.topics: <![CDATA[ QUALITY ASSURANCE,MANAGEMENT,14-20 WEEKS,DOWN'S SYNDROME (SERUM),11-14 WEEKS,ANTENATAL,IMPLEMENTATION,SCREENING,WOMEN'S HEALTH,DOWN'S SYNDROME (NUCHAL TRANSLUCENCY),SCREENING,ANTENATAL CARE,NORMAL PREGNANCY,DOWN'S SYNDROME]]>
document.description: Standards to improve the quality of the Down's Syndrome screening process
document.body:
These standards are intended to improve the quality of the screening process and enable women to exercise informed choice along the Down's syndrome screening pathway. It was agreed that all women would be offered screening for Down's syndrome as part of new initiatives to modernise neonatal and antenatal screening.

The 2007 working standards have evolved from those originally published in 2004

]]>

M.F. Murphy, L.M. Williamson & S.J. Urbaniak. Antenatal Screening for Fetomaternal Alloimmune Thrombocytopenia: Should we be doing it? Vox Sanguinis 2002; 83, (Suppl. I): 409-416.

document.title: Antenatal Screening For Hepatitis C
document.description: Working party report on screening for hepatitis C in the UK
document.body:
111-1Antenatal Screening For Hepatitis C

Working party report on screening for hepatitis C in the UK

This report concludes that:

"At the present time no case can be made for an HCV screening programme which specifically targets the antenatal period".

 A more recent review of screening for hepatitis C was included in the NICE Antenatal care: routine care for the healthy pregnant woman. CG62: full guidance and also concludes that screening for hepatitis C should not be offered.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Antenatal screening for heritable thrombophilia
document.description: Summary of a systematic review assessing effectiveness of antenatal thrombophilia screening
document.body:
Antenatal screening for heritable thrombophilia.
Medicare Services Advisory Committee 2002

The Medical Services Advisory Committee (MSAC) advises the Australian Minister for Health and Ageing on evidence relating to the safety, effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of new medical technologies and procedures.

This is a summary of a systematic literature review assessing safety, effectiveness and cost effectiveness of antenatal thrombophilia screening. 

This report recommended that "on the strength of evidence pertaining to antenatal screening for heritable thrombophilia, public funding should not be supported for systematic screening of all pregnant women. Since there is currently insufficient evidence pertaining to high-risk women with obstetric indications, selective antenatal screening should not receive public funding at this time".

 

This recommendation is more than five years old. However, it is still current.

]]>

document.title: Antenatal Screening Service for Down's Syndrome in England: 2001
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ANTENATAL,SCREENING,IMPLEMENTATION,DOWN'S SYNDROME (NUCHAL TRANSLUCENCY),MANAGEMENT,11-14 WEEKS,14-20 WEEKS,DOWN'S SYNDROME (SERUM)]]>
document.description: This National Screening Committee report presents findings of a survey about Down's syndrome screening within NHS maternity units in England
document.body:
111-1Antenatal Screening Service for Down's Syndrome in England: 2001

This National Screening Committee report presents selected findings of a survey undertaken in 2001 to establish service provision, and the underlying infrastructure, for Down's syndrome screening within NHS maternity units in England.

The report is divided into two parts:

  • an introduction to antenatal screening for Down's syndrome and its historical background
  • key findings from the 2001 Survey

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Appraisal of Evidence about Screening Women for Domestic Violence
document.publisher: Royal London and Bart's Medical School
document.topics: <![CDATA[ NOT ROUTINELY OFFERED,NOT ROUTINELY OFFERED,DOMESTIC VIOLENCE,SCREENING,ANTENATAL,ADULT,DOMESTIC VIOLENCE,DETERMINANTS,PUBLIC HEALTH,SOCIAL DETERMINANTS,MONTHLY ADDITIONS,DOMESTIC VIOLENCE,2009 SEPTEMBER,ABUSE]]>
document.description: Report examining the evidence for domestic violence screening.
document.body:
111-1Appraisal of Evidence about Screening Women for Domestic Violence

This report for the NSC examines the evidence for domestic violence screening in women.

The report concludes that "a health service based screening programme for domestic violence is not justified. We need good quality evidence of the benefit of intervention and lack of harm from routine questioning of women about domestic violence. If this evidence is forthcoming we need a strategy for changing the views of clinicians about the role of screening and its implementation. The weakness of evidence for screening is not an argument for health services to ignore the problem of domestic violence".

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Assessment of techniques for cervical cancer screening
document.publisher: Canadian Coordinating Office for Health Technology Assessment
document.body:
The Canadian Coordinating Office for Health Technology Assessment (CCOHTA) Technology Reports are critical appraisals or systematic reviews of the literature to provide a clear picture of the clinical effectiveness, cost-effectiveness and impact of health technologies in Canada.

This report** concludes that "barriers that prevent women from participating in screening may put them at a higher risk for cervical cancer. Opportunistic screening leads to over screening of younger, affluent, lower-risk women and underscreening of older, less affluent and minority group women. The targeted recruitment of women in coordination with an information system that would allow regular follow-up and recall of women could significantly reduce the number of cervical cancer cases".

**Please note that this report is >10 years old.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Attitudes towards carrier testing in minors: a systematic review
document.description: Systematic review published in Genet Couns.
document.body:
Genet Couns. 2005;16(4):341-52

OBJECTIVE: to review the attitudes of the different stakeholders (minors, healthcare professionals, parents and relatives of affected individuals) towards carrier testing in minors

CONCLUSION: the studies retrieved suggest that most parents are interested in the carrier status of their children and want their children to be tested before they reach legal majority (and some even in childhood).

]]>

document.title: Bone mineral density screening
document.publisher: Canadian Coordinating Office for Health Technology Assessment
document.topics: <![CDATA[ NOT ROUTINELY OFFERED,SCREENING,OSTEOPOROSIS,LATER LIFE,SCREENING AND SURVEILLANCE,TRAUMA,INVESTIGATION,OSTEOPOROSIS,SCREENING,ADULT,TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,MUSCULOSKELETAL,CONDITIONS,OSTEOPOROSIS,BONE DISORDERS,ACCIDENT PREVENTION,METABOLIC BONE DISEASE]]>
document.body:
The Canadian Coordinating Office for Health Technology Assessment (CCOHTA) performs pre-assessments of the literature, before deciding whether to undertake a health technology assessment. Pre-assessments are not systematic reviews, but involve a limited literature search, and provide a quick guide to current information on a topic.

This pre-assessment is on the topic of bone mineral density screening for osteoporosis. They conclude that "available evidence does not support the use of bone mineral density measurement for population screening of asymptomatic individuals".

Please note that this resource is >5 years old

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Brief cognitive screening instruments: an update
document.body:
Authors' conclusions: Dementia is under diagnosed in the elderly. The Mini Mental State Exam has significant limitations but is most frequently used instrument and best value in the community and primary care is to rule out dementia. Other instruments are recognised consistently for use in primary care while other newer instruments are gaining credibility due to the improvement of sensitivity, addressing frontal/executive functioning and decreasing susceptibility to cultural and educational biases.

 

Method: Medline was searched to find articles focussing on brief screening methods in primary care and geriatric services. Reference lists were also searched for relevant contributing articles.

 

Results: 679 abstracts were retrieved. This review focussed on instruments recommended from previous reviews of cognitive screening and those identified as being most commonly used in primary care and geriatric settings.

 

Citation: Ismail Z. Rajji TK. Shulman KI. Brief cognitive screening instruments: an update. International Journal of Geriatric Psychiatry 2010; 25(2):111-20

 

Access: Full text freely available

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Brief screening questionnaires to identify problem drinking during pregnancy: a systematic review
document.body:
Authors' conclusions: Although three questionnaires (T-ACE, TWEAK and AUDIT-C) were found to be potentially useful further evaluation is needed before they are used as stand alone tools.

Method: Databases, from their start dates to June 2008, and reference lists of eligible papers and related reviews, were searched, for cohort or cross-sectional studies that compared brief alcohol screening questionnaires with reference criteria.

 

Results: 5 studies, including 6724 participants, were reviewed. Seven screening questionnaires were evaluated.

 

Citation: Burns E, Gray R, Smith LA. Brief screening questionnaires to identify problem drinking during pregnancy: a systematic review. Addiction 2010; 105(4):601-14

 

Access: PubMed abstract available

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ GENETIC CONDITIONS,RESPIRATORY,CHILD HEALTH,SPECIALTIES,CYSTIC FIBROSIS,ANTENATAL,SCREENING,CYSTIC FIBROSIS,GENETIC CONDITIONS A-Z,SYSTEMS & SYMPTOMS,GENETICS - PRACTICE & ISSUES,CYSTIC FIBROSIS (CF),PREGNANCY,CONDITIONS C,GENETIC SCREENING (FOR CONDITIONS),BLOODSPOT (<1WK),NEWBORN,BLOOD]]>
document.description: Evaluation of cystic fibrosis against NSC criteria
document.body:
111-1Child Health Sub-Group Report - cystic fibrosis

This report by the Child Health Sub-Group evaluates cystic fibrosis against the NSC criteria. Both antenatal and neonatal screening have been considered, but this report concentrates mainly on neonatal screening.

The report recommends that "...on the evidence available, a national neonatal screening programme [for cystic fibrosis] should not be introduced. However, as one fifth of babies are already being screened in the UK, considerations of equity could not be ignored. The Minister of State for Health decided that screening should be introduced and an implementation group has been set up".

]]>

The report concludes that: "it is recommended that all children should be screened for visual impairment between four and five years of age. No other preschool vision screening can be justified".

Sex Transm Infect. 2004 Oct;80(5):331-3.

Note: This reference is indexed in Medline, and has been established as a systematic review using specific criteria. It does not yet appear in any pre-appraised source and so the quality of the research has not been assessed.

 

OBJECTIVE: To undertake a systematic review to obtain estimates of genital Chlamydia trachomatis prevalence in various populations in the United Kingdom and Ireland

 

CONCLUSION: The chlamydia prevalence estimates by age and setting from the model may be used to inform chlamydia screening strategies

 

Please note this review is >5 years old

document.body:

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Colorectal cancer screening for average-risk north americans: an economic evaluation
document.body:
Authors' conclusions: Screening for colorectal cancer with fecal immunochemical test reduces the risk of colorectal cancer and deaths related to colorectal cancer. Health care costs are lower in comparison to no screening and the other screening strategies.

 

Method: Incremental cost-utility analysis using a Markov model comparing guaiac-based fecal occult blood test of fecal immunochemical test annually, fecal DNA every 3 years, flexible sigmoidoscopy or computed tomographic colonography every 5 years, colonoscopy every 10 years and no screening natural history.

 

Results: Assuming mid-range testing characteristics, the annual fecal immunochemical test was more effective and less costly than no screening and the other strategies considered, but not fecal immunochemical test with high test performance characteristics. The number of cancers could be reduced from 4,857 to 1,782 and the number of deaths from 1,393 to 457, while saving CAN$68 per person during the lifetimes of 100,000 patients with average risk. When the test performance was reduced, or the cost of managing colorectal cancer was reduced the strategy became more expensive than no screening although it did remain economically attractive.

 

Citation: Heitman SJ, Hilsden RJ, Au F et al. Colorectal cancer screening for average-risk north americans: an economic evaluation. PLoS Medicine 2010; 7(11):e1000370

 

Access: Full text freely available

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Colorectal cancer screening options appraisal: cost effectiveness, cost-utility and resource impact of alternative screening options for colorectal cancer
document.publisher: School of Health and Related Research (ScHARR)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ECONOMICS,COLORECTAL (BOWEL) CANCER,SCREENING,ADULT,FLEXIBLE SIGMOIDOSCOPY,CANCER,SCREENING,STOOL TESTS,FAECAL BLOOD,GASTROENTEROLOGY & LIVER DISEASES,COLON & RECTUM,GASTROINTESTINAL ENDOSCOPY,DIAGNOSTIC PROCEDURES,DISEASE PREVENTION]]>
document.body:
The aim of this study was to conduct a detailed assessment of research evidence and to model costs, benefits and capacity implications of alternative screening options for colorectal cancer in England. Eight screening options using faecal occult blood testing, flexible sigmoidoscopy, or a combination of the two modalities are compared to a policy of ‘no screening.’

The report was prepared by ScHARR for the English Bowel Cancer Screening Working Group.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Colorectal cancer: screening
document.body:
Author's conclusions: Effectiveness and safety of colonoscopy, computed tomography colography, double contrast barium enema, faecal occult blood testing and flexible sigmoidoscopy were reviewed.

 

Method: Important databases, including Medline, Embase, The Cochrane Library and others, were searched up to November 2006.

 

Results: 19 systematic reviews were included in this review to answer the question 'What are the effects of screening for colorectal cancer?'

 

Citation: Lewis CL. Colorectal cancer: screening. Clinical Evidence 2007

 

Access: Full text available via Athens login

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Computed tomographic colonography (virtual colonoscopy)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SCREENING,ADULT,COLORECTAL (BOWEL) CANCER,GASTROENTEROLOGY & LIVER DISEASES,DIAGNOSTIC PROCEDURES,CT / CAT SCAN,VIRTUAL ENDOSCOPY,RECENT ADDITIONS,RADIOLOGY]]>
document.body:
The Health Technology Advisory Committee in Minnesota, USA provides unbiased, scientifically based assessments and recommendations on new and emerging technologies. Note that this committee was discontinued in July 2002 due to budget cuts, so the publications will not be updated subsequently.

This report concludes that "computed tomographic colonography (CTC) is a safe procedure. Further research is needed before CTC can be recommended as a screening tool. The sensitivity and specificity of CTC needs to improve to be comparable to that of colonoscopy".

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Computed Tomographic Colonography for Detection of Colorectal Polyps and Neoplasms
document.topics: <![CDATA[ GASTROENTEROLOGY & LIVER DISEASES,SCREENING,ADULT,COLORECTAL (BOWEL) CANCER,NON-MALIGNANT NEOPLASMS,RADIOLOGY,RECENT ADDITIONS,CANCER,VIRTUAL ENDOSCOPY,CT / CAT SCAN,POLYPS,DIAGNOSTIC PROCEDURES,COLON & RECTUM]]>
document.body:
Institute for Clinical Systems Improvement (ICSI) Technology Assessment Reports are designed to provide a scientific assessment, through review and analysis of medical literature, of the safety and efficacy of medical technologies.

This report looks at the use of computed tomographic colonography for detecting colorectal neoplasms. The Technology Assessment Committee summarised by stating that: "computed tomographic colonography (CTC) is a safe procedure with minor side effects reported. CTC appears to be superior, in terms of detection of colorectal polyps and neoplasms, to no examination, fecal occult blood test, double-contrast barium enema, and flexible sigmoidoscopy. CTC has not been proven to be superior to conventional colonoscopy".

]]>

This Health Technology Scientific literature review aims to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of virtual colonography as a screening tool in colorectal cancer.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Consolidated guidance on standards for the NHS Breast Screening Programme
document.body: <![CDATA[ This publication brings together standards for the NHS Breast Screening Programme in a single document. The standards have been developed by different professional quality assurance (QA) groups at different times. Some standards have been revised recently; some are still in the process of being revised. Because of this, there are inconsistencies in terminology and the presentation of standards. In addition, some standards may need to be revised as new techniques (such as digital mammography) come into routine use. This is the second version of the document which exists only as a PDF. The intention is to review it and publish a revised edition in hard copy when some of the issues have been resolved.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Continuous professional development for screening
document.topics: <![CDATA[ MANAGEMENT,NEWBORN,BLOODSPOT (<1WK),11-14 WEEKS,14-20 WEEKS,DOWN'S SYNDROME (SERUM),18-20 WEEKS,WOMEN'S HEALTH,DOWN'S SYNDROME (NUCHAL TRANSLUCENCY),FETAL ANOMALY,IMPLEMENTATION,ANTENATAL,SCREENING,8-10 WEEKS,SICKLE CELL & THALASSAEMIA]]>
document.description: Cross-cutting education and training resources for antenatal and newborn screening
document.body:
This website contains National Antenatal and Newborn Screening education and training resources developed by the National Screening Committee (NSC). It was developed to provide a single site of access to all national screening resources, including those for Down's Syndrome, Fetal Anomaly, Sickle Cell and Thalassaemia, Infectious diseases and Newborn blood spot. The resources are appropriate for all health care professionals involved in screening.

The UK National Screening Committee's Continuing Professional Development website for England is a ‘one stop' website bringing together all the cross-cutting education and training programmes and resources - meeting the continuing professional development (CPD) needs of health professionals involved in NHS antenatal and newborn screening.

Whether you're responsible for facilitating education and training locally or want to find out more about the latest developments in screening, this website provides the ideal starting point from which to explore the full range of NSC education programmes, e-resources, and other relevant information and publications.

]]>

This report concludes that "available evidence does not support the routine use of the C-Reactive protein (CRP) test for the diagnosis, management, or screening of patients with diagnosed disease, or in asymptomatic, healthy subjects".

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Criteria for appraising the viability, effectiveness and appropriateness of a screening programme
document.description: National Screening Committee criteria used to assess the suitability of screening for various conditions
document.body:
These National Screening Committee (NSC) criteria are based on the World Health Organization (WHO) criteria developed in the 1960s (see Principles and Practices of screening for disease by Wilson JM, and Junger YG. Geneva, World Health Organization, 1968), but take into account both more rigorous standards of evidence required to improve effectiveness, and the greater concern about adverse effects of screening.

These criteria are used to assess the suitability of screening for various conditions, and a part of the evidence used to create NSC screening policies.

]]>

111-1Current screening in the UK

The National Screening Committee convened a workshop on antenatal screening for streptococcus B, in November 2003. The policy not to screen was reaffirmed, but issues requiring further work were identified relating to the current level of knowledge of Group B streptococcus.

This presentation from the workshop outlines current group B streptococcus screening practices.

A more recent review was undertaken in November 2008

document.topics: <![CDATA[ DISEASE MANAGEMENT,TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,ADULT,SCREENING,INVESTIGATION,OSTEOPOROSIS,NOT ROUTINELY OFFERED,OLD AGE,METABOLIC BONE DISEASE]]>
document.body:
Institute for Clinical Systems Improvement (ICSI) Technology Assessment Reports are designed to provide a scientific assessment, through review and analysis of medical literature, of the safety and efficacy of medical technologies.

This report looks at the use of bone mineral density (BMD) measurement for the identification of osteoporosis. The Technology Assessment Committee summarised by stating that: "there is insufficient evidence to support mass screening for BMD; the need for BMD testing must be determined on an individual patient basis".

document.publisher: Journal of Public Health, Oxford Journals
document.body:
Authors' conclusions: Participation in colorectal cancer screening depends on local circumstances. It is, therefore dificult to produce a general strategy for improving uptake. Locally targeted strategies are needed.

 

Method: Systematic search of PubMed, Medline, Embase and PsycINFO.

 

Results: Studies included looked at socio-demographic determinants of participation of colorectal screening by faecal occult blood testing

 

Citation: My von Euler-Chelpin, Klaus Brasso, Elsebeth Lynge. Determinants of participation in colorectal cancer screening with faecal occult blood testing. Journal of Public Health 2010; 32(3):395-405

document.body:
111-1Diabetes, Heart Disease and Stroke (DHDS) prevention pilot project. Project Description Winter 2003

The Department of Health has allocated funding for the development of a Diabetes, Heart Disease, and Stroke (DHDS) Prevention Pilot Project under the auspices of the UK National Screening Committee (NSC).

The purpose of the project is to screen for diabetes and encourage healthy lifestyle changes in people aged 40 and over, considered at high risk for diabetes on the basis of a prior diagnosis of cardiovascular disease and/or being overweight. This report outlines the DHDS project.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Digital Rectal Examination (DRE) Screening for Prostate Cancer
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SCREENING,CANCER,PROSTATE,NOT ROUTINELY OFFERED,SCREENING,ADULT,CANCER,PROSTATE,SCREENING AND SURVEILLANCE,LATER LIFE,MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,PROSTATE DISORDERS,PROSTATE CANCER,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS]]>
document.body:
Digital Rectal Examination (DRE) Screening for Prostate Cancer

See the review in Bandolier

Bandolier writes:

"Few of the studies discussed the method of digital rectal examination used or the sort of result from the digital rectal examination that constituted a positive test. The review considered a non-enlarged, smooth, symmetrical prostate with normal consistency to be normal, and test results were recalculated using this criterion where it was possible to do so. The review, concentrating on men without prostate problems, cannot speak about the usefulness of DRE for diagnosing prostate cancer in men with prostate symptoms.

Bandolier found the statistical outcomes unhelpful, which is why we calculated the results on the basis of actual numbers of men classified correctly or incorrectly, on the basis of 1000 men and a primary care group. This seems to be much easier to understand than sensitivity and specificity, or other ways of expressing results of diagnostic tests. As shown in Bandolier 61 , most doctors seem to agree with us that we need new ways of expressing and using test results.

The arguments for screening for prostate cancer are moot, and digital rectal examination alone would be unlikely to be used. When more sophisticated methods are evaluated, like PSA or newer laboratory tests, it will be interesting to see how many men are correctly and incorrectly diagnosed".

 

References:

 

  1. A Hoogendam, F Buntinx, HCW de Vet. The diagnostic value of digital rectal examination in primary care screening for prostate cancer: a meta-analysis. Family Practice 1999 16: 621-626.
  2. MD Krahn, A Coombs, IG Levy. Current and projected annual direct costs of screening asymptomatic men for prostate cancer using prostate-specific antigen. Canadian Medical Association Journal 1999 160: 49-57.
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Dipstick urinalysis for screening of childhood urinary tract infection
document.body:
This is a Critical Appraisal produced by the Centre for Clinical Effectiveness, Monash University (Australia) to answer the question: Is dipstick urinalysis an appropriate method of screening for urinary tract infection in children? These critical appraisals are evaluative summaries of identified studies based on standard templates.

The appraisal concluded that "there is good evidence that in children aged 2-10 years old, dipstick urinalysis combing leukocyte and nitrite testing is an effective and appropriate screening method for urinary tract infection"

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Do growth monitoring and promotion programs answer the performance criteria of a screening program? A critical analysis based on a systematic review
document.description: Systematic review published in Trop Med Int Health
document.body:
Trop Med Int Health. 2005 Nov;10(11):1121-33.

Note: This reference is indexed in Medline, and has been established as a systematic review using specific criteria. It does not yet appear in any pre-appraised source and so the quality of the research has not been assessed.

 

OBJECTIVE:  to review whether growth monitoring programmes (GMP) answer the theoretical grounds of a screening and intervention program.

 

CONCLUSION: there is too little scientific evidence to indiscriminately support international promotion of GMP.

]]>

document.title: Does skin cholesterol testing provide benefit?
document.publisher: Canadian Coordinating Office for Health Technology Assessment
document.body:
The Canadian Coordinating Office for Health Technology Assessment (CCOHTA) publishes Issues in Emerging Health Technologies, a series of bulletins highlighting technologies.

This bulletin looks at the use of a detector solution to measure the amount of cholesterol that has accumulated in a person's skin. This report states that "this test is not intended to be used as a screening tool for coronary artery disease in the general population. Evidence from non-randomized, non-blinded clinical trials suggests a correlation between higher skin cholesterol levels and the presence of severe coronary arterial lesions".

]]>

document.title: Economic evaluation of population-based screening for colorectal cancer
document.publisher: Canadian Coordinating Office for Health Technology Assessment
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SCREENING,ADULT,COLORECTAL (BOWEL) CANCER,ECONOMICS,GASTROENTEROLOGY & LIVER DISEASES,RECENT ADDITIONS,CANCER,COLON & RECTUM]]>
document.body:
The Canadian Coordinating Office for Health Technology Assessment (CCOHTA) performs pre-assessments of the literature, before deciding whether to undertake a health technology assessment. Pre-assessments are not systematic reviews, but involve a limited literature search, and provide a quick guide to current information on a topic.

This pre-assessment is on the topic of population-based screening for colorectal cancer. They summarised that " the report by the [Canadian] National Committee on Colorectal Cancer Screening (NCCCS) concluded that the potential benefits of population-based biennial screening of colorectal cancer using fecal occult blood test (FOBT) outweighs the potential harms, and they recommended that such a program be implemented"

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Economic evaluation, human immunodeficiency virus infection and screening: a review and critical appraisal of economic studies
document.publisher: International Journal of Technology Assessment in Health Care, Cambridge Journals
document.body:
Authors' conclusions: The results of most of the economic evaluations included were based on 'inappropriate static models'. Further research, and analysis by health economists into cost-effectiveness of screening for HIV, is therfore recommended on the basis of this review.

 

Method: 3 electronic bibliographic databases searched from 1993-2008.

 

Results: 84 studies were identified.

 

Citation: Dibosa-Osadolor O, Roberts T.Economic evaluation, human immunodeficiency virus infection and screening: a review and critical appraisal of economic studies. International Journal of Technology Assessment in Health Care 2010; 26(3):301-8

 

Access: PubMed abstract available

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Effect of deodorants on mammographic films
document.body:
This National Co-ordinating Centre for Mammography report investigates whether deodorants and anti-perspirants cause specks (artefacts) on mammographic films, and whether there are differences between brands and types of deodorants.

This report concluded that: "it has been shown that deodorants and anti-perspirants do have sufficient contrast to be visible on mammograms and can potentially be the source of artefacts. Aluminium compounds appear to be the main source of the attenuation although even solid deodorants with no aluminium also showed low levels of contrast which may be visible on films. Only the one liquid deodorant with no aluminium could be ruled out as a possible source of artefacts".

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ NOT ROUTINELY OFFERED,PRIMARY CARE,MANAGEMENT,SCREENING,PRIMARY CARE SERVICES,POPULATION BASED & PREVENTATIVE SERVICES,SCREENING,ALCOHOL PROBLEMS,ADULT,DETERMINANTS,PUBLIC HEALTH,ALCOHOL CONSUMPTION,INDIVIDUAL BEHAVIOUR,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,LIFESTYLE,SOCIAL DETERMINANTS,SERVICES]]>
document.description: Systematic review published in Scandinavian J of Primary Health Care
document.body:
Scand J Prim Health Care. 2006 Mar;24(1):5-15

Note: This reference is indexed in Medline, and has been established as a systematic review using specific criteria. It does not yet appear in any pre-appraised source and so the quality of the research has not been assessed.

OBJECTIVE: To review systematically the available literature on implementation of brief alcohol interventions in primary healthcare in order to determine the effectiveness of the implementation efforts by the health are providers.

CONCLUSION: Intervention effectiveness (material utilization, screening, and brief intervention rates) generally increased with the intensity of the intervention effort, i.e. the amount of training and/or support provided

document.body:

The Effective Public Health Practice Project (EPHPP) is a key initiative of the Public Health Research, Education and Development Program in Ontario, Canada, and conducts systematic reviews on the effectiveness of public health interventions.

 

This review aimed to determine the effectiveness of strategies to increase cervical cancer screening, and concluded that reminder systems may offer considerable gains in Pap smear rates, providing that they are applied judiciously to appropriate groups of women.

document.topics: <![CDATA[ MANAGEMENT,PRIMARY CARE,NOT ROUTINELY OFFERED,POPULATION BASED & PREVENTATIVE SERVICES,PRIMARY CARE SERVICES,SCREENING,ADULT,ALCOHOL PROBLEMS,SCREENING,PUBLIC HEALTH,DETERMINANTS,SOCIAL DETERMINANTS,LIFESTYLE,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,INDIVIDUAL BEHAVIOUR,ALCOHOL CONSUMPTION,SERVICES]]>
document.description: Systematic review published in Journal of Studies on Alcohol
document.body:
J Stud Alcohol. 2004 Mar;65(2):191-9.

Note: This reference is indexed in Medline, and has been established as a systematic review using specific criteria. It does not yet appear in any pre-appraised source and so the quality of the research has not been assessed.

OBJECTIVE: A systematic review was undertaken of studies that test the effectiveness of different strategies used to increase general practitioners' rates of screening for and giving advice about hazardous and harmful alcohol consumption.

CONCLUSIONS: Although the small numbers of programs studied suggest caution be used in interpreting the results, it seems it is possible to increase the engagement of general practitioners in screening and giving advice for hazardous and harmful alcohol consumption.

document.title: Enhancing the use and quality of colorectal cancer screening
document.publisher: Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality
document.body:
Authors' conclusions: Multiple problems of underuse, overuse and misuse of colorectal cancer screening exist.  Some interventions look promising but further research, tailored to specific populations, is needed to design and test interventions to both increase screening as well as reduce overuse and misuse.

 


Method: Medline, The Cochrane Library and the Cochrane Central Trials Registry were searched for English language studies published between Jabuary 1998 and September 2009. This was supplemented by hand searches.

 


Results: 116 articles, including 72 studies were included

 


Citation: Holden DJ, Harris R, Porterfield DS, et al. Enhancing the use and quality of colorectal cancer screening. Evidence Report/Technology Assessment Number 190, AHRQ Publication No. 10-E002 February 2010

 

Access: Full text PDF report freely accessible

document.topics: <![CDATA[ SCREENING,MANAGEMENT,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT,RACE EQUALITY]]>
document.description: A review for the the National Screening Committee on ethnic issues in screening.
document.body:
111-1Ethnic issues in screening

This report investigates the following questions:

What is the National Screening Committee legally obliged to provide to ensure equity of access to its programmes?

What guidance does the Department of Health and other organisations provide to healthcare providers to ensure access to healthcare for people from minority ethnic groups?

Are there any barriers in terms of access to screening programmes, communication during the consultation, or barriers to follow-up for people from minority ethnic backgrounds?

What are the possible solutions to ensure equity of access and a uniform standard of care?

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Evaluation of Cervical Cytology
document.publisher: Agency for Health Care Policy and Research, USA
document.body:
Evaluation of Cervical Cytology**

Evidence Report/Technology Assessment

Number 5, 1999

Prepared for:
Agency for Health Care Policy and Research, USA

A summary of this report is also available.

Overview: "Despite the indisputably dramatic impact of Pap screening, there is still uncertainty about the details of Pap smear performance, and much could be done to improve the performance of the test and followup of patients after screening. Controversy about the details of Pap smear performance is manifest in differing recommendations about the frequency of screening and the age (if any) at which screening may safely be stopped. A significant proportion of patients and providers fail to comply with even the least demanding recommendations for Pap screening frequency. Numerous barriers to screening have been identified that reduce access to Pap smears and other preventive services.

Recently, efforts to improve Pap smear performance have focused on reducing the number of false negative smears, that is, cases in which premalignant or malignant cells have been misdiagnosed as normal. Recently, several technologies have been developed to optimize Pap test screening by reducing the false negative rate. These technologies are a major focus of this report."

** Note that this report is > 5 years old

]]>

document.body:
The research and development directorate at the Department of Health commissioned an independent evaluation of the UK Pilot, which ran from 2000-2002. There was a single study of both the English and Scottish sites conducted by a multi-disciplinary evaluation team.

The evaluation team produced annual reports for three years. The reports were made available to the Pilot Steering Group and the National Screening Committee to help to decide whether to introduce bowel cancer on a national level. The final report and its supplementary report were published in July 2003.

The report into the second round of the English bowel cancer screening pilot was published in August 2006.

document.title: Evaluation of the newborn hearing screening programme (NHSP) in England
document.description: This is the report of the evaluation of the first phase of implementation of the newborn hearing screening programme
document.body:
111-1Evaluation of the newborn hearing screening programme (NHSP) in England

The aim of this evaluation was to appraise the benefits, effects, costs and practical implications of the pilot implementation of the national model for newborn hearing screening. A number of recommendations are made for future policy and practice.

See the appendices for this document.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Evidence-based screening
document.body:
Evidence-based screening

See the review in Bandolier**

Gill Grimshaw writes:

"Effective screening is as much a matter of good administration as it is of good medicine. For those contemplating introducing screenings two crucial questions should be answered:-

  • Can the proposed test be shown to be cost-effective - is it worth doing?
  • Can the test be delivered and the results responded to consistently for all those at risk - can it be done? "

** Note that this review is > 5 years old

]]>

Evidence-Based Medicine is a secondary evidence journal, containing informative abstracts and expert commentaries about the best quality research from primary care medicine.

document.title: Familial breast cancer
document.description: NICE update of advice on familial breast cancer
document.body:
This guideline produced for NICE and the National Collaborating Centre for Primary Care (NCCPC) sets out how health professionals should identify and care for women who are at risk of developing breast cancer because of a history of the condition in their family.

This guideline is an update of advice on familial breast cancer that NICE produced in 2004. The advice on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) for breast cancer screening has changed, but all the other advice is the same.

A quick reference guide to this guideline is also available: http://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/cg41/quickrefguide/pdf/English/?template=download.aspx

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Fetal nuchal translucency in early detection of Down´s syndrome
document.publisher: Swedish Council on Technology Assessment in Health Care
document.body:
Alert is a system for identification and early assessment concerning new methods in health care. The Alert reports are produced by the Swedish Council on Technology Assessment in Health Care, and describe the new methods and their effects.

This report summarises fetal nuchal translucency in early detection of Down´s syndrome. It concludes that " the use of fetal nuchal translucency to assess the risk for Down´s syndrome should take place only within the framework of scientific studies that encompass research on the acceptance of the method, the characteristics of the method in broad application, and its ethical, psychological, and economic consequences. It is essential to complete the ongoing controlled trials prior to general dissemination of the method in healthcare"

A more recent review of the literature is reported in Methods of Early Prenatal Diagnosis, SBU report 182, published 2006.

]]>

document.title: First Report of the National Screening Committee
document.body:
This is the first National Screening Committee report, which outlines the main issues in screening in the UK. It covers definitions and purpose of screening, quality assurance, the research base, and the criteria used to appraise the viability of a screening programme.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: First Trimester Prenatal Testing for Down Syndrome using Nuchal Translucency
document.body:
Institute for Clinical Systems Improvement (ICSI) Technology Assessment Reports are designed to provide a scientific assessment, through review and analysis of medical literature, of the safety and efficacy of medical technologies.

This report looks at the use of nuchal translucency testing for Down's Syndrome. The Technology Assessment Committee summarised by stating that: "nuchal transulcency (NT) or the combined test in the first trimester have the potential to detect 64%-91% of Down syndrome cases with a 5% false positive rate. The positive predictive values for NT alone were 1.5%-5.8%. However, the efficacy and practicality of first trimester testing have not been proven"

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Gastric cancer screening using the serum pepsinogen test method.
document.body:
Author's conclusions: The pepsinogen test method can be used as a screening test for high-risk subjects, rather than as a tool for screening for cancer itself.

 

Method: Meta-analysis of 42 studies

 

Results: 42 studies were included. 27 were population-based screening studies that incorporated 296,553 individuals, and 15 were of selected groups incorporating 4,385 individuals.

 

Citation: Miki K. Gastric cancer screening using the serum pepsinogen test method. Gastric Cancer 2006;9(4):245-53

 

Access: Full text PDF freely available

 

This meta-analysis has not been critically appraised.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Genetic carrier testing for cystic fibrosis
document.body:
Institute for Clinical Systems Improvement (ICSI) Technology Assessment Reports are designed to provide a scientific assessment, through review and analysis of medical literature, of the safety and efficacy of medical technologies.

This report looks genetic carrier testing for cystic fibrosis (CF). The Technology Assessment Committee summarised by stating that: "genetic carrier testing for CF should be offered to individuals planning a pregnancy or seeking prenatal care if they have a family history of CF, if they are reproductive partners of individuals who have CF, or if they or their partner are Caucasian (including Ashkenazi Jews)."

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Genetic screening in the Ashkenazi Jewish population - is there a case for more testing?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SCREENING,ANTENATAL,NOT ROUTINELY OFFERED,BEFORE 16 WEEKS,TAY SACHS,CYSTIC FIBROSIS]]>
document.description: A report for the National Screening Committee looking at whether current screening in the Jewish population should be extended.
document.body:
111-1Genetic screening in the Ashkenazi Jewish population - is there a case for more testing?

This is a report of a National Screening Committee meeting on genetic screening in the Ashkenazi Jewish population. Screening for Tay Sachs disease in this population is well established, but there have been requests for screening for other disorders such as Canavans disease, familial dysautonomia, Gauchers disease and cystic fibrosis. Other areas addressed in the report are the psychosocial, ethical, and economic aspects of such screening.

]]>

document.title: Genetic screening: ethical issues
document.description: Nuffield Council report and supplement on ethical issues in genetic screening
document.body: <![CDATA[ This Nuffield Council report on genetic screening examines issues such a consent to being screened, counselling and the storage and use of genetic information for legal purposes. The main report was published in 1993 - a supplement to this report was published in 2006 (see related links below) and concluded that "the ethical principles identified in the 1993 Report remained relevant for guiding current research and practice".]]>

document.title: Genetic testing for hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ADULT,SCREENING,COLORECTAL (BOWEL) CANCER,GASTROENTEROLOGY & LIVER DISEASES,CANCER,RECENT ADDITIONS,COLON & RECTUM]]>
document.body:
Institute for Clinical Systems Improvement (ICSI) Technology Assessment Reports are designed to provide a scientific assessment, through review and analysis of medical literature, of the safety and efficacy of medical technologies.

This report looks at the use of genetic testing for hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HPNCC) and summarises by stating that "genetic testing of HNPCC can reduce the number of surveillance colonoscopies and help target surveillance at high-risk patients, however, studies of the effect of genetic testing of HNPCC on more substantial outcomes such as mortality are limited."

]]>

The National Screening Committee convened a workshop on antenatal screening for streptococcus B, in November 2003. The policy not to screen was reaffirmed, but issues requiring further work were identified relating to the current level of knowledge of Group B streptococcus.

This presentation from the workshop outlines the epidemiology and natural history of group B streptococcal disease.

 

A more recent evaluation of antenatal screening for Group B Streptococcal (GBS) carriage against NSC Handbook Criteria was undertaken in 2008.

 

]]>

document.title: Helical computed tomography (CT) for lung cancer screening for asymptomatic patients
document.body:
The Health Technology Advisory Committee in Minnesota, USA provides unbiased, scientifically based assessments and recommendations on new and emerging technologies. Note that this committee was discontinued in July 2002 due to budget cuts, so the publications will not be updated subsequently.

This report concludes that "while helical computed tomography (CT) scans may be able to detect pulmonary nodules at an earlier stage, at the present time there is no evidence from randomized controlled trials that screening asymptomatic individuals for lung cancer with helical CT scan increases actual survival time or reduces lung cancer-related mortality".

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Human papillomavirus testing in primary cervical cancer screening
document.publisher: Swedish Council on Technology Assessment in Health Care
document.body:
Alert is a system for identification and early assessment concerning new methods in health care. The Alert reports are produced by the Swedish Council on Technology Assessment in Health Care, and describe the new methods and their effects.

This report summarises human papillomavirus testing in primary cervical cancer screening. It concludes that "there is poor scientific documentation to show the effects of introducing HPV testing as a primary screening method aimed at reducing morbidity and mortality... there is no scientific evidence to show how screening programs that include HPV testing can be conducted in an optimum way - at what ages and at what intervals. Further assessments of model studies and randomized controlled trials, with the ultimate goal of reducing cancer incidence and increasing patient survival, are needed before the method can be routinely applied in primary screening programs"

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Human papillomavirus testing in women with cytological prediction of low-grade abnormality
document.body:
Human papillomavirus testing in women with cytological prediction of low-grade abnormality. Fennessy P, Raulli A, Abdulwadud O. Canberra, ACT, Australia: Medical Services Advisory Committee 2002: 97 (ref 12b)

The Medical Services Advisory Committee (MSAC) advises the Australian Minister for Health and Ageing on evidence relating to the safety, effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of new medical technologies and procedures.

 

This report summarises the assessment of the current evidence for the use of the HC-II test as an aid in triaging women who have undergone cervical screening.

 

The report recommends that "there is currently insufficient evidence to support public funding at this time for the use of the human papillomavirus test for triaging of women with equivocal cervical screening results".

 

There is also a one-page summary of this report available.

]]>

document.title: Imaging in coronary heart disease
document.body:
These New and Emerging Technology Briefings from the National Horizon Scanning Centre, University of Birmingham outline what the technology is, its likely patient group, the current treatment alternatives, the level and amount of research evidence available and a prediction of its relevance both clinically and to the wider NHS. 

This report looks at the use of cardiac imaging in the diagnosis and management of coronary heart disease (CHD). The imaging modalities considered include myocardial ultrasound, nuclear medicine, positron emission tomography, computerised tomography and magnetic resonance imaging.

]]>

The National Screening Committee convened a workshop on antenatal screening for streptococcus B, in November 2003. The policy not to screen was reaffirmed, but issues requiring further work were identified relating to the current level of knowledge of Group B streptococcus.

This presentation from the workshop looks at the impact of prenatal antibiotics on neonatal sepsis, through a review of randomised controlled trials and surveillance studies.

 


A more recent evaluation of antenatal screening for Group B Streptococcal (GBS) carriage against NSC Handbook Criteria was undertaken in 2008.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Improving outcomes for oral cancer
document.description: This National Screening Committee report summarises workshops convened to examine issues in oral cancer
document.body:
111-1Improving outcomes for oral cancer

The National Screening Committee set up a series of workshops to examine the following issues in oral cancer:

  • Raising public awareness
  • Improving professional awareness to facilitate earlier detection
  • Organising support services for patients and improving pathways earlier treatment
  • Identifying topics that would be priorities for research

This report summaries the results from these workshops. It concludes that "there is an overwhelming need for more information about history of oral cancer. Greater awareness of the disease professionals and standardised referral pathways would facilitate treatment when necessary. The population should be aware of possible risk factors and early signs and symptoms".

]]>

document.body:
This report was commissioned by the UK National Screening Committee (UK NSC) to investigate best practice to reduce inequalities in screening uptake. document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Intimate partner violence screening tools: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ NOT ROUTINELY OFFERED,DETERMINANTS,DOMESTIC VIOLENCE,ADULT,SCREENING,PUBLIC HEALTH,SOCIAL DETERMINANTS,MONTHLY ADDITIONS,2009 SEPTEMBER,DOMESTIC VIOLENCE,ABUSE]]>
document.body:
Context
Intimate partner violence (IPV) screening remains controversial. Major medical organizations mandate screening, whereas the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) cautions that there is insufficient evidence to recommend for or against screening. An effective IPV screening program must include a screening tool with sound psychometric properties. A systematic review was conducted to summarize IPV screening tools tested in healthcare settings, providing a discussion of existing psychometric data and an assessment of study quality.

Evidence acquisition
From the end of 2007 through 2008, three published literature databases were searched from their start through December 2007; this search was augmented with a bibliography search and expert consultation. Eligible studies included English-language publications describing the psychometric testing of an IPV screening tool in a healthcare setting. Study quality was judged using USPSTF criteria for diagnostic studies.

Evidence synthesis
Of 210 potentially eligible studies, 33 met inclusion criteria. The most studied tools were the Hurt, Insult, Threaten, and Scream (HITS, sensitivity 30%–100%, specificity 86%–99%); the Woman Abuse Screening Tool (WAST, sensitivity 47%, specificity 96%); the Partner Violence Screen (PVS, sensitivity 35%–71%, specificity 80%–94%); and the Abuse Assessment Screen (AAS, sensitivity 93%–94%, specificity 55%–99%). Internal reliability (HITS, WAST); test–retest reliability (AAS); concurrent validity (HITS, WAST); discriminant validity (WAST); and predictive validity (PVS) were also assessed. Overall study quality was fair to good.

Conclusions
No single IPV screening tool had well-established psychometric properties. Even the most common tools were evaluated in only a small number of studies. Sensitivities and specificities varied widely within and between screening tools. Further testing and validation are critically needed.

 

Bibliographic details: Rabin RF, Jennings JM, Campbell JC, Bair-Merritt MH. Intimate partner violence screening tools: a systematic review. American Journal of Preventive Medicine 2009;36(5):439-445.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Is pulse palpation helpful in detecting atrial fibrillation? A systematic review
document.body:
Authors' conslusions: Pulse palpation is useful tool to rule out atrial fibrillation and may be useful in opportunistic screening for undetected atrial fibrillation.

 

Method: Systematic search of Medline, Embase and reference lists of review articles for studies comparing pulse palpation with the electrocardiogram (ECG) diagnosis of atrial fibrillation. Search results then assessed by two reviewers for eligibility and quality and to extract data.

 

Results: 3 studies, including 2385 participants were included, comparing pulse palpation with ECG.

 

Citation: Cooke G, Doust J and Sanders S. Is pulse palpation helpful in detecting atrial fibrillation. Journal of Family Practice 2006; 55(2):130-4

 

Access: PubMed abstract available

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Knowledge update on growth screening for preschool children 2004/2006
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SCHOOL ENTRY,HEIGHT,NUTRITION,OBESITY,GROWTH CHARTS,OBESITY AND THINNESS,SPECIALTIES,STAFF USE,SCREENING,CHILD,CHILD HEALTH,ENDOCRINOLOGY,SCREENING,NUTRITION,KNOWLEDGE UPDATES]]>
document.description: This report outlines a knowledge update on growth screening for preschool children
document.body:
111-1Knowledge update on growth screening for preschool children 2004/2006

[Compiled by the Screening Specialist Library, May 2006]

 

The World Health Organisation (WHO) is to issue new guidelines on measuring the growth rates of babies (see BBC news health). The WHO publication on Child Growth Standards is currently in press – the summary states that “a comprehensive review of the uses and interpretation of anthropometric references undertaken by WHO in the early 1990s concluded that new growth curves were needed to replace the existing international reference”.

 

A systematic review of the routine monitoring of growth in children has been commissioned by the Health Technology Assessment (HTA) programme (A systematic review of the routine monitoring of growth in children of primary school age to identify growth related conditions). However, this report is not due for publication until mid 2007.

 

In the interim, a literature search was performed to find citations on growth screening of preschool children published since the National Screening Committee Child Health Sub-Group report on growth disorders (Sept 2004)

 

SOURCES SEARCHED: Medline, Embase, Cochrane Library, PubMed Related Article 

 

DATES OF SEARCH: Jan 2004 to March 2006

The full report is available below. The titles and abstracts of the relevant citations are included in the report - no quality assurance is implied by their inclusion. Any relevant good quality systematic reviews will have been entered as individual resources onto the Screening Library.

[Compiled by the Screening Specialist Library, May 2006]

 

A systematic review looking at the usefulness and value of genetic testing for haemochromatosis has been commissioned by the Health Technology Assessment (HTA) programme - see the clinical validity and utility of adding DNA testing to case identification strategies for haemochromatosis in at-risk populations. However, this report is not due for publication until mid 2008.

 

In the interim, a literature search was performed to find citations on screening for haemochromatosis published since the National Screening Committee report on the Evaluation of Haemochromatosis Screening (2001).

DATES OF SEARCH: Jan 2001 to April 2006

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Knowledge update on screening for open-angle glaucoma 2001/2006
document.description: This report outlines a knowledge update on screening for open-angle glaucoma
document.body:
111-1Knowledge update on screening for open-angle glaucoma 2001/2006

 [Compiled by the Screening Specialist Library, October 2005]

 

UPDATED† [In November 2006, the Eyes and Vision Library conducted a national knowledge week update on screening for glaucoma - see Glaucoma screening]

 

A systematic review has been commissioned by the Health Technology Assessment (HTA) programme, with the aim of assessing the extent to which screening for open angle glaucoma meets the UK National Screening Committee criteria for a screening programme (see clinical and cost-effectiveness of screening for open angle glaucoma). However, this report is not due for publication until mid-2007.

 

In the interim, a literature search was performed to find citations on glaucoma screening published since the date of the last National Screening Committee (NSC) workshop, and the publication of the report “Evaluation of open angle glaucoma against the NSC criteria for screening viability, effectiveness and appropriateness” (both 2001).

 

  

SOURCES SEARCHED: Medline, Embase, Cochrane Library

 

DATES OF SEARCH: Jan 2001 to Oct 2005 

 

RESULTS: 101 citations were deemed to be relevant to open-angle glaucoma screening. These 101 relevant citations were classified in a way that health professionals involved in screening would recognise:

The full report is available below. The titles and abstracts of the relevant citations are included in the report - no quality assurance is implied by their inclusion. Any relevant good quality systematic reviews will have been entered as individual resources onto the Screening Library.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Liquid based cytology for cervical screening
document.body:
Liquid based cytology for cervical screening. Fennessy P, Raulli A, Abdulwadud O, Petherick E, Bryan E, Harris C, Medical Services Advisory Committee, Australia. 2002: 1-97 (ref 12a)

The Medical Services Advisory Committee (MSAC) advises the Australian Minister for Health and Ageing on evidence relating to the safety, effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of new medical technologies and procedures.

 

This report summarises the assessment of current evidence for cervical screening with liquid based cytology.

 

The report recommends that "there is insufficient evidence to support public funding of liquid based cytology for cervical screening at this time."

 

A one-page summary of the report is also available.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Liquid-Based Cervical Cytology
document.body:
Institute for Clinical Systems Improvement (ICSI) Technology Assessment Reports are designed to provide a scientific assessment, through review and analysis of medical literature, of the safety and efficacy of medical technologies.

This report looks at the use of liquid-based cytology (LBC) in place of conventional Pap smear methods. The Technology Assessment Committee summarised by stating that:

"LBC is an option to conventional Pap testing for cervical cancer screening............of 11 studies cited in this report that presented test results as either satisfactory, satisfactory but limited by, or unsatisfactory, 8 found a higher rate of satisfactory samples with LBC. Between 75.6% and 97.7% of LBC preparations were satisfactory compared with 60.5% to 97.5% with conventional Pap preparations"

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Lubrication of the vaginal introitus and external speculum had no effect on Papanicolaou smear interpretation
document.body:
Lubrication of the vaginal introitus and external speculum had no effect on Papanicolaou smear interpretation. Evidence-Based Medicine 2003; 8:79.

This summary is based on the original article: Harer WB, Jr, Valenzuela G, Lebo D. Lubrication of the vaginal introitus and speculum does not affect Papanicolaou smears.Obstet Gynecol 2002;100:887–8

Evidence-Based Medicine is a secondary evidence journal, containing informative abstracts and expert commentaries about the best quality research from primary care medicine.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Lung cancer screening: recommendation statement
document.publisher: Agency for Health Care Policy and Research, USA
document.body:
This is the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommendation on screening for lung cancer. The USPSTF concludes that "the evidence is insufficient to recommend for or against screening asymptomatic persons for lung cancer with either low dose computerized tomography (LDCT), chest x-ray (CXR), sputum cytology, or a combination of these tests".

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Lungscreen for lung cancer detection in high risk patients
document.body:
These 'News on emerging technologies in healthcare' summaries from the National Horizon Scanning Centre, University of Birmingham outline what the technology is, its likely patient group, the current treatment alternatives, the level and amount of research evidence available and a prediction of its relevance both clinically and to the wider NHS. 

The briefing reviews the Lungscreen device for the detection of lung cancer in high-risk patients.

'This technology summary is based on information available at the time of research and a limited literature search. It is not intended to be a definitive statement on the safety, efficacy or effectiveness of the health technology covered and should not be used for commercial purposes.'

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) for the Detection of Breast Abnormalities
document.body:
Institute for Clinical Systems Improvement (ICSI) Technology Assessment Reports are designed to provide a scientific assessment, through review and analysis of medical literature, of the safety and efficacy of medical technologies.

This report looks at the use of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in breast cancer screening. The Technology Assessment Committee summarised by stating that: "MRI as a screening test for the low-risk general population has not been studied and should not be performed at this time. Mammography and ultrasound should be used for the initial evaluation of breast symptoms".

]]>
