document.body:
This report by the Human Genetics Commission examines prenatal screening, preimplantation genetic testing, diagnostic and genetic services, and genetic aspects of assisted reproduction. Chapter 3 (prenatal and neonatal screening and diagnostic testing) starts on pg 29.

]]>

document.title: Mammography screening attendance: meta-analysis of the effect of direct-contact invitation
document.body:
Mammography screening attendance: meta-analysis of the effect of direct-contact invitation
Denhaerynck K, Lesaffre E, Baele J, Cortebeeck K, Van Overstraete E, Buntinx F. American Journal of Preventive Medicine 2003; 25(3): 195-203.

This review has been evaluated by reviewers from the NHS Centre for Reviews and Dissemination (CRD), University of York, as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria, and a structured abstract is in the process of being written.

An abstract for the article from Am J Preventive Medicine is available from PubMed.

]]>

document.title: Master data dictionary 2008-2009 with addendum
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SCREENING,IMPLEMENTATION,POSTNATAL CARE,NORMAL PREGNANCY,WOMEN'S HEALTH,NEWBORN,BLOODSPOT (<1WK),MANAGEMENT,NEONATAL AND INFANT CARE,NEWBORN BLOODSPOT,GENERAL EXAMINATION AND SCREENING]]>
document.description: Newborn Bloodspot and Sickle Cell & Thalassaemia Programmes data collection dictionary.
document.body:
This Data Collection and Performance Analysis Dictionary is a reference resource to support data collection for newborn blood spot screening. This tool has been developed with the Sickle Cell and Thalassaemia Screening programme, it is a joint collection tool for the two programmes  

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Maternal serum screening for Down syndrome
document.publisher: Swedish Council on Technology Assessment in Health Care
document.body:
Alert is a system for identification and early assessment concerning new methods in health care. The Alert reports are produced by the Swedish Council on Technology Assessment in Health Care, and describe the new methods and their effects.

This report summarises the methods and effects for maternal serum screening  for Down's Syndrome. It concludes that "there is good scientific documentation on the diagnostic characteristics of the serum marker test. There is poor scientific documentation on a range of different consequences in clinical use. Using serum markers may have potential advantages, but until further evidence becomes available they should be used only in cases that allow scientific followup of the intended, and unintended, effects".

A more recent review of the literature is reported in Methods of Early Prenatal Diagnosis, SBU report 182, published 2006.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Meta-analysis on the validity of pepsinogen test fro gastric carcinoma, dysplasia or chronic atrophic gastritis screening
document.publisher: Journal of Medical Screening, Royal Society of Medicine Press
document.body:
Authors' conclusions: Pepsinogen test definition should include pepsinogen I/II ratio as consistency was obtained, both in population based studies and in selected groups for those studies that used pepsinogen I serum levels together with pepsinogen I/II ratio for screening for gastric cancer in high-incidence regions other than Japan. Further studies of this test in the management of high-risk patients seem to be worthwhile.  

 

Method: Meta-analysis of 42 studies 

 

Results: 42 studies were included. 27 were population-based screening studies incorporating 296,553 individuals. 15 were of selected groups and incorporated 4,385 individuals.

 

Citation: Dinis-Ribeiro M, Yamaki G, Miki K, et al. Meta-analysis on the validity of pepsinogen test for gastric carcinoma, dysplasia or chronic atrophic gastritis screening. Journal of Medical Screening 2004;11(3):141-7

 

Access: Full access available with NHS Athens account.

 

This meta-analysis has not been critically appraised.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Methods of early prenatal diagnosis
document.publisher: Swedish Council on Technology Assessment in Health Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ANTENATAL,SCREENING,FETAL ANOMALY,NEURAL TUBE DEFECTS,DOWN'S SYNDROME (NUCHAL TRANSLUCENCY),18-20 WEEKS,DOWN'S SYNDROME (SERUM),14-20 WEEKS,BEFORE 16 WEEKS,11-14 WEEKS,ULTRASOUND]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ This report presents the scientific evidence for the methods currently used, or in the process of being adopted, to detect fetal chromosomal and structural abnormalities during early pregnancy. Medical, social, psychological, ethical, health economic, quality assurance and safety aspects of early prenatal diagnosis were analysed. This summary reviews the questions addressed and the most important conclusions reached in each chapter of the report.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Methods of prediction and prevention of pre-eclampsia: systematic reviews of accuracy and effectiveness literature with economic modelling
document.body:
Objectives: To investigate the accuracy of predictive tests for pre-eclampsia and the effectiveness of preventative interventions for pre-eclampsia. Also to assess the cost-effectiveness of strategies
(test - intervention combinations) to predict and prevent pre-eclampsia.


 

Data sources: Major electronic databases were searched to January 2005 at least.

 

Review methods: Systematic reviews were carried out for test accuracy and effectiveness. Quality assessment was carried out using standard tools. For test accuracy, meta-analyses used a bivariate approach.
Effectiveness reviews were conducted under the auspices of the Cochrane Pregnancy and Childbirth Group and used standard Cochrane review methods. The economic evaluation was from an NHS perspective and used a decision tree model.

 

Results: For the 27 tests reviewed, the quality of included studies was generally poor. Some tests appeared to have high specificity, but at the expense of compromised sensitivity. Tests that reached specificities
above 90% were body mass index > 34, alpha-foetoprotein and uterine artery Doppler (bilateral notching). The only Doppler test with a sensitivity of over 60% was resistance index and combinations of indices. A few tests not commonly found in routine practice, such as kallikreinuria and SDS-PAGE proteinuria, seemed to offer the promise of high sensitivity, without compromising specificity, but these would require further investigation. For the 16 effectiveness reviews, the quality of included studies was variable. The largest review was of antiplatelet agents, primarily low-dose aspirin, and included 51 trials (36,500 women). This was the only review where
the intervention was shown to prevent both preeclampsia and its consequences for the baby. Calcium supplementation also reduced the risk of preeclampsia, but with some uncertainty about the impact on outcomes for the baby. The only other intervention associated with a reduction in RR of pre-eclampsia was rest at home, with or without a nutritional supplement, for women with normal blood pressure. However, this review included just two small trials and its results should be interpreted with caution. The cost of most of the tests was modest, ranging from £5 for blood tests such as serum uric acid to approximately £20 for Doppler tests. Similarly, the cost of most interventions was also modest. In contrast, the best estimate of additional average cost associated with an average case of pre-eclampsia was high at approximately £9000. The results of the modelling revealed that prior testing with the test accuracy sensitivities and specificities identified appeared to offer little as a way of improving cost-effectiveness. Based on the evidence reviewed, none of the tests appeared sufficiently accurate to be clinically useful and the results of the model favoured no-test/treat-all strategies. Rest at home without any initial testing appeared to be the most cost-effective ‘test–treatment’ combination. Calcium supplementation to all women, without any initial testing, appeared to be the second most cost-effective. The economic model provided little support that any form of Doppler test has
sufficiently high sensitivity and specificity to be costeffective for the early identification of pre-eclampsia. It also suggested that the pattern of cost-effectiveness was no different in high-risk mothers than the low-risk mothers considered in the base case.

 

Conclusions: The tests evaluated are not sufficiently accurate, in our opinion, to suggest their routine use in clinical practice. Calcium and antiplatelet agents, primarily low-dose aspirin, were the interventions
shown to prevent pre-eclampsia. The most costeffective approach to reducing pre-eclampsia is likely to be the provision of an effective, affordable and safe intervention applied to all mothers without prior testing to assess levels of risk. It is probably premature to suggest the implementation of a treat-all intervention strategy at present, however the feasibility and acceptability of this to women could be explored. Rigorous evaluation is needed of tests with modest cost whose initial assessments suggest that they may have high levels of both sensitivity and specificity. Similarly, there is a need for high-quality, adequately powered randomised controlled trials to investigate whether interventions such as advice to rest are indeed effective in reducing pre-eclampsia. In future, an economic
model should be developed that considers not just pre-eclampsia, but other related outcomes, particularly those relevant to the infant such as perinatal death, preterm birth and small for gestational age. Such a
modelling project should make provision for primary data collection on the safety of interventions and their associated costs.

 

Full reference: Meads CA, Cnossen JS, Meher S, Juarez-Garcia A, ter Riet G, Duley L, et al. Methods of prediction and prevention of pre-eclampsia: systematic reviews of accuracy and effectiveness literature with economic modelling. Health Technology Assessment 2008;12(6).

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Multi-slice/helical computed tomography for lung cancer screening
document.publisher: Canadian Coordinating Office for Health Technology Assessment
document.body:
The Canadian Coordinating Office for Health Technology Assessment (CCOHTA) publishes Issues in Emerging Health Technologies, a series of bulletins highlighting technologies.

This bulletin looks at the use of helical computed tomography for lung cancer screening and summarises by stating that "compared to chest radiography, multislice/helical computed tomography (CT) is able to detect lung cancers of smaller size and at an earlier stage...however, the rate of detecting benign lung nodules is high using these technologies.....presently, even for smokers, screening for lung cancer with multi-slice/helical CT would be premature".

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Multi-slice/spiral computed tomography for screening for coronary artery disease
document.publisher: Canadian Coordinating Office for Health Technology Assessment
document.body:
The Canadian Coordinating Office for Health Technology Assessment (CCOHTA) publishes Issues in Emerging Health Technologies, a series of bulletins highlighting technologies.

This bulletin looks at the use of spiral computed tomography (CT) for screening for coronary artery disease and summarises by stating that "there is insufficient evidence at this time to suggest that asymptomatic people derive clinical benefit from undergoing coronary calcification screening using multislice computed tomography (MSCT) or spiral CT scanning"

]]>

document.title: National Chlamydia Screening Programme Phase 3 Guide
document.topics: <![CDATA[ MANAGEMENT,CHLAMYDIA,SCREENING,IMPLEMENTATION,ADULT,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,CHLAMYDIA,BACTERIAL,MALE SEXUALLY TRANSMITTED INFECTIONS,MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,CHLAMYDIA]]>
document.body:
This guide has been put together to support Strategic Health Authorities and Primary Care Trusts establish the chlamydia screening programme in local areas. It contains information and materials that have been developed following experience with implementing the programme so far. The information is not prescriptive but aims to facilitate development of common structures, processes and outputs.

]]>

document.title: National Education and Training Needs Analysis for Antenatal and the Newborn Blood Spot Screening Services across England 2007
document.body:
This national survey was carried out by the UK NSC Regional Teams and Education Lead in 2007 to ascertain education and training needs and preferred methodology in relation to the NHS antenatal and newborn screening programmes. Recommendations from the reports have informed the NHS education action plan.

This follows on from the Training Needs Analysis survey in 2004.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: National Knowledge Week for Antenatal Care 1st - 7th October 2007
document.body:
111-1National Knowledge Week for Antenatal Care 1st - 7th October 2007

     

                                                  

 

National Knowledge Weeks contain recent, relevant evidence and summaries written by health professionals, on particular topics. The screening specialist collection and the women's health specialist collection welcome you to the National Knowledge Week on Antenatal Care 1st -7th October 2007. As part of this National Knowledge Week:

 

  • the screening specialist collection has created entries on Antenatal and Newborn Screening topics - each topic contains a summary written by a health professional with associated references, an annual evidence update and information to give pregnant women and/or parents
  • the women's health specialist collection has created entries on Antenatal Care, including common pregnancy problems

 

Contents

 

Preconception Care

 

Screening for Sickle Cell and Thalassaemia (antenatal and newborn)

 

Screening for Down's Syndrome

 

Screening for Infectious Diseases in Pregnancy

 

Screening for Fetal Anomalies

 

Newborn and Infant Physical Examination (NIPE)

 

Newborn Bloodspot Screening

 

Newborn Hearing Screening (this is an external link to the newborn hearing screening section of the National Knowledge Week for Hearing -  produced by the ENT and Audiology specialist collection in March 2007)

 

Antenatal Care - including information needs, common pregnancy problems, antenatal care, ultrasound and fetal heart rate monitoring (this is an external link to the National Knowledge Week on Antenatal Care section produced by the women's health specialist collection)

 

 

Contributors

 

Summaries for screening sections: Sandra Anglin, Lyn Bryant, Christine Cavanagh, Jean Chapple, Cathy Coppinger, David Elliman, Adam Fisher, John Marshall, Catherine Peckham, Allison Streetly, Fiona Vicente, Pat Ward

 

Evidence updates, project management, page design and creation: Nicola Pearce-Smith

 

Thanks to: Jo Harcombe, Nic Rosen, all Antenatal and Child Health Screening Co-ordinators

 

]]>

document.description: The National Screening Committee's Policy on screening for beta-ketothiolase deficiency, glutaric acidaemia type I, hydroxymethylglutaric aciduria, isovaleric acidaemia, 3 Methylcrotonyl CoA carboxylase deficiency, methylmalonic acidaemia, multiple carboxylase deficiency and proprionic acidaemia (in the newborn)
document.body:
111-1National Screening Committee policy - organic acid metabolism disorder screening

This policy covers the following rare inherited organic acid metabolism disorders:

 

Beta-ketothiolase deficiency
Glutaric acidaemia type I
Hydroxymethylglutaric aciduria
Isovaleric acidaemia
3 Methylcrotonyl CoA carboxylase deficiency
Methylmalonic acidaemia, Cbl A and Cbl B forms
Methylmalonic acidaemia, mutase deficiency form
Multiple carboxylase deficiency
Proprionic acidaemia

 

National Screening Committee current policy position

Systematic population screening programme not recommended

 

Full policy and supporting evidence

 

]]>

document.body:
This report is a comprehensive training needs analysis for the provision of antenatal screening services in England. It provides valuable information for staff assisting in the facilitation and delivery of quality education and training.

A subsequent survey on Education and Training Needs was carried out in 2007.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Neonatal screening of inborn errors of metabolism using tandem mass spectrometery
document.publisher: Ministry of Health and Long-Term Care, Canada
document.body:
The Medical Advisory Secretariat, Ontario, Canada provides evidence-based policy advice on the coordinated uptake of new health technologies and health services, by conducting systematic reviews of scientific evidence and consultation with experts in the medical community.

This Health Technology Scientific literature review looks at the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of using tandem mass spectrometer for the neonatal screening of inborn errors of metabolism.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Newborn and Infant Physical Examination - standards and competencies
document.publisher: NHS Antenatal and Newborn Screening Programmes
document.body: <![CDATA[ This document provides information on pathways, standards and competencies for the screening components of the Child Health Promotion Programme examinations, namely examination of the hips, eyes, testes and cardiovascular system.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Newborn and Infant Physical Examination (National Knowledge Week)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SCREENING,SCREENING,OPHTHALMOLOGY,NEONATOLOGY,MUSCULOSKELETAL,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,CONDITIONS,CARDIOLOGY,CHILD HEALTH,EYES,HEART,TESTES,CONGENITAL HEART DISEASE,CONGENITAL ABNORMALITIES,EXAMINATION OF THE NEONATE,CONGENITAL ABNORMALITIES,NEONATAL,SPECIALTIES,STAFF USE,PHYSICAL (<72HRS),NEWBORN,DIAGNOSIS,CONGENITAL HEART DISEASE,HIPS,KNOWLEDGE UPDATES]]>
document.body:
111-1Newborn and Infant Physical Examination (National Knowledge Week)

     

Back to Contents page

Annual Evidence Updates: Congenital Cataract, Congenital Heart Disease, Cryptorchidism, Hip Dysplasia

 

This section has been written by Dr. David Elliman, National Screening Committee

 

The Newborn and Infant Physical Examination

A detailed examination of the newborn baby soon after birth and again at 6-8 weeks has been considered routine for decades. However, apart from guidance on examination of the hips [1] and successive editions of the Hall report [2], there has been no central guidance on the examination, in general, or more specifically on the screening components.

 

Guidance on the examination was set out in the recent NICE guideline on Postnatal Care [3]. Standards for the screening components:

  • examination of the heart
  • hips
  • eyes
  • and, in boys, the testes

have been drawn up by a multidisciplinary group under the auspices of the National Screening Committee. The same group has also looked at the competencies needed of the professionals who carry out the examination. These standards and competencies will be launched in the autumn.

 

Work will now be undertaken to ensure that healthcare workers are properly trained and that the examination and its outcome are audited to ensure that the standards are attained and maintained. Currently very little data is collected and so there is much work to be done before these goals can be attained.

 

Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip (DDH)
Previously known as ‘congenital dislocation of the hip’, the name was changed to emphasise that the condition is not always present at birth and is due to malformation of the socket of the ball and socket joint. There is no gold standard for diagnosis and so it is not possible to give accurate figures for the prevalence. The incidence of cases needing operative treatment is 1-2 per 1,000 liveborn infants.

 

However many more infants have unstable hips that become stable while under observation. Treatment is aimed at stabilising the hips, initially with a splint. If this fails, an operation may be necessary.
The mainstay of screening is clinical examination, using the Barlow and Ortolani tests. However, even when performed competently soon after birth and again at 6-8 weeks, late detected DDH is not eliminated.

 

Limited experience of ultrasound examination of the hips of all babies suggests that this may be more sensitive, but may be associated with considerable over-treatment. As treatment may itself damage the hip, this is an important consideration and is one of the reasons why universal ultrasound is not recommended. It is however recommended in babies with a history of clinically detected breech presentation during pregnancy or where there is a first degree family history of DDH.

 

Recent systematic reviews [4],[5] have reiterated these concerns and pointed out that the evidence base for this screening programme is not strong. In particular there are no randomised controlled trials (RCTs) comparing the long term outcome after various forms of screening, compared with no screening. Because screening is so widespread, it is unlikely that such studies will ever be done. However it is incumbent on those who are responsible for screening programmes to ensure that staff are competent for the task and that the programme has appropriate quality controls in place.

 

Cryptorchidism (Undescended Testes –UDT)
Undescended testes are found in about 2% of male infants at birth. This figure goes down to about 1% at 3 months and then changes little over the next year. The condition is important for a number of reasons. It may be associated with other problems such as hypospadias and apparent bilateral undescended testes may be an indication of congenital adrenal hyperplasia. Undescended testes are associated with an increased risk of torsion, subfertility and malignancy.

 

While there is little debate that boys with indescended testes should have treatment to fix the affected testis in the scrotum (orchidopexy), there is no good evidence that this changes the risk of malignancy developing and evidence of its effect on fertility is inconsistent [6]. As changes in the affected testis are seen early in life, it is generally agreed that surgery should take place before starting school. Many authorities recommend surgery between the first and second birthdays.

 

It used to be assumed that when a boy was noted to have an undescended testis at an older age, this was because they had not been examined properly. Recently [7], it has become apparent that a proportion, at least, of these have testes that were at one stage normally placed, but have ascended. This issue will need to be addressed by the National Screening Committee.

 

Congenital Heart Disease (CHD) [8]
Congenital heart disease covers a very wide spectrum of disease, from ventricular septal defects which often resolve spontaneously to conditions that have a very high mortality. The overall incidence is about 1 in 100 livebirths, but the incidence of the latter is only 1 in 1,000 live births. Of the order of 1 in 200 will need active treatment.

 

Screening is justified on the basis that planned surgery is more likely to result in a better outcome than emergency surgery, both in terms of mortality and morbidity. It is also likely to be less distressing for parents.

 

The main stay of the screening programme is physical examination of all elements of the cardiovascular system and a history of feeding. Echocardiography is only appropriate as part of further assessment, or as part of assessment of children at high risk, such as those with Down Syndrome. On the other hand, pulse oximetry may have a part to play and further work on this has been commissioned.

 

Whatever the primary screening modality, it is essential that there is timely access to an experienced clinician who can make a definitive diagnosis, in order to facilitate early surgical treatment if necessary.

 

Abnormalities of the Eyes
This examination is designed to pick up structural abnormalities of the eyes, not to check vision. The main abnormalities being sought are ocular cataracts and retinoblastoma. They are rare (2 or 3 in 10,000 live births). Screening is based on inspection of the eyes and examination for the red reflex. Unfortunately detection rates are low [9]. This may be due to poor examination technique.

 

References 

 

[1] Standing Medical Advisory Committee. Screening for the detection of congenital dislocation of the hip in infants. London: Department of Health and Social Security, 1966. Revised 1986

 

[2] Hall DM and Elliman D, ed. (2006). Health for All Children. 4th ed. revised. Oxford: Oxford University Press.

 

[3] NICE clinical guideline 37. Routine postnatal care of women and their babies. 2006.

 

[4] Shipman SA, Helfand M, Moyer VA, Yawn BP. Screening for developmental dysplasia of the hip: A systematic literature review for the US Preventive Services Task Force. Pediatrics 2006;117(3):e557-e576.

 

[5] York: Centre for Reviews and Dissemination (CRD). Systematic review of the clinical and cost effectiveness of ultrasound in screening for developmental dysplasia of the hip in newborns. April 2006. [CRD abstract]. Note - original article: Woolacott N, Puhan MA, Misso K, Steurer S, Kleijnen J. CRD Report 28. 2005.

 

[6] Murphy F, Paran TS, Puri P. Orchidopexy and its impact on fertility. Pediatric Surgery International 2007;23(7):625-632. [PubMed abstract]

 

[7] Martin JDC. Further evidence for acquired undescended testicle in the UK and its incompatibility with current recommendations in the Hall Report. Journal of Pediatric Urology 2006;2(5):392-397. [Journal website abstract]

 

[8] Knowles R, Griebsch I, Dezateux C, Brown J,Bull C, Wren C. Newborn screening for congenital heart defects: a systematic review and cost-effectiveness analysis. Health Technol Assess 2005;9(44):1–168.

 

[9] Rahi J, Dezateux C. National cross sectional study of detection of congenital and infantile cataract in the United Kingdom: role of childhood screening and surveillance   BMJ 1999;318:362-365.

 

 

Annual evidence updates on newborn and infant physical screening 2006/07

The Screening Library has identified the new evidence published over the last year, and the results of our search are classified and presented as evidence updates below

 

Congenital cataract

 

Congenital Heart Disease

 

Cryptorchidism (undescended testes)

 

Developmental dysplasia of the hip

Additional references (selected from the above annual evidence updates)

 

Guidance


Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality, U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. Screening for Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip. Evidence Synthesis no. 42. March 2006.

 

Systematic reviews

Thangaratinam S, Daniels J, Ewer AK, Zamora J, Khan KS. Accuracy of pulse oximetry in screening for congenital heart disease in asymptomatic newborns: a systematic review. Archives of Disease in Childhood Fetal & Neonatal Edition 2007, 92(3):F176-80 [PubMed abstract]

 

Other information for health professionals

Information to give parents

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Newborn Bloodspot Screening (National Knowledge Week)
document.body:
111-1Newborn Bloodspot Screening (National Knowledge Week)

      

Back to Contents page

Annual Evidence Updates: Congenital hypothyroidism, Cystic Fibrosis, MCADD, Phenylketonuria, Sickle cell

 

This section has been written by Christine Cavanagh/Cathy Coppinger, Programme Manager (job share), UK Newborn Screening Programme Centre

 

UK Newborn Screening Programme Centre: Bloodspot screening

The UK Newborn Screening Programme Centre was established in 2002 with the overall objective of assuring high quality screening services for babies and their parents through the development of a quality assurance programme and performance management framework for the blood spot screening programmes. The first version of performance standards governing the overall programme together with a framework for its performance management were launched by the Programme Centre in December 2004 and are currently being reviewed. These have led to a more joined-up approach to assuring its quality.

 

New blood sampling guidelines will be available at the end October ’07 from the UK Newborn Screening Programme Centre:  http://www.newbornbloodspot.screening.nhs.uk

 

The national newborn screening programme for phenylketonuria (PKU) was introduced in 1969 and, for congenital hypothyroidism (CHT) in 1981. Today newborn screening is one of the largest such programmes in the UK and each year over 725,000 newborns are screened. The newborn blood spot screening programme has been and remains a very successful one, and the uptake of screening tests is high, with local audits showing that more than 99% of the babies born each year are being screened.

 

Each year approximately 400 babies with phenylketonuria or congenital hypothyroidism are identified through screening, allowing effective treatments to be started before irreversible neurological damage has occurred, preventing lifelong disability.

 

More recently in England, screening for sickle cell disorders (SCD) [see the entry for Screening for Sickle Cell and Thalassaemia National Knowledge Week] and cystic fibrosis (CF) has been introduced, and in February 2007 a screening programme was announced for screening for medium chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency (MCADD) [1]. Screening for all of these conditions utilises the same blood sample used for PKU and CHT screening, formally known as the ‘Guthrie’ card.


 

Medium Chain Acyl-CoA Dehydrogenase Deficiency (MCADD)

 

MCADD is a rare inherited disorder of fatty acid metabolism. It occurs mainly among people of north-western European origin [2] [3] Males and females are affected equally. MCADD occurs when the enzyme called medium chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase is either missing, or not functioning properly.  This enzyme breaks down fats from food, and from within the body, to convert into energy. 

 

Babies affected by MCADD often do not show any symptoms straight after birth. Symptoms typically appear for the first time when a child is between 3 months and 3 years old [2]. This usually happens following a period of fasting, infection, or stress, for example if the child feels unwell and does not want to eat, or vomits [3]. Symptoms can be highly variable [3], but may include drowsiness or lethargy, diarrhoea, vomiting and fits. The child may go into a coma. This is called a metabolic crisis.  

 

If MCADD is not identified early and treated, children affected by the disorder may experience repeated metabolic crises and result in breathing problems, seizures, brain damage, cardiac arrest or sudden death.  Conservative estimates suggest that without newborn screening, at least half of children born with MCADD will have a metabolic crisis and between 1 in 4 and up to 1 in 5 will die or experience severe disability [3] [5]

 

Research evidence suggests that between one in 10,000 and one in 20,000 babies born in the UK is affected by MCADD [2]. Newborn screening throughout England should identify around 60 cases each year. It is thought that around 1 in 80 healthy people are carriers of MCADD.  These people do not have any symptoms.  However, if both parents are MCADD carriers, they have a one in four chance of having an affected child, in each pregnancy.

 

In a large-scale pilot study conducted between 2004 and 2006, approximately three-quarters of a million babies were screened for MCADD in England. The study showed that newborn screening reliably identifies children affected by MCADD.  Identifying newborns affected by MCADD allows parents to use simple measures to avoid fasting and to ensure a regular, adequate energy intake for their child, thereby reducing the chances of severe, life-threatening episodes of illness.

 

On the basis of these findings and evidence from other studies worldwide, the National Screening Committee, which advises Ministers on proposed screening programmes, recommended the introduction of an MCADD screening programme in England.

 

Several studies looking at screened cohorts with MCADD have reported that the children show no neurological impairment, but longer-term follow up is necessary before any firm conclusions can be drawn on this issue [3]. The evidence suggests that screening all babies for MCADD makes significant health gains as well as being financially viable. A systematic review conducted in 2004 concluded that the use of tandem mass spectrometry to screen for MCADD would be highly cost-effective [4] [6].

 

The Programme Centre is leading the implementation of MCADD screening in England. Those areas, which piloted the National protocol, now form Phase 1 of the screening programme. Phase 2 will be comprised of the areas served by the remaining seven screening laboratories in England, who were not involved in the pilot. It is planned that screening will be offered to all babies in the catchment areas of the remaining 7 laboratories by April 2009.

 

Phase1: Birmingham, Leeds, London (GOSH), London (Guy’s), Manchester, Sheffield.

Phase 2: Cambridge, Bristol, Liverpool, London (Carshalton), Portsmouth, Newcastle and Oxford.


 

Cystic Fibrosis (CF)

In cystic fibrosis there is a problem transporting chloride across cell membranes. This affects certain organs in the body, particularly the pancreas and lungs. The thick secretions in these organs cause digestive problems and chest infections. The abnormal transport of chloride in sweat glands leads to an increased level of chloride in their sweat. This is the basis of the ‘sweat test’, often used to investigate suspected cases. As from Sept 2007, all of the UK screens for newborn CF.

 

Diagnosis of CF can be made by looking for alterations (mutations) in the CF gene. This gene is called the cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator or CFTR gene. Alterations to this gene can cause CF. Whilst
some alterations usually cause severe symptoms, others are more often associated with milder forms of CF.

 

Cystic fibrosis can affect the baby before birth. Fifteen per cent of affected babies are born with blocked intestines, a condition called meconium ileus. Without screening, about 70% of babies with CF show some symptoms by the time they have a diagnostic sweat test [7].  These can include problems absorbing food, as well as breathing problems. One study found that all babies with CF examined during their first year had inflamed airways and in some it was present by four weeks.7 Eventually all patients with CF develop long-term chest infections. Now most people with CF can expect to live into adulthood [8].

 

In the UK there are 40 babies born with cystic fibrosis in every 100,000 births, the equivalent of 4 in every 10,000 or one in every 2500 babies [9]. Of the 750,000 babies born in the UK each year, about 300 babies have CF.

 

CF is caused by a large number (over 1200 are known) of different alterations on the CFTR gene. The most common in the UK is called Delta F508. It accounts for between 55% and 85% of all detected CF alterations, depending on the area. UK screening laboratories only test for between 19 and 31 of the most common alterations out of the 1200+ identified. This means newborn screening will not identify some babies with rare alterations on the CFTR gene. Whilst most of the common alterations on the CFTR gene are known to cause CF (referred to from now on as ‘CF-causing alterations’), other alterations don’t cause CF, and others are not yet well understood.

 

Babies with CF are treated vigorously as soon as they are first diagnosed. New guidelines on sweat testing are now available [10]. Treatment of children with CF aims to do two things:

 

  • improve nutrition by providing supplements containing enzymes to help digestion

 

  • reduce chest infections with frequent physiotherapy and either occasional or continuous
       antibiotics.


Studies have demonstrated benefits, including in the areas of nutrition, cognitive function, pulmonary function, and survival. [11] [12] [13]. Newborn screening for CF may also reduce any delays in diagnosis, reducing anxiety and uncertainty about why the child is ill [14]. Having said that, a confirmed diagnosis following newborn screening can also take time and cause parents anxiety [16] [17]. New patient information is now available on CF and the laboratory tests involved [18] [19].

 

Longer-term benefits of screening are hard to assess, as improved treatments make living with CF better than in the past (whether or not a person is diagnosed through screening). Early diagnosis of a baby with CF through screening can also alert the parents to their risk of having other affected children. Treatment can slow down the effects of the disease, but cannot stop it progressing. Now, half of those with CF live to be over 30 years old.


 

Congenital Hypothyroidism (CHT)

Congenital hypothyroidism (CHT) is a condition where, for one of a number of reasons, the thyroid gland doesn’t work when a baby is born and fails to make sufficient amounts of the thyroid hormone called thyroxine. The thyroid gland usually starts working in the unborn fetus from about 20 weeks gestation. The mother’s own thyroid doesn’t provide enough thyroxine to maintain sufficiently high levels in the fetus. Scientific and medical evidence has been growing that the tests used may not work properly for premature babies. 

 

In summary all babies should have:

 

  • Repeat blood spot sample at equivalent of 35 weeks + 7 days

 

  • Repeat blood test up to 1 chronological year of age for those not having the repeat test at the equivalent of 36 week

 

  • Repeat using a blood spot card, unless have normal ranges for whole blood and wish to use that approach.

 

In very severe cases of CHT, babies are born with, or quickly develop, the following symptoms: a very low hair-line, a protruding tongue, cold skin, protruding tummy button, jaundice, feeding difficulties, constipation, and generally sluggish behaviour. However, only very few babies will have all of these symptoms and primary CHT is rarely diagnosed by clinical means in the newborn period.

 

If babies with CHT are not treated, they fail to grow properly and will have ‘mild to severe’ mental disability. In the most severe cases children also have a lack of co-ordination, jerky movements and tremors. In general, patients with complete absence of the thyroid gland (called thyroid agenesis) are the most severely affected.

 

In the UK as a whole there are around 25 babies born with CHT in every 100,000 births, the equivalent of 2.5 in every 10,000, or about one in every 4000 births [7]. Of the 750,000 babies born in the UK each year, 185 babies have CHT. Similar rates of CHT are reported in the USA and Europe [21]. It is less common in African and African-American children in the UK [20] and USA [22] but may be higher in children born to mothers of Indian, Pakistani and Bangladeshi origin [20]. More girls have CHT than boys in a ratio of 2.3 girls to every one boy [20].


 

Phenylketonuria (PKU)

People with PKU are unable to break down phenylalanine, an amino acid present in all foods. This is because the liver does not have enough of an enzyme called phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH). This enzyme is needed to convert phenylalanine into tyrosine, which is
essential for normal brain development after birth. People with PKU accumulate too much phenylalanine in the body and not enough tyrosine.

 

A baby with untreated phenylketonuria doesn’t usually show any signs of the condition for the first few months. By the time they are 6-12 months they show delayed mental development. By the time they are two years old they show serious and permanent mental disability.

 

In the UK as a whole there are 11 babies born with PKU in every 100,000 births [23], the equivalent of about one baby in every 10,000. Of the 750,000 babies born in the UK each year, 80 have PKU. The likelihood of having PKU is related to your ethnic origin. PKU is twice as common in Ireland, where there are around 22 babies born with PKU in every 100,000 births. In contrast PKU is very uncommon amongst certain groups, including African-Americans and Ashkenazi Jews.

 

If started early, treatment for PKU is very effective. It involves a special diet and extra minerals and vitamins.

 

References

[1]. National Screening Committee policy - medium chain acyl CoA dehydrogenase deficiency (MCADD) screening Feb 2007.


[2].  Pollitt RJ, Green A, McCabe A, Booth A, Cooper NJ, Leonard JV, et al. Neonatal screening for inborn errors of metabolism: cost, yield and outcome. Health Technology Assessment 1997;1(7):1-203.


[3].  Grosse SD, Khoury SJ, Greene CL, Crider KS, Pollitt RJ. The epidemiology of medium chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency: An update. Genetics in Medicine 2006;8(4):205-12. [PubMed abstract]


[4].  Pandor A, Eastham J, Beverley C, et al. Clinical effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of neonatal screening for inborn errors of metabolism using tandem mass spectrometry: a systematic review. Health Technology Assessment 2004;8:12.

 

[5]. Wilcken B, Haas M, Joy P, Wiley V, Chaplin M, Black C et al. Outcome of neonatal screening for medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency in Australia: a cohort study. Lancet. 2007, 369(9555):37-42. [PubMed abstract]

 

[6]. Tran K, Banerjee S, Li H, Noorani HZ, Mensinkai S, Dooley K. Clinical efficacy and cost-effectiveness of newborn screening for medium chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency using tandem mass spectrometry. Clinical Biochemistry. 2007, 40(3-4):235-41. [PubMed abstract]. Free full text of CRD abstract: http://www.crd.york.ac.uk/crdweb/ShowRecord.asp?View=Full&ID=32006000216 and free full text of HTA report: http://www.cadth.ca/media/pdf/297_tandemmass_tr_e_no-appendices.p

 

[7].  Khan TZ, Wagener JS, Bost T, Martinez J, Accurso F, Riches DWH. Early pulmonary inflammation in infants with cystic fibrosis. Am J Resp Crit Care Med 1995;151:1075-82. [PubMed abstract]

 


[8].  Elborn JS, SHale DJ, Britton JR. Cystic fibrosis: current survival and population estimates to the year 2000. Thorax 1991;46(12):881-5. [PubMed abstract]

 


[9].  Dodge J, Morrison S, Lewis PA, et al. Cystic fibrosis in the United Kingdom, 1968-1988: incidence, population and survival. Pediatr Perinat Epidemiol 1993;7(2):157-166. [PubMed abstract]

 


[10].  Green A, Kirk J, Guidelines Development Group. Guidelines for the performance of the sweat test for the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis. Annals of Clinical Biochemistry. 2007, 44(Pt 1):25-34. [PubMed abstract]. Both the appraisal comments and the full evidence base can be found on http://www.rcpch.ac.uk/doc.aspx?id_Resource=1719 . The full guidelines can also be found at http://www.ukneqas.org.uk/nov2003guideline.pdf

 


[11]. Rock MJ. Newborn screening for cystic fibrosis. Clinics in Chest Medicine. 2007, 28(2):297-305. [PubMed abstract]

 


[12]. Sims EJ, Clark A, McCormick J, Mehta G, Connett G, Mehta A et al. Cystic fibrosis diagnosed after 2 months of age leads to worse outcomes and requires more therapy. Pediatrics. 2007, 119(1):19-28. [PubMed abstract]

 


[13]. Baussano I, Tardivo I, Bellezza-Fontana R, Forneris MP, Lezo A, Anfossi L et al. Neonatal screening for cystic fibrosis does not affect time to first infection with Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Pediatrics. 2006, 118(3):888-95

 


[14] Dankert-Roelse JE, te Meerman GJ. Long term prognosis of patients with cystic fibrosis in relation to early detection by neonatal screening and treatment in a cystic fibrosis centre. Thorax 1995 Jul;50(7):712-8 [PubMed abstract]

 


[16]. Green J, Hewison J, Bekker H, Bryant LD, Cuckle H. Psychological aspects of genetic screening of pregnant women and newborns: a systematic review.  Health Technology Assessment Programme 2004, 8(33).

 


[17]. Moran J, Quirk K, Duff AJ, Brownlee KG. Newborn screening for CF in a regional paediatric centre: the psychosocial effects of false-positive IRT results on parents. Journal of Cystic Fibrosis. 2007, 6(3):250-4. [PubMed abstract]

 


[18]. Clinical Knowledge Summaries (CKS). Patient information leaflet on Cystic Fibrosis. 2007. 

 


[19]. Lab tests online UK 2007.  Sweat chloride test, CF Gene Mutation Testing and Immunoreactive Trypsin 

 

[20]. Grant DB, Smith I. Survey of neonatal screening for primary hypothyroidism in England, Wales, and Northern Ireland 1982-4. British Medical Journal 1988 May 14;296(6633):1355-8.

 


[21].  Toublanc JE. Comparison of epidemiological data on congenital hypothyroidism in Europe with those of other parts of the world. Horm Res 1992;38:230-5. [PubMed abstract]

 


[22].  Lorey F, Cunningham G. Birth prevalence of primary congenital hypothyroidism by sex and ethnicity. Hum Biol 1992;64:531-8. [PubMed abstract]

 


[23]. Smith I, Cook B, Beasley M. Review of neonatal screening programme for phenylketonuria. British Medical Journal 1991 Aug 10;303(6798):333-5.

 

Annual evidence updates on newborn bloodspot screening 2006/07

The Screening Library has identified the new evidence published over the last year, and the results of our search are classified and presented as evidence updates below

 

Congenital hypothyroidism

Grosse SD, Rosenfeld M, Devine OJ, Lai HJ, Farrell PM. Potential impact of newborn screening for cystic fibrosis on child survival: a systematic review and analysis. Journal of Pediatrics.149(3):362-6, 2006 [PubMed abstract]

 

 

Other information for health professionals

This NHS Fetal Anomaly and Down's Syndrome Screening Programme website is for all users of maternity services and health professionals involved in maternity care. It aims to provide information on all aspects of Down's syndrome and fetal anomaly screening

document.title: NHS Infectious Diseases in Pregnancy Screening Programme
document.body:
The infectious diseases in pregnancy screening programme offers screening to all pregnant women for four conditions: Hepatitis B, HIV, Rubella susceptibility and Syphilis.

The website provides information on the four screened conditions for health professionals and the public.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: NHS Newborn & Infant Physical Examination Programme
document.body: <![CDATA[ The NHS Newborn and Infant Physical Examination Programme (NIPE) offers parents of newborn babies the opportunity to have their child examined shortly after birth.  The examination includes a general physical check as well as an examination of the baby’s eyes, heart, hips and testes in boys. The examination is repeated at 6 to 8 weeks, usually by a GP. ]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: NHS Newborn Bloodspot Screening Programme
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SCREENING,IMPLEMENTATION,CONGENITAL HYPOTHYROIDISM,PHENYLKETONURIA,CYSTIC FIBROSIS,SICKLE CELL DISEASE,GENETIC CONDITIONS,GENETIC CONDITIONS A-Z,SYSTEMS & SYMPTOMS,GENETICS - PRACTICE & ISSUES,CONDITIONS N-R,CYSTIC FIBROSIS (CF),MANAGEMENT,LEARNING DISABILITY,SICKLE CELL (SC) (SCD),NEWBORN,BLOODSPOT (<1WK),GENETIC SCREENING (FOR CONDITIONS),NEWBORN BLOODSPOT,CONDITIONS S-Z,CONDITIONS C,PHENYLKETONURIA (PKU),PREGNANCY,BLOOD]]>
document.body:
The UK Newborn Screening Programme Centre has been set up to support the establishment and maintenance of consistent standards in newborn bloodspot screening throughout the UK, for phenylketonuria, congenital hypothyroidism, cystic fibrosis and sickle cell conditions. This Centre will monitor these conditions, along with screening for other inborn errors of metabolism.

This is the Programme Centre website.

]]>

document.body:
The NHS Newborn Hearing Screening Programme (NHSP) ensures all parents are offered hearing screening for their new child within the first few weeks of life. It is a core service within the NHS in England and part of the family of Antenatal & Newborn Screening Programmes.

This is the Programme website.

]]>

document.body:
This is Chapter 2 of the National Service Framework (NSF) for Coronary Heart Disease. It looks at systematic identification of patients with a high-risk of coronary heart disease and modifiable risk factors, systematic provision and documentation of the delivery of appropriate advice, treatment and the offering of regular review, and clinical audit.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Nuchal translucency measurement in the first trimester of pregnancy for screening of trisomy 21 and other autosomal trisomies
document.body:
11-1

This assessment report, produced by the Australian Medical Services Advisory Committee (MSAC), involved a systematic review of the literature and other available data on nuchal translucency (NT) measurement.

The MSAC concluded that "NT screening, and NT screening in conjunction with first trimester maternal biochemical screening are safe and effective where provided by individuals with appropriate expertise in NTS".

There is also a one page summary available.

]]>]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Nutritional screening in community-dwelling older adults: a systematic literature review
document.publisher: Asia Pacific Journal of Clinical Nutrition, HEC Press
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SCREENING,ADULT,LATER LIFE,OLD AGE,NOT ROUTINELY OFFERED,HEALTH & WELLBEING]]>
document.body:
Authors' conclusions: Mini Nutritional Assessment-Short Form seems to be the most appropriate screening tool, although there is some evidence to support the use of two others ('Malnutrition Universal Screening Tool' and 'Seniors in the Community: Risk Evaluation for Eatin and Nutrition (SCREEN) II'). Further research is needed into the acceptability of screening, particularly on outcome and appropriate interventions

 

Method: Medline, PubMed, Cinahl and the Cochrane Library were searched for nutrition screening tools that identify malnutrition or under-nutrition in adults over 65 who live in the community.

 

Results: Ten screening tools were included and subjected to validity and/or reliability testing.

 

Citation: Phillips M, Foley A, Barnard R, et al. Nutritional screening in community-dwelling older adults: a systematic literature review. Asia Pacific Journal of Clinical Nutrition 2010; 19(3):440-9

 

Access: Abstract available

 

This systematic review/meta-analysis has not been critically appraised.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Option appraisal: screening for prostate cancer: report to the UK National Screening Committee
document.publisher: School of Health and Related Research (ScHARR)
document.body:
The aim of the study was to develop a mathematical model to estimate the costs, benefits and resource implications of alternative screening options for prostate cancer in the UK. The impacts of four screening options using the prostate specific antigen (PSA) blood test conducted are assessed in comparison to no screening and to each other:

  • a single screen at age 50 years,
  • screening every four years from age 50 to 74 years,
  • screening every two years from age 50 to 74 years,
  • screening every year from age 50 to 74 years.

In addition a range of further screening options investigating the impact of screening
at different ages and over different durations have also been examined.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Osteoporosis and fractures among people aged 65 and over: recommendations for an integrated framework for action in Quebec
document.publisher: Agence d'Evaluation des Technologies et des Modes d'Intervention en Sante
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SCREENING,ADULT,OSTEOPOROSIS,SCREENING AND SURVEILLANCE,LATER LIFE,OSTEOPOROSIS,SCREENING,NOT ROUTINELY OFFERED]]>
document.body:
Agence d’évaluation des technologies et des modes d’intervention en santé (AETMIS), is the Québec (Canada) government agency responsible for health services and technology assessment. They produce reports on various matters relating to health management.

AETMIS have reviewed 11 international reports on osteoporosis screening, as a starting point for recommendations for a framework of action on fighting osteoporosis and fractures in Quebec. Their report concludes that "based on the evidence, none of the 11 reports studied recommends universal bone density screening, i.e. among individuals who present no symptoms of osteoporosis and do not request the test".

 

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Overdiagnosis in publicly organised mammography screening programmes: systematic review of incidence trends
document.body:
Abstract
Objective: To estimate the extent of overdiagnosis (the detection of cancers that will not cause death or symptoms) in publicly organised screening programmes.
Design Systematic review of published trends in incidence of breast cancer before and after the introduction of mammography screening.

Review methods: One author extracted data on incidence of breast cancer (including carcinoma in situ), population size, screening uptake, time periods, and age groups, which were checked independently by the other author. Linear regression was used to estimate trends in incidence before and after the introduction of screening and in older, previously screened women. Meta-analysis was used to estimate the extent of overdiagnosis.

Results: Incidence data covering at least seven years before screening and seven years after screening had been fully implemented, and including both screened and non-screened age groups, were available from the United Kingdom; Manitoba, Canada; New South Wales, Australia; Sweden; and parts of Norway. The implementation phase with its prevalence peak was excluded and adjustment made for changing background incidence and compensatory drops in incidence among older, previously screened women. Overdiagnosis was estimated at 52% (95% confidence interval 46% to 58%). Data from three countries showed a drop in incidence as the women exceeded the age limit for screening, but the reduction was small and the estimate of overdiagnosis was compensated for in this review.

Conclusions: The increase in incidence of breast cancer was closely related to the introduction of screening and little of this increase was compensated for by a drop in incidence of breast cancer in previously screened women. One in three breast cancers detected in a population offered organised screening is overdiagnosed.

Full reference:
Jørgensen KJ and Gøtzsche PC. Overdiagnosis in publicly organised mammography screening programmes: systematic review of incidence trends. BMJ 2009;339:b2587

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Performance characteristics of postpartum screening tests for type 2 diabetes mellitus in women with a history of gestational diabetes mellitus: a systematic review
document.publisher: Journal of Women's Health, Mary Ann Liebert, Inc.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SCREENING,ANTENATAL,ADULT,DIABETES,NOT ROUTINELY OFFERED,NOT ROUTINELY OFFERED,VASCULAR RISK]]>
document.body:
Authors' conclusions: Compared to the oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT), fasting blood glucose (FBG) on its own was not consistently sensitive to screen for type 2 diabetes in women with a history of gestational diabetes.

 

Method: Electronic databases were searched up to October 2 2008. Titles and abstracts were reviewed by two investigators and assessed for quality.

 

Results: 11 studies, including 13 evaluations, comparing OGTT with FBG were included.

 

Citation: Bennett WL, Bolen S, Wilson LM et al. Performance characteristics of postpartum screening tests for type 2 diabetes mellitus in women with  a history of gestational diabetes mellitus: a systematic review. Journal of Women's Health 2009; 18(7):979-87

 

Access: Full text freely available via UK PubMed Central

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Population based screening for chronic kidney disease: cost-effectiveness study
document.body:
Authors' conclusions: Population based screening for chronic kidney disease is not cost effective by assessment of estimated glomerular filtration rate, overall or in subgroups of people with hypertension or older people. Targeted screening of people with diabetes is acceptable in comparison to other interventions funded by public health systems.

 

Method: Cost utility analysis of screening with estimated glomerular filtration rate alone compared with no screening, defined by age, diabetes and presence or absence of proteinuria. Costs were estimated by age, diabetes and hypertension.

 

Results: Population based screening was associated with an incremental cost of CAN$463 and a gain of 0.0044 QALYs per patient overall, meaning a cost per QALY gained of CAN$104900. In a cohort of 100,000 people, screening for chronic kidney disease would be expected to reduce the number of people who develop end stage renal disease over their lifetime from 675 to 657. The cost per QALY gained was CAN$22600 and CAN$572000 in subgroups of people with and without diabetes respectively. In a cohort of 100,000 people with diabetes, screening would be expected to reduce the number of people who develop end stage renal disease over their lifetime from 1796 to 1741. In people without diabetes with and without hypertension, the cost per QALY gained was CAN$334000 and CAN$1411100 respectively.

 

Citation: Manns B, Hemmelgarn B, Tonelli M et al. Population based screening for chronic kidney disease: cost-effectiveness study. BMJ 2010; 341:c5869 doi:10.1136/bmj.c5869

 

Access: Full text freely available

]]>

document.description: Report on screening for hypertrophic cardiomyopathy commissioned by NSC
document.body:
This report was commissioned by the National Screening Committee (NSC) in 2008. It updates a previous review of the evidence on screening for hypertrophic cardiomyopathy carried out for the NSC in 2003.

The aim of the project reported here was to consider the extent to which existing evidence supports the implementation of a population screening programme for HCM.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Population screening for lung cancer using computed tomography, is there evidence of clinical effectiveness? A systematic review of the literature
document.body:
Authors' conclusions: There is currently insufficient evidence that screening for lung cancer by computed tomography is clinically effective in reducing mortality from lung cancer.

 

Method: Systematic literature review. 15 databases and internet resources searched from 1994 to December/January 2005.

 

Results: Twelve studies, including two randomized controleed trials and 10 studies without control groups were included. The proportion of abnormal findings varied widely (5-51%). Prevalence of lung cancer detected was between 0.4% and 3.2%, with the number needed to screen to detect one lung cancer being between 31 and 249.

 

Citation: Black C, de Verteuil R, Walker S et al. Population screening for lung cancer using computed tomography, is there evidence of clinical effectiveness? A systematic review of the literature. Thorax 2007; 62(2)131-8

 

Access: Full text available with NHS Athens account

]]>

document.title: Potential impact of newborn screening for cystic fibrosis on child survival: a systematic review and analysis
document.description: Systematic review published in J Pediatrics
document.body:
J Pediatrics. 2006 Sep;149(3):362-6.

Note: This reference is indexed in Medline, and has been established as a systematic review using specific criteria. It does not yet appear in any pre-appraised source and so the quality of the research has not been assessed.

OBJECTIVE: to estimate impact of child mortality as a result of cystic fibrosis (CF) potentially preventable by newborn screening.

CONCLUSION: newborn screening for CF may result in improved child survival.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Preconception Care (National Knowledge Week)
document.body:
111-1Preconception Care (National Knowledge Week)

     

 Back to Contents page

Annual Evidence Update

 

This section has been written by Dr. Jean Chapple, Child Health Screening Co-ordinator, London

 

Preconception care


There are currently no UK national guidelines for preconception care, despite several national reports [1] [2] stressing the need for risk assessment, education and health promotion to maximise the chance of a healthy pregnancy, mother, baby and family. Information on preconception policy for specific groups of women is included in reports and patient web sites (for example, Diabetes UK [3])  but is not gathered together in one place for all women.

 

This is in contrast to the USA, where national guidance has been published by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention  / The Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry Preconception Care Work Group [4] [5].

 

Health professionals should emphasise that in each and every pregnancy, including women who have already had a baby:

  • healthy lifestyles have a role for both potential parents to enhance the chances of conceiving a healthy child

 

  • risk assessment through screening (either by question or by technology) ensures that potential problems are spotted well in advance of the pregnancy and minimised

 

A large proportion of pregnancies are unplanned but not necessarily unwanted. In 1990, one third of pregnancies in four London health districts were unplanned [6] compared to 42% in the 2004 Millennium cohort study [7]. This suggests that preconception care should take place:

 

  • opportunistically in primary care whenever a girl or a woman of child bearing age not using a reliable method of contraception attends [8]

 

  • systematically in more formal settings for women actively planning a pregnancy and for those at high risk of complications – for example, women with diabetes

 

It is essential that any couple being referred for infertility assessment or assisted conception should have a complete preconception assessment and any investigations or treatment completed before any infertility treatment starts.

 

We need to increase professional [4] and public awareness of the importance of preconception health behaviour and of individual’s use of preconception care services using information and tools appropriate for varying ages, literacy levels, health literacy levels, and cultural and linguistic contexts. Women need to know that health conditions and medications can affect pregnancy outcomes and that pregnancy can affect a woman's health.

 

Opportunistic preconception care


Women should begin to be informed about preconception options from an early age. Initial screening comes in the form of questions:

 

For all women:

Are you immune to rubella?


About 40 infants with congenital rubella syndrome have been reported in the UK since 1991; about a third of their mothers were infected abroad, most in their country of origin (imported infections), a third of mothers were born abroad but acquired infection in the UK, and a third were UK-born [9]. Women are routinely offered screening for rubella during pregnancy, but this cannot provide protection for that pregnancy, and pregnancy is a contraindication to vaccination, but can highlight the need for post partum immunisation.

 

As rates of MMR vaccination in childhood have declined and there are more births to women born outside the UK (21.9% of all births in England and Wales in 2006 [10] who may not have been offered rubella immunisation as part of a national programme, women without proof of vaccination should be offered it before pregnancy wherever possible. 

 

Are you a carrier of a haemoglobinopathy?


One standard set by the NHS Sickle Cell and Thalassaemia Screening Programme in 2006 [11] is to ensure that screening tests for these diseases, including carrier status, are offered by 8-10 weeks of pregnancy. Ideally, preconception discussion, identification and testing, especially with women whose family origin suggests that they may have a high risk genetic background, offers women more reproductive choices and less anxiety in pregnancy. Preconception screening and genetic counselling have been successfully implemented in other countries, and this experience can provide a good model for the United Kingdom to learn from [11a].

 

Are you taking folic acid?


In the absence of fortification of flour in the UK, all women should take 400 micrograms of folic acid each day for at least 12 weeks before trying to get pregnant and for at least the first 12 weeks of pregnancy to reduce the risk of neural tube defects (NTDs) (and possibly orofacial) clefts by two thirds [12] [13] [14].

 

A higher dose of folic acid (usually 4.0 to 5.0 milligrams) is recommended for women at risk of folate deficiency [15] such as those:

 

  • being treated with anticonvulsant medicines

 

  • on kidney dialysis

 

  • with conditions such as liver disease, malabsorption (difficulty absorbing vitamins and minerals) or certain types of anaemia

 

All women planning a pregnancy should also aim to increase their dietary consumption of folic acid by eating green vegetables and fortified cereals.

 

Both women with diabetes and those on antiepileptic drugs may wish to take a high (4.0 - 5.0 milligrams) dose of folic acid, although there is no evidence that an increased dose prevents NTDs, except for women who have had a previous pregnancy with an NTD [15a]

 

Important questions not specific to pregnancy but having a large effect on healthy outcome

Do you or your partner smoke?


If yes, offer smoking cessation counselling. Smoking is associated with preterm birth, low birth weight, and other negative perinatal outcomes. Smoking around a baby increases the risk of sudden infant death.

 

Do you drink alcohol?


Whilst there is debate about a ‘safe’ level of drinking in pregnancy, current Government guidance is not to drink in pregnancy or when trying to conceive [16]. Health professionals can stress the risks of alcohol use (especially ‘binge’ drinking) during periods when pregnancy can occur which can change behaviour [17] [18]. 

 

Do you eat a healthy diet? Are you overweight?


Being well-nourished is important during and after a pregnancy, for both the mother’s health and for the development of the fetus/baby [18a]. A healthy weight prior to pregnancy reduces the risks for neural tube defects, preterm delivery, diabetes, Caesarean delivery, hypertension, and thromboembolic disease.

 

Past personal health - Does this woman have any chronic illnesses that require treatment or medication? Does this woman need specialist review and advice before pregnancy?


It is important that any woman with a past or chronic illness is reminded opportunistically that in some conditions, planning a pregnancy can minimise the effects of the illness.

 

It is important that information is sought in a non judgemental way – if a health professional appears antagonistic to a woman with a physical or mental health problem contemplating a pregnancy, some women will delay reporting the pregnancy and accessing antenatal care for fear that the clinician will want them to terminate the pregnancy or to put the baby into care.

 

Examples include:

  • Women with diabetes - improved control of diabetes and taking periconceptional folic acid can reduce the risk for birth defects 3-fold. The risk for major abnormalities was lower among women receiving preconception care than non-recipients (relative risk 0.36, 95% confidence interval 0.22 to 0.59) [19]. The rate of anomalies was 2.1% versus 6.5%. Separate preconception clinics (provided in 17% of units) are most likely to provide the dedicated time and expertise to meet the needs of these women [20] [21].

 

  • Clinicians should attempt to minimize the teratogenic potential of oral antiepileptic medications for women with epilepsy and ensure that these women take periconceptional folic acid to reduce the risks of NTDs

 

  • Both women with diabetes and those on antiepileptic drugs may wish to take a high (400mg) dose of folic acid, although there is no evidence that an increased dose prevents NTDs  except for women who have had a previous pregnancy with an NTD

 

  • All women with congenital or acquired heart disease should discuss future pregnancies with a consultant cardiologist or physician with an interest and expertise in the care of adult congenital heart disease in pregnancy. Pregnancy care should be provided in close conjunction with a consultant obstetrician, preferably at a joint clinic [1]

 

  • Women on oral anticoagulants should consider changing to injectable preparations because of the risk of teratogenicity and bleeding in pregnancy

 

  • The requirement for thyroid replacement therapy for women with hypothyroidism increases during pregnancy, and early intervention promotes healthy neurological development in children

 

  • Women with acne being treated with isotretinoin should stop treatment before becoming pregnant because of teratogenicity

 

  • Women who have phenylketonuria should be on a phenylalanine reduced diet before and during pregnancy to stop the disease damaging their own baby’s brain development

 

  • Women with mental health problems benefit from a review of their care and increased support during and after pregnancy [22], so health professionals should ask questions about past or present severe mental illness (including schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, psychosis in the postnatal period and severe depression), previous treatment by a psychiatrist/specialist mental health team (including inpatient care) and a family history of perinatal mental illness.

 

Planned preconception care


In addition to the questions above, women actively planning a pregnancy should be asked about:-

Current personal health and immunity


Women need to minimise the risk of acquiring any infection during pregnancy. If they are at risk of sexually transmitted or blood borne infections such as chlamydia, syphilis, hepatitis B and HIV they should be offered testing and treatment before pregnancy. Women at risk of hepatitis B can be offered immunisation before pregnancy.

 

Health professionals also have the opportunity to offer advice on avoiding infections during pregnancy, for example by better food hygiene [23] to avoid food poisoning, avoiding foods like raw eggs to minimise the risk of a salmonella infection, and washing hands after gardening and not cleaning cat litter trays to avoid toxoplasmosis.

 

Dental health - when did you last visit the dentist?


There is some evidence that having healthy teeth and gums help women to have healthy babies. Maternal periodontal disease is associated with preterm birth, development of preeclampsia and small for dates babies [24].

 

Family health - are there any inherited illnesses in your family or in the family of the intended father of your baby?


Many women know little about the health of their partner’s family. A preconception visit can encourage them to ask their partner and his mother and their own family about any diseases which have affected other family members, allowing time to consult with a geneticist if indicated.

 

Life style - what work do you do? Are you exposed to any chemicals? What environment do you live in? What do you do when you are not working? What hobbies do you have? Do you take recreational drugs?

 

Toxins that can affect pregnancy that are common in industries where women traditionally work. These include heavy metals such as lead and cadmium, organic solvents, pesticides and herbicides, sterilising agents, anaesthetic gases and anti cancer drugs used in health care. Questions about life styles can allow choice about changing behaviour, using protective strategies or a move to another part of a factory [25]

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Predictive genetic testing for breast and prostate cancer
document.publisher: Canadian Coordinating Office for Health Technology Assessment
document.topics: <![CDATA[ NOT ROUTINELY OFFERED,BENEFITS & HARMS,PROSTATE,BREAST CANCER,CANCER,ADULT,SCREENING,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,PROSTATE CANCER,PROSTATE DISORDERS]]>
document.body:
The Canadian Coordinating Office for Health Technology Assessment (CCOHTA) Technology Reports are critical appraisals or systematic reviews of the literature to provide a clear picture of the clinical effectiveness, cost-effectiveness and impact of health technologies in Canada.

This report** is a qualitative review that describes the current molecular basis of breast and prostate cancer and explores the ethical, psycho-social, and policy implications associated with genetic testing. One of the report's conclusions stated that "key ethical implications arising from genetic testing for hereditary breast and prostate cancer include informed consent, privacy and confidentiality, and familial implications. Predictive genetic testing for breast and prostate cancer has brought forth social issues such as the potential creation of a genetic subclass".

**Note that this report is >5 years old

]]>

document.body:
NHS Quality Improvement Scotland exists to improve the quality of healthcare in Scotland, by setting standards, monitoring performance and providing support to NHSScotland on effective clinical practice and service improvements.

This document introduces the NHS Quality Improvement Scotland clinical standards for pregnancy and newborn screening. It comprises five standards:

  1. service provision and monitoring
  2. pregnancy screening: Down's syndrome and neural tube defects
  3. pregnancy screening: communicable diseases
  4. newborn: bloodspot screening
  5. newborn: hearing screening

The standards can be found in section five.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Prenatal Ultrasound as a Screening Test
document.body:
Institute for Clinical Systems Improvement (ICSI) Technology Assessment Reports are designed to provide a scientific assessment, through review and analysis of medical literature, of the safety and efficacy of medical technologies.

This report looks at the use of prenatal ultrasound as a screening test. The Technology Assessment Committee summarised by stating that: "although routine ultrasound measurements are safe procedures, there are risks associated with false negative and false positive test results. Routine ultrasound in early pregnancy (before 24 weeks gestation) has not been shown to reduce perinatal mortality. Routine ultrasound in late pregnancy (after 24 weeks gestation) has not been shown to reduce perinatal mortality or morbidity".

]]>

document.publisher: Canadian Task Force on Preventive Health Care
document.body:
This report, published by the Candian Task Force on Preventive Health Care, systematically reviews the evidence relating to three different group B streptococcus screening strategies: universal screening of pregnant women and selective intrapartum chemoprophylaxis of colonised women with risk factors, universal screening of pregnant women and intrapartum chemoprophylaxis of all colonised women, and intrapartum chemoprophylaxis based on risk factors only.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Promoting informed decisions about cancer screening in communities and healthcare systems
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SCREENING,CANCER,ADULT,COLORECTAL (BOWEL) CANCER,PROSTATE,BREAST CANCER,INFORMED DECISION-MAKING,NOT ROUTINELY OFFERED]]>
document.body:
Promoting informed decisions about cancer screening in communities and healthcare systems.  Briss P, Rimer B, Reilley B et al. Am J Prev Med 2004 Jan;26(1):67-80.

Note: This reference is indexed in Medline, and has been established as a systematic review using specific criteria. It does not yet appear in any pre-appraised source and so the quality of the research has not been assessed.

"Objective: This review specifically asked whether informed decision making (IDM) interventions (1) promote understanding of cancer screening, (2) facilitate participation in decision making about cancer screening at a level that is comfortable for individuals; or (3) encourage individuals to make cancer-screening decisions that are consistent with their preferences and values.

Conclusion: The interventions were generally consistent in improving individuals' knowledge about the disease, accuracy of risk perceptions, or knowledge and beliefs about the pros and cons of screening and treatment options. However, few studies evaluated whether these interventions resulted in individuals participating in decision making at a desirable level, or whether they led to decisions that were consistent with individuals' values and preferences".

]]>

document.body:

Note: This reference is indexed in Medline, and has been established as a systematic review using specific criteria. It does not yet appear in any pre-appraised source and so the quality of the research has not been assessed

Objective: to determine accuracy and rapidity of group B Streptococcus (GBS) colonization tests
