document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Recommendations for the selective use of herpes simplex virus type 2 serological tests
document.body:
Recommendations for the selective use of herpes simplex virus type 2 serological tests. Guerry S et al. Clinical Infectious Diseases 2005;40:38-45.

Note: This reference is indexed in Medline, and has been established as a systematic review using specific criteria. It does not yet appear in any pre-appraised source and so the quality of the research has not been assessed.

This article is available in free full text.

Objective: to find evidence that supports screening in selected high-risk groups, by means of a systematic review of the literature on screening for herpes simplex virus.

Conclusions: the review concluded that screening is likely to be beneficial among those at high risk for sexually transmitted infections (STDs) and  HIV infection, HIV-infected patients, and patients with sex partners with genital herpes. In contrast, universal screening for HSV-2 infection in pregnant women is unlikely to be beneficial. 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Reconsidering reproductive benefit through newborn screening: a systematic review of guidelines on preconception, prenatal and newborn screening
document.body:
Authors' conclusions: Prenatal and preconception guidance identifies a coherent framework to support the pursuit of reproductive benefits through population screening programmes.

 

Method: Review of 53 unique guidelines addressing prenatal, preconception and newborn screening to examine how generating reproductive risk information is construed as a benefit of screening and what conditions support the realization of this benefit.

 

Results: Most preconception and prenatal guidelines, where reproductive risk information was described as a primary benefit, required individuals be given choices to ensure the decision-making process was well-informaed. Except for 3 guidelines, newborn screening policy infrequently attended to the potential for reproductive benefits.

 

Citation: Bombard Y, Miller FA, Hayeems RZ et al. Reconsidering reproductive benefit through newborn screening: a systematic review of guidelines on preconception, prenatal and newborn screening. European Journal of Human Genetics 2010; 18(7):751-60

 

Access: Subscription or payment required

]]>

document.title: Reduction in uptake of PSA tests following decision aids: systematic review of current aids and their evaluations
document.body:
Reduction in uptake of PSA tests following decision aids: systematic review of current aids and their evaluations. Evans R, Edwards A, Brett J et. al. Patient Educ Couns. 2005 Jul;58(1):13-26.

Note: This reference is indexed in Medline, and has been established as a systematic review using specific criteria. It does not yet appear in any pre-appraised source and so the quality of the research has not been assessed.

Objective: to identify and appraise prostate specific antigen (PSA) decision aids and evaluations

Conclusions: PSA decision aids improve knowledge about PSA testing, at least in the short term. Men given these decision aids seem to be less likely to have the PSA test.

document.title: Review of screening for prostate cancer
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SCREENING,ADULT,CANCER,PROSTATE,NOT ROUTINELY OFFERED,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,PROSTATE DISORDERS,PROSTATE CANCER,MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS]]>
document.description: BJU supplement outlining the estimates of ad-hoc screening for prostate cancer, informed decision making and PSA testing
document.body:
111-1Review of screening for prostate cancer

This review of prostate cancer screening was prepared for the Prostate Cancer Risk Management Programme Scientific Research Group, and has been published as a British Journal of Urology (BJU) supplement: BJU volume 95, supplement 3, April 2005.

It contains an editorial and introduction to prostate cancer screening, and information about:

  • the burden and natural history of prostate cancer
  • outcomes of screening
  • estimates of ad-hoc screening in England and Wales
  • patient information and informed decision-making
  • psychosocial impact of PSA testing

document.title: Screening adults for bladder cancer: a review of the evidence for the US preventive services task force
document.publisher: Annals of Internal Medicine, American College of Physicians
document.body:
Authors' conclusions: High quality evidence on whether screening adults for bladder cancer was not available and so further research is needed as to whether screening leads to better outcomes compared with no screening.

 

Method: Medline, Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials and CancerLit section of PubMed were searched for studies in English. Inclusion criteris were randomized trials and controlled observational studies directly evaluating screening adults for bladder cancer compared with no screening or treatment of screen-detected bladder cancer with no treatment.

 

Results: No randomized trials or high quality controlled observational studies evaluated clinical outcomes associated with screening compared with no screening or treatment of screen-detected bladder cancer compared with no treatment. No study evaluated the sensitivity or specificity of tests used to screen and no study evaluated the harms associated with treatment of screen-detected bladder cancer compared with no treatment.

 

Citation: Chou R and Dana T. Screening adults for bladder cancer: a review of the evidence for the US preventive services task force. Annals of Internal Medicine 2010; 153(7):461-8

 

Access: Full text freely available from the US Preventive Services Task Force website

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Screening and behavioural counselling interventions in primary care to reduce alchol misuse
document.publisher: Agency for Health Care Policy and Research, USA
document.topics: <![CDATA[ MANAGEMENT,PRIMARY CARE,NOT ROUTINELY OFFERED,DETERMINANTS,PRIMARY CARE SERVICES,POPULATION BASED & PREVENTATIVE SERVICES,SCREENING,SCREENING,ALCOHOL PROBLEMS,ADULT,PUBLIC HEALTH,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,INDIVIDUAL BEHAVIOUR,ALCOHOL CONSUMPTION,HEALTHCARE & HEALTH SERVICES,HEALTH SERVICES,SERVICES,MONTHLY ADDITIONS,2008-JULY]]>
document.body:
This is the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommendation on screening and counselling for alcohol misuse. The USPSTF recommends "screening and behavioral counseling interventions to reduce alcohol misuse by adults, including pregnant women, in primary care settings" but conclude that the evidence is insufficient to recommend "for or against screening and behavioral counseling interventions to prevent or reduce alcohol misuse by adolescents in primary care settings".

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Screening and case-finding instruments for depression : a meta-analysis
document.publisher: CMAJ Canadian Medical Association Journal, CMA Publications
document.body:
Authors' conclusions: Case-finding or screening questionnaires for depression do not appear to have any impact on detection and management for depression, if used in isolation.

 

Method: A Cochrane systematic review of randomized controlled trials was performed. A meta-analysis was then performed.

 

Results: 16 trials incorporating 7,567 patients were reviewed. Screening and case-finding was found to modestly increase the recognition of depression by clinicians

 

Citation: Gilbody S, Sheldon T, House A. Screening and case-finding instruments for depression: a meta-analysis. CMAJ Canadian Medical Association Journal 2008;178(8):997-1003

 

Access: Full text PDF is freely available

 

This meta-analysis has not been critically reviewed.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Screening and intervention for domestic violence during pregnancy care: a systematic review
document.body:
Authors' conclusions: Screening for the identification of domestic violence during pregnancy was significantly more likely than nonstandardized, or no, screening. Recurrent screening improved rates. There was limited evidence that interventions reduced violence and further research is needed to establish those that are most effective.

 

Method: The Cochrane Library, Medline, Embase  and PsycINFO were searched between January 1995 and November 2009

 

Results: Nine studies (five on screening, four on interventions) met the inclusion criteria of being in English and using either national or international comparative methodology.

 

Citation: O'Reilly R, Beale B, Gillies D. Screening and intervention for domestic violence during pregnancy care: a systematic review. Trauma Violence & Abuse 2010; 11(4):190-201

 

Access: Abstract available

]]>

document.body:

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Screening for Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm. A Best evidence systematic review for the US PReventive Services Task Force
document.publisher: Annals of Internal Medicine, American College of Physicians
document.body:
Authors' conclusions: 'For men aged 65-75 years, an invitation to attend AAA screening reduces AAA-related mortality.'

 

Method: Medline and the Cochrane Library were searched between 1994 and 2004. This was supplemented by reference lists from retrieved articles and suggestions from experts. Studies were reviewed and rated against predefined criteria.

 

Results: Four population RCTs of AAA screening in men aged 65 years and older met the criteria and were included.

 

Citation: Fleming C, Whitlock EP, Beil TL,  et al.  Screening for Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm. A Best evidence Systematic Review for the US Preventive Services Task Force.  Annals of Internal Medicine 2005; 142(3):203-11.

 

Access: Full text also available via the US Preventive Services Task Force website

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Screening for alcohol abuse and dependence in older people using DSM criteria: a review
document.description: Systematic review published in Aging and Mental Health
document.body:
Aging and Mental Health. Jan 2004; 8(1): 76-82.

 

Note: This reference is indexed in Medline, and has been established as a systematic review using specific criteria. It does not yet appear in any pre-appraised source and so the quality of the research has not been assessed.

 

OBJECTIVE: to review the quality of screening instruments for alcohol abuse and dependance used in older people in a clinical setting

 

CONCLUSION: the geriatric version of the Michigan Alcohol Screening Test(MAST-G) and the CAGE (Cut-down, Annoyed, Guilty and Eye-opener) are the only instruments appropriate for alcohol screening in elderly people in a clinical setting

This is the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommendation on screening for cervical cancer. The USPSTF "strongly recommends screening for cervical cancer in women who have been sexually active and have a cervix" but "recommends against routinely screening women older than age 65 for cervical cancer if they have had adequate recent screening with normal Pap smears and are not otherwise at high risk for cervical cancer".

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Screening for Cervical Cancer: Recent Advances
document.body:
The Health Technology Advisory Committee in Minnesota, USA provides unbiased, scientifically based assessments and recommendations on new and emerging technologies. Note that this committee was discontinued in July 2002 due to budget cuts, so the publications will not be updated subsequently.

This report concludes that "one reason why Pap smear may have reached its optimal efficacy is the inherent limited sensitivity of the test... many studies have addressed impediments to cervical cancer screening and report that the most common impediments are: a lack of appreciation of the need for screening; the primary care provider does not suggest performing a Pap smear; and a belief that older patients did not require screening. These impediments to recommended screening make it imperative that the screening test used when recruiting unscreened or infrequently screened women has the highest sensitivity. Liquid-based cytology has the potential to increase the effectiveness of these programs by reducing the risk of missed disease in infrequently screened women".

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Screening for chlamydia
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SCREENING,ADULT,WOMEN'S HEALTH,SEXUAL HEALTH,CHLAMYDIA,CHLAMYDIA,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,MALE SEXUALLY TRANSMITTED INFECTIONS,BACTERIAL,MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,CHLAMYDIA]]>
document.body:
Screening for chlamydia

See the review in Bandolier**

Bandolier write:

"Screening is a complex issue, even when, as here, it appears to produce overall healthcare savings of $50 per woman screened. Muir Gray's book [6] is instructive when considering screening, as well as being a good read generally. In any complex organisation, and especially for screening programmes, performance is the key, and it depends on a number of factors:
Performance = ((Motivation x Competence)/Barriers)

A good strategy is to assume people are well motivated, to ensure that they have the necessary skills and to knock down the barriers which can hinder performance. Those barriers include inaccessible information, information overload, information irrelevance and insufficient time".

References:

  1. MR Howell, TC Quinn, CA Gaydos. Screening for Chlamydia trachomatis in asymptomatic women attending family planning clinics. Annals of Internal Medicine 1998 128:277-84.
  2. AC Haddix, SD Hillia, WJ Kassler. The cost effectiveness of azithromycin for Chlamydia trachomatis infections in women. Sexually Transmitted Diseases 1995 22:274-80.
  3. AP Lea, HM Lamb. Azithromycin. A pharmacoeconomic review of its use as a single-dose regimen in the treatment of uncomplicated urogenital Chlamydia trachomatis infections in women. Pharmacoeconomics 1997 12:596-611.
  4. T Stokes. Screening for Chlamydia in general practice: a literature review and summary of the evidence. Journal of Public Health Medicine 1997 19:222-32.
  5. D Scholes, A Stergachis, F Heidrich et al. Prevention of pelvic inflammatory disease by screening for cervical Chlamydial infection. New England Journal of Medicine 1996 334:1362-6.
  6. JA Muir Gray. Evidence-based Healthcare - how to make health policy and management decisions. Churchill Livingstone 1997. ISBN 0-443-05721-4

** Note that this review is > 10 years old

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Screening for chronic kidney disease: an evidence based review for the National Screening Committee
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SCREENING,ADULT,NOT ROUTINELY OFFERED,CHRONIC KIDNEY DISEASE,SCREENING OPTIONS,SCREENING TESTS,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,KIDNEY DISEASES,KIDNEY DISEASE]]>
document.description: A systematic review to assess the evidence for a screening programme for Chronic Kidney Disease
document.body:
This systematic review will assess the evidence for a screening programme for Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) for the UK adult population using the NSC criteria. The purpose is to determine firstly whether a screening programme would be effective, feasible and cost-effective. Secondly, if it is, whether this programme should involve screening the population or should be restricted to high-risk groups. A secondary aim is to identify the gaps in the literature, which could form the basis for future research proposals.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Screening for depression in adults in primary care settings: a systematic review
document.publisher: Annals of Internal Medicine, American College of Physicians
document.body:
Authors' conclusions: Screening for depression is unlikely to improve outcomes unless substantial care support is provided.

 

Method: Medline, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, DARE, PsycINFO were serched from 1998-2007. Suggestions from experts and bibliographies of recent reviews were also searched.

 

Results: 33 articles were were abstracted, critically appraised and their data extracted by two investigators. Fair and good quality RCTs, controlled clinical trials, systematic reviews, meta-analases and large observational studies on the benefits and harms of screening adults for depression, the benefits of treating depression in older adults plus the harms of antidepressant medications were evaluated.

 

Citation: O'Connor EA, Whitlock EP, Beil TL, et al. Screening for depression in adult patients in primary care settings: a systematic review of the evidence. Annals of Internal Medicine 2009; 151(11):793-803

 

Access: Full text available with NHS Athens account

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Screening for depression in medical settings with the Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ) : a diagnostic meta-analysis
document.publisher: Journal of General Internal Medicine, Springer
document.body:
Authors' conclusions: Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ) 9 is acceptable as a screening instrument for depression, while further research is needed to validate PHQ2.

 

Method: Systematic search of Medline, PscLIT, Embase, Cinahl, Cochrane registers and study reference list. Heterogeneity was explored with metaregression.

 

Results: 17 validation studies were included. 14 (incorporating 5,026 participant) validated PHQ9 and three validated PHQ2.

 

Citation: Gilbody S, Richards D, Brealey S, Hewitt C. Screening for depression in medical settings with the Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ): a diagnostic meta-analysis. Journal of General Internal Medicine 2007;22(11):1596-602

 

Access: Full text available with NHS Athens login.

 

This meta-analysis has not been critically appraised.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Screening for Down's syndrome (Annual Evidence Update 2009)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SCREENING,ANTENATAL,DOWN'S SYNDROME (NUCHAL TRANSLUCENCY),ULTRASOUND,11-14 WEEKS,BEFORE 16 WEEKS,14-20 WEEKS,DOWN'S SYNDROME (SERUM)]]>
document.body:
111-1Screening for Down's syndrome (Annual Evidence Update 2009)

 

 

 

Back to contents page 

 

Screening for Down's syndrome evidence update

 

This section has been updated by Fiona McInnes, National Projects Officer, NHS Fetal Anomaly Screening Programme

 

Each human cell is made up of 46 chromosomes (23 pairs).  In Down's syndrome there are 3 copies of  chromosome 21, totalling 47 chromosomes  in all.. This explains why Down's Syndrome is also called Trisomy 21.

 

Down's Syndrome occurs in approximately 1: 800 births [1]. This figure is similar in all populations and is an overall population risk. The incidence rises with the mother's age.

 

Down’s syndrome screening

Down’s syndrome screening is offered in England to all pregnant women and is part of a Government initiative to provide equity and access in the NHS - the primary aim is to allow parents to make informed choices concerning their pregnancy outcome.

 

The policy for this was initiated in 2003 following the publication of the Model of Best Practice [1a] (updated 2008) from the Department of Health, and underpinned by the NICE clinical guideline on routine antenatal care in 2003 [2] (updated 2008), the Genetics White Paper in 2003 [3] and the National Service Framework for children (NSF) in 2004 [4].

 

The national Programme Centre on behalf of the UK National Screening Committee has the remit to set standards which are auditable and benchmarked. The Programme also manages the national implementation of the policy, working in close collaboration with the 9 regional teams (10 SHA’s).

 

The Programme objectives are:

  • To offer screening to all pregnant women at the appropriate gestational age

  •  To ensure that all pregnant women receive written information offered in a format they can access and understand before they enter the screening Programme 

  • To maximise the detection rate  and minimise the false positive rate of the test, and ensure that these rates conform to national standards 

  • To minimise harm associated with the screening Programme 

  • To ensure that all results are made available to all screened women on a timescale conforming to national standards 

  • To ensure that women who screen positive/high risk are given appropriate information and support to make the decision whether or not to have a diagnostic test, and that appropriate services are made available without delay 

  • To minimise harm and anxiety following a diagnosis of a Down’s syndrome fetus and manage the pregnancy according to the wishes of the parents 

  • To ensure that all relevant health professionals involved in the screening Programme have attained the necessary level of knowledge and skill 

  • To provide regular feedback of the effectiveness and quality of the service of the population screened to clinicians, managers and those who commission services 

  •  To improve all aspects of the Programme by a process of continuous quality assurance 

The Model of Best Practice (2008) recommends the following Programme Outcomes and benchmark timeframes:

 

  • A detection rate (DR) for Down’s syndrome of greater than 75% of affected pregnancies with a screen positive rate (SPR) of less than 3%. (Benchmark time frame: April 2007 to April 2010)
  • A detection rate (DR) of greater than 90% of affected pregnancies with a screen positive rate (SPR) of less than 2%. (Benchmark time frame: by April 2010)

There are various screening strategies that will meet the 2010 target such as the combined screening test, using nuchal translucency (NT) and biochemistry (undertaken before 14 weeks), and integrated testing (a two stage test, undertaken between 10 and 20 weeks of pregnancy).

 

An annual evidence update 2007/8 on screening for Down's Syndrome has been reviewed and there are a small number of references on markers deemed useful for consideration.

 

Markers

 

A study conducted in Asia on over 3000 second trimester fetuses found that nasal bone length (NBL), a potential soft marker for Down's Syndrome, appears to be shorter in Korean fetuses than Caucasian and Chinese fetuses [7]. This indicates that the NBL has a bias towards different ethnic populations.
 

It seems that the use of fetal cells in maternal blood (free fetal DNA) is not yet a reliable marker for Down's syndrome, as demonstrated by a study to quantify fetal DNA levels in trisomy 21 [8]

 

A brief synopsis of the value of ADAM12 by measuring levels in pregnancies prior to 10 weeks gestation is given in this study (10 pregnancies with T21 against a series of 62 gestational age matched samples as ‘controls’), and concludes that combining the data from this study and from the only other published study with data prior to 10 weeks suggests that ADAM12s may have the potential as an early screening marker for trisomy 21 (9) Spencer K

 

 

References 

 

[1] Cuckle H., Wald NJ, Thompson SG. Estimating a woman's risk of having a pregnancy associated with Down's syndrome using her age and serum alphfetoprotein level. British Journal of Obstetrics and Gynaecology 1987; 94:387-402. [PubMed abstract]

 

[1a] Department of Health and UK National Screening Committee. NHS Fetal Anomaly Screening Programme - Screening for Down's Syndrome: UK NSC Policy Recommendations 2007-2010: Model of best practice.  2008

 

[2] National Institute of Clinical Excellence (NICE) (October 2003). Antenatal Care: routine care for the pregnant woman. [This guidance was updated in 2008 - see reference below]

 

[3] Department of Health. Genetics White Paper,  Our Inheritance Our Future, Realising the potential of genetics in the NHS. 2003.

 

[4] Department of Health. National Service Framework for children, young people and maternity services. 2004.

 

[6] Laigaard J, Cuckle H, Wewer UM, Christiansen M. Maternal serum ADAM12 levels in Down and Edwards' syndrome pregnancies at 9-12 weeks' gestation. Prenatal Diagnosis 2006, 26(8):689-91 [PubMed abstract]

 

[7] Jung E, Won HS, Lee PR, Kim A. Ultrasonographic measurement of fetal nasal bone length in the second trimester in Korean population. Prenatal Diagnosis 2007, 27(2):154-7 [PubMed abstract

 

[8] Gerovassili A, Garner C, Nicolaides KH, Thein SL, Rees DC. Free fetal DNA in maternal circulation: a potential prognostic marker for chromosomal abnormalities? Prenatal Diagnosis 2007, 27(2):104-10 [PubMed abstract]

  

 

 

Further information

2009 Annual evidence update: antenatal screening for Down's syndrome

 

UK NSC policy on screening for Down's syndrome during pregnancy

 

NHS Fetal Anomaly Screening Programme website

 

NHS Fetal Anomaly Screening Programme Annual Report 2006-2008

 

 

Further information for professionals

NHS Fetal Anomaly Screening Programme. Chorionic villus sampling (CVS) and amniocentesis - for health professionals. 2009

 

National Collaborating Centre for Women’s and Children’s Health. Commissioned by the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence. Antenatal care: routine care for the healthy pregnant woman. CG62: full guidance. March 2008 (corrected June 2008). 

 

Continuous professional development - resources to support the Antenatal and Newborn Screening Programmes

 

NHS Fetal Anomlay Screening Programme. Antenatal screening - working standards for Down's syndrome screening. 2007

National Down’s Syndrome Screening Programme for England. A hanbook for staff. 2004.

 

Wald N J, Rodeck C, Hackshaw A K, Walters J, Chitty L, Mackinson A M. First and second trimester antenatal screening for Down's syndrome: the results of the Serum, Urine and Ultrasound Screening Study (SURUSS). No.11, 2003: 88

 

The NHS Fetal Anomaly Screening Programme has produced a number of pathways which will illustrate the screening process for fetal anomaly and Down's syndrome screening and also the governance responsibilities for health professionals.

NHS Fetal Anomaly Screening Programme Pathways

 

 

Patient information

The Elfrida Society. Testing for Down's syndrome during pregnancy: an easy read book. 2009

 

NHS Fetal Anomaly Screening Programme. Amniocentesis test - information for parents. 2009.

 

NHS Fetal Anomaly Screening Programme. Information for women on non invasive prenatal diagnosis (NIPD) and cell fre-fetal DNA (cffDNA). 2009

 

Antenatal and Newborn Screening Programmes. Testing for Down's syndrome during pregnancy. 2009

 

NHS Fetal Anomaly Screening Programme. Chorionic villus sampling (CVS) - information for parents. 2009

 

Lab tests online - searchable website designed to help consumers understand the many clinical lab tests that are part of routine care. See pregnancy screening (2008).

 

Antenatal and Newborn Screening Programmes. Screening tests for you and your baby. 2007

 

NHS Fetal Anomaly Screening Programme. Having a mid-pregnancy ultrasound scan. 2007


 

]]>

document.body:
111-1Screening for Down's Syndrome (National Knowledge Week)

        

         See bigger image of diagram (pg 19)

 

Back to Contents page                                         

Annual Evidence Update

                                              

This section has been written by Pat Ward, Programme Director, NHS Fetal Anomaly Screening Programme

 

Each human cell is made up of 46 chromosomes (23 pairs).  In Down's syndrome there is an extra chromosome making 47 in all, and this extra chromosome is the number 21. This gives three number 21 chromosomes and hence explains why Down's Syndrome is also called Trisomy 21.

 

Down's Syndrome occurs in approximately 1: 800 births [1]. This figure is similar in all populations and is an overall population risk. The incidence rises sharply with the mother's age.

 

Down’s syndrome screening

Down’s syndrome screening  is offered in England to all pregnant women and is part of the governments'  initiatives to provide equity and access in the NHS -  the primary aim being to allow parents to make informed choices concerning their pregnancy outcome.

 

The policy for this was initiated in 2003 following the publication of the Model of Best Practice [1a] from the Department of Health, and underpinned by the NICE clinical guideline on routine antenatal care in 2003 [2], the Genetics White Paper in 2003 [3] and the National Service Framework for children (NSF) in 2004 [4].


The remit to implement this fully in England, and ensure that it adhered to set standards which could be auditable and benchmarked, was given to the UK National Screening Committee (NSC) who then set up a Programme Centre to take forward the various work streams.

 

The Programme objectives are:

 

  • To offer screening to all pregnant women at the appropriate gestational age

 

  • To ensure that all pregnant women receive written information, supplemented as appropriate, before they enter the screening programme 

 

  • To maximise the detection rate  and minimise the false positive rate of the test, and ensure that these rates conform to National Standards 

 

  • To minimise harm associated with the screening programme 

 

  • To ensure that all results are made available to all screened women on a timescale conforming to National Standards 

 

  • To ensure that women who screen positive/high risk are given appropriate information and support to make the decision whether or not to have a diagnostic test, and that appropriate services are made available without delay 

 

  • To minimise harm and anxiety following a diagnosis of a Down’s syndrome fetus and manage the pregnancy according to the wishes of the parents 

 

  • To ensure that all relevant health professionals involved in the screening programme have attained the necessary level of knowledge and skill 

 

  • To provide regular feedback of the effectiveness and quality of the service of the population screened to clinicians, managers and those who commission services 

 

  • To improve all aspects of the programme by a process of continuous quality assurance 

The present policy sets out that all women must be offered a screening test which meets a standard of a greater than 75% detection rate for a less than 3% false positive rate. This should have been achieved by April 2007.


There are various screening strategies that will meet this target such as the combined screening test, using Nuchal Translucency (NT) and biochemistry (undertaken before 14 weeks), and integrated testing (a two stage test, undertaken between 10 and 20 weeks of pregnancy).

 

An annual evidence update on screening for Down's Syndrome has been reviewed and there are a small number of references on markers deemed useful for consideration.

Markers

One study aimed to evaluate whether there was a NT measurement, independent of gestational age, above which immediate diagnostic testing should be offered (without waiting for serum screening results) [5]. They concluded that if a NT measurement of 3.0mm or above is obtained, there is minimal benefit in waiting for serum markers. This concurs with the cut-off of 3.0mm used in the Down's Syndrome Programme NT standards.

 

A brief synopsis of the value of ADAM12 (a new marker) by measuring levels in Down's Syndrome pregnancies at 9-12 weeks gestation is given in this study, but concludes that more data will be needed to predict performance. [6]
 
 
A study conducted in Asia on over 3000 second trimester fetuses found that nasal bone length (NBL), a potential soft marker for Down's Syndrome, appears to be shorter in Korean fetuses than Caucasian and Chinese fetuses [7]. This indicates that the NBL has a bias towards different ethnic populations.
 

It seems that the use of fetal cells in maternal blood (free fetal DNA) is not yet a reliable marker for Down's syndrome, as demonstrated by a study to quantify fetal DNA levels in trisomy 21 [8]

 

References

[1] Cuckle H., Wald NJ, Thompson SG. Estimating a woman's risk of having a pregnancy associated with Down's syndrome using her age and serum alphfetoprotein level. British Journal of Obstetrics and Gynaecology 1987; 94:387-402. [PubMed abstract]

 

[1a] Department of Health. Model of Best Practice for providing Down's Syndrome screening services.  2003

 

[2] National Institute of Clinical Excellence (NICE) (October 2003). Antenatal Care: routine care for the pregnant woman. Full guidance document (304 pages) also available.

 

[3] Department of Health. Genetics White Paper,  Our Inheritance Our Future, Realising the potential of genetics in the NHS. 2003.

 

[4] Department of Health. National Service Framework for children, young people and maternity services. 2004.

 

[5] Comstock CH, Malone FD, Ball RH, Nyberg DA, Saade GR, Berkowitz RL et al. Is there a nuchal translucency millimeter measurement above which there is no added benefit from first trimester serum screening? American Journal of Obstetrics & Gynecology. 2006, 195(3), 843-7. [PubMed abstract]

 

[6] Laigaard J, Cuckle H, Wewer UM, Christiansen M. Maternal serum ADAM12 levels in Down and Edwards' syndrome pregnancies at 9-12 weeks' gestation. Prenatal Diagnosis 2006, 26(8):689-91 [PubMed abstract]

 

[7] Jung E, Won HS, Lee PR, Kim A. Ultrasonographic measurement of fetal nasal bone length in the second trimester in Korean population. Prenatal Diagnosis 2007, 27(2):154-7 [PubMed abstract

 

[8] Gerovassili A, Garner C, Nicolaides KH, Thein SL, Rees DC. Free fetal DNA in maternal circulation: a potential prognostic marker for chromosomal abnormalities? Prenatal Diagnosis 2007, 27(2):104-10 [PubMed abstract]

 
 

Annual evidence update on antenatal screening for Down's Syndrome 2006/07

 

Down's Syndrome

 

 

National Screening Committee policy, July 2006

Down's Syndrome screening

 

 

Recent systematic reviews (selected from above evidence update)

O’Connell R, Stephenson M, Weir R. Screening Strategies for Antenatal Down Syndrome Screening. A systematic review of the literature. New Zealand Health Technology Assessment Report November 2006 Volume 9 Number 4. 

 

Hewison J, Nixon J, Fountain J, Cocks K, Jones C, Mason G et al. Amniocentesis results: investigation of anxiety. The ARIA trial. Health Technology Assessment  2006; Vol 10: number 50

 

 

Other information for health professionals

NICE Guidance currently being reviewed: Antenatal Care: routine care for the healthy pregnant woman (Oct 2003). See review details. Consultation period: 4 September - 29 October 2007.

 

Continuous professional development - resources to support the Antenatal and Newborn Screening Programmes: Down's Syndrome

 

Down's Syndrome Screening Programme (DSSP) website

 

National Down’s Syndrome Screening Programme for England. Antenatal screening – working standards. March 2004.

 

National Down’s Syndrome Screening Programme for England. A hanbook for staff. 2004.

 

National Down’s Syndrome Screening Programme for England. 3rd annual programme report 2005/2006

 

Wald N J, Rodeck C, Hackshaw A K, Walters J, Chitty L, Mackinson A M. First and second trimester antenatal screening for Down's syndrome: the results of the Serum, Urine and Ultrasound Screening Study (SURUSS). No.11, 2003: 88

 

 

Information to give pregnant women

National Screening Committee (Jan 2007). Screening tests for you and your baby - booklet explaining the screening tests offered to pregnant women and their newborn babies.

 

 Lab tests online - searchable website designed to help consumers understand the many clinical lab tests that are part of routine care. See pregnancy screening (Aug 2006) and screening tests for newborns  (July 2007)


 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Screening for elevated lead levels in childhood and pregnancy
document.publisher: Agency for Health Care Policy and Research, USA
document.body:
This is the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommendation on screening for elevated lead levels in children and pregnant women. The USPSTF concluded that "evidence is insufficient to recommend for or against routine screening for elevated blood levels in asymptomatic children aged 1 to 5 who are at increased risk"  and "recommends against routine screening for elevated blood lead levels in asymptomatic children aged 1 to 5 years who are at average risk". In addition the USPSTF "recommends against routine screening for elevated blood lead levels in asymptomatic pregnant women".

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ NOT ROUTINELY OFFERED,DOMESTIC VIOLENCE,NOT ROUTINELY OFFERED,SCREENING,ANTENATAL,ADULT,DOMESTIC VIOLENCE,PUBLIC HEALTH,DETERMINANTS,SOCIAL DETERMINANTS,MONTHLY ADDITIONS,DOMESTIC VIOLENCE,2009 SEPTEMBER,ABUSE]]>
document.body:
This is the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommendation on screening for family and intimate partner violence. The USPSTF found "insufficient evidence to recommend for or against routine screening of parents or guardians for the physical abuse or neglect of children, of women for intimate partner violence, or of older adults or their caregivers for elder abuse". 

 

]]>

document.title: Screening for fetal anomalies (Annual Evidence Update 2009)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SCREENING,ANTENATAL,NEURAL TUBE DEFECTS,FETAL ANOMALY,BEFORE 16 WEEKS,18-20 WEEKS,ULTRASOUND]]>
document.body:
111-1Screening for fetal anomalies (Annual Evidence Update 2009)

 

 

Back to contents page

 

Screening for fetal anomalies evidence update

Screening for neural tube defects evidence update

 

This section has been updated by Donna Kirwan, National Projects Officer NHS Fetal Anomaly Screening Programme, September 2009

 

Introduction


Within the realms of the UK National Screening Committee (NSC), the overseeing body which is responsible for advising Ministers and governing screening programmes across the UK sits the NHS Fetal Anomaly Screening Programme (FASP), which is responsible for developing and promoting a national, quality assured obstetric ultrasound screening programme for England.  Together with its sister programme, the NHS Down’s Syndrome Screening Programme (DoSySP), which began life in 2001, they are now one fraternity with seven other antenatal and newborn screening programmes that reside under the umbrella of the Fetal, Maternal and Child Health (FMCH) division of the UK NSC.


Nowadays, virtually every pregnant woman will undergo some type of prenatal investigation during her pregnancy to understand more about her health and the baby she carries.  Antenatal screening is nothing new, except that there are now more tests available to offer.

Ultrasound scanning in the second trimester of pregnancy to detect structural abnormalities has been undertaken in the UK since the 1980s and as ultrasound machines have improved so have the expectations about what might be diagnosed.  Obstetric ultrasound is a ‘seasoned’ phenomenon, in that it is used world-wide clinically and associated with a large literature base in both the medical and public domains (ultrasound itself and the clinical application and psycho-social experiences of those either undergoing or providing the technology). 


The development of ultrasound as a screening test has been largely technology driven however the evidence base for its effectiveness is generally considered to be of poor quality.  Much of the evidence about the ability of ultrasound to diagnose specific conditions has come from small studies undertaken by ultrasound experts but in more recent years population studies evaluating ultrasound as a screening, as opposed to a diagnostic tool, have been less encouraging.

 

Evolution of the NHS Fetal Anomaly Screening Programme


In 2004, the Department of Health (DH) funded an NHS Fetal Anomaly Screening Programme (FASP) to oversee the implementation of standards to an agreed level of quality in order to provide flexible and responsive antenatal screening services to meet the needs of pregnant women having ultrasound and biochemistry, as evidence showed “some serious gaps and deficiencies” in the way services operated.1  


Under the auspices of Sir Muir Gray, Programmes Director of the UK National Screening Committee (UKNSC), Pat Ward, National FASP director, Professor Martin Whittle (Chair of the Ante Natal Sub Group of the UKNSC Steering Group) and expert stakeholders, a strategy was devised to develop standards and pathways for obstetric ultrasound.  As ultrasound invariably is capable of complementing chromosomal diagnosis of conditions such as Down’s syndrome, FASP and DoSySP were amalgamated. 

Aims of the 18+0 to 20+6 weeks fetal anomaly ultrasound scan
The purpose of the scan is to:

  1. Identify:
        a. Lethal abnormalities
        b. Abnormalities amenable to immediate neonatal treatment.
        c. Abnormalities for which there may be intrauterine treatment.
  2. Offer a choice about whether or not to continue with a pregnancy in which the baby is abnormal.
  3. Plan appropriate management of the pregnancy and delivery.
  4. Enable the development of a care pathway for individual women

For serious abnormalities and reasonably common ones four pathways should be considered:


a. Incompatible with life
b. With serious morbidity in life
c. Amenable to post natal treatment with relatively low morbidity
d. For possible antenatal treatment

However, although these anomalies are identified, they are not always reported, thus up to date data is not always readily available.

 

Reasons for ultrasound screening


Congenital abnormalities still remain one of the leading causes of perinatal morbidity and mortality and a wide variety of structural abnormalities can be detected prenatally by ultrasound scanning.  The optimum time period for undertaking fetal anomaly ultrasound is between 18 weeks to 20 weeks, 6 days gestation.  This allows time for the relevant referrals and investigations to be undertaken as well as giving the woman time to make any necessary decisions about the continuation of the pregnancy prior to the 24 week viability limit.  Obviously the earlier the screening can be performed, the greater time for subsequent action (although screening later may make the identification of some abnormalities easier).

The understanding of the purpose of the scan is variable – from the woman’s perspective it is a chance to see the baby and confirm normality rather than a screening test to look for abnormalities.  From the clinical perspective it is considered to be a useful tool to identify problems which if present allow the clinician to develop management pathways which are likely to optimise outcome.  This dichotomy appears to have led to confusion over the purpose, limitations and benefits of the use of ultrasound screening.

It is important that both women and health professional appreciate that the scan is a screening test and because of that it has limitations.  Invariably some conditions will be missed or misidentified.  Women should receive comprehensible information before the scan and should she choose to decline the screening test then this must be respected.

 

What makes this programme unique?


The uniqueness lies in the fact that the individual or person being directly screened is the fetus, unlike, for example screening for sickle cell and thalassaemia where the woman and genetic father are screened for their carrier status.  Whilst screening has the potential to save lives or improve quality of life through early diagnosis of serious conditions, it is not a fool-proof process and ultrasound, like any screening process can yield both false positive (the fetus wrongly reported as having a malformation/condition) and false negative results (the fetus wrongly reported as no having a malformation/condition).  Equally, practitioners do get it right and what is seen on scan is correct. 


In attempting to reduce parental anxiety referring for a re-scan by another colleague i.e. ‘member checking,’ takes place to refute or confirm the original ultrasound findings.  The business of screening is complex and involves many steps in a programme, from, identification of a population or in this case fetus at risk to diagnosis of a malformation/condition.  This is the very reason why the primary test in any screening programme should not been seen in isolation; rather the ‘whole cake’, not just the ‘slice’ should be considered.  Healthcare professionals are required to see beyond the ‘slice’ and realise that both ‘harm’ and ‘good’ can result. 

 

18+0 to 20+6 weeks fetal anomaly screening ‘base menu’


To ensure that practitioners operate consistently and make the purpose of the scan focused, specific fetal anatomical structures have been selected for assessment.   An ‘ultrasound base menu’ has been developed which provides a list of seven anatomical structures and views which should be observed and recorded.
These key structures lend themselves to detecting a number of abnormalities that should be screened for.  These abnormalities and the expected detection rates for them form the basis of the fetal anomaly screening programme.  It is understood that other conditions may be detected using the base menu, however because there is insufficient data to confidently predict the standard which should be achieved 11 conditions were chosen which Trust ultrasound services will be expected to audited from 2010.

Detection rates

  1. Anencephaly: 98%
  2. Open Spina Bifida: 90%
  3. Serious Cardiac Heart abnormalities: 50%
  4. Bilateral Renal Agenesis: 84%
  5. Lethal Skeletal Dysplasia: 60%
  6. Trisomy 18: 95%
  7. Trisomy 13: 95%
  8. Diaphragmatic Hernia: 60%
  9. Exomphalos: 80%
  10. Gastrochisis: 98%
  11. Cleft Lip: 75%

 

18+0 to 20+6 weeks fetal anomaly screening scan: National standards for England


Again in trying to promote scanning consistency amongst practitioners and also in response to the “...serious gaps and deficiencies” from the 2005 NSC national ultrasound survey, it was necessary to ‘standardise’ all aspects of obstetric ultrasound services, by developing a suite of national standards for England.

Back in 2000, a set of auditable standards, specific to practitioners, was produced by the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists (RCOG)2.  The aim of these was to ensure that services conformed to set ways of working.  As these were produced nearly a decade ago the landscape of obstetric practice has advanced in relation to practice, policy and technology.

From April 2010, hospital Trusts will be expected to implement the new 18 to 20 weeks, 6 days a suite of auditable obstetric ultrasound screening standards, developed by the national programme centre.  The new standards will bring a sense of realism to what ultrasound screening can and, importantly, cannot achieve in terms of how services should be configured, the advice and information women should receive and the screening menu .  For the first time the standards will be explicit for both sonographers and women alike.  In addition it will enable robust auditing of the service.  Maternity services in England account for a significant proportion of the number and cost claims reported to the NHS Litigation Authority (NHSLA) each year.  However, with the advancement of the Programme’s standards, this ultimately should improve clinical performance and reduce risks in patient care.

The standards are a “living” document which will require modification over time but it does provide the basic structure needed to deliver the service. The document would only relate to the 18+0 to 20+6 fetal anomaly ultrasound scan including information about specific structures to measure and observe and those to ignore (normal variant best practice statement, ultrasound base menu and cardiac protocol).  Given the purposes of the fetal anomaly scan, Down’s syndrome screening, first trimester ultrasound and nuchal translucency were excluded from the document.  It is anticipated that the standards will be used to promote flexible and responsive services for the purpose of improving the care for women and their babies.

 

Normal variant screening policy


There are several definitions to describe a soft marker but essentially, ‘a soft marker is an ultrasonic finding from 18 top 22 weeks of pregnancy which increases the risk of the fetus having a chromosomal anomaly (usually Trisomy 21).3 Screening for ‘soft markers’ has been an integral aspect of the obstetric ultrasound scan and for the past 20 years, and was contentious simply because of the maternal anxiety generated for a ‘less sensitive test’ which had limited data to justify its existence.  Additionally, there was not clinical agreement or standardisation amongst clinicians about what should be reported and in what combination and so prenatal treatment and maternal experiences varied. 

Prenatal diagnosis (PND) was not uncommon as markers tended to yield higher false positive rates along with increased psychological morbidity.  It is the woman’s desire to know more about her baby’s health that triggers PND and unfortunately this can result in unnecessary investigation coupled by the loss of unaffected pregnancies. 

Given the seriousness of this evidence, the NHS Fetal Anomaly Screening Programme deemed it necessary to review current practice in an attempt to develop a new sustainable policy for future practice and this will be issued as part of the new standards in early 2010.

 

Consent and ultrasound


Obstetric ultrasound like all examinations or procedures in pregnancy should be described as an option and not as an inevitable part of antenatal care. If the consent process is to be meaningful, it must be clear that refusal is an option.  Individual requirements should be taken into account where possible. Care should be taken to ensure that consent is obtained, even when there is a language or other communication barrier.4


What women may consider being an opportunity to get a scan picture may turn out to be a horrendous experience, if a fetal anomaly is found.  Thus, every woman should be informed about the indication, benefits and limitations of screening and allowed sufficient time to make a make a decision which is right for them. 

 

Horizon scanning and future innovations


Nuchal translucency (NT) and cardiac screening


In the past screening strategies such as combined testing was only available in the independent sector.  However, this is no longer the case since the Model of Best Practice (MoBP) for Down’s Syndrome Screening came into force, advocating the use of first trimester screening.5 Given that NT is an essential component of combined screening, the Programme Centre has devised a national NT infrastructure to provide sonographers with continual support, training and evaluating their NT performance. 

NT is an innovative procedure within NHS hospitals which requires sonographers to undertake additional training.  NT requires sonographers to take an ultrasound measurement (in millimetres) of the maximum thickness of the subcutaneous translucency between the fetal skin and the soft tissue overlying the cervical spine.  High quality machines and skilled sonographers will be needed in order to obtain reliable measurements.  Equally, screening for fetal malformation (including fetal cardiac scanning between 18+0 to 20+6 weeks) requires machines of similar calibre that are capable of improving diagnostic skill.

In recent years there has been an unprecedented emphasis on quality issues in relation to medical care. Recent initiatives are the Darzi report which promotes quality and patient safety.  As such, NHS FASP is in collaboration with the NHS Purchasing And Supply Agency (PASA) to produce a ‘buyer’s guide’ which will enable Trusts to purchase equipment in the most cost-effective way.

Major congenital heart defects occur in approximately 3 in 1000 live births. With the advance of better ultrasound equipment and providing specific training, the current four chamber approach will advance and include the outflow tracts.  It is hoped that by doing this the detection of cardiac anomalies will improve.
The horizons are open and beckoning and other future considerations include:

  • Possible introduction of screening modalities (following review of DH policy)
  • Possible introduction and development of a first trimester fetal anomaly screening programme   


Summary


From a public health perspective, the identification of anomalies can improve perinatal morbidity and mortality as conditions may be identified early in pregnancy and treated accordingly.  From the professional perspective, there are considerable gains if the screening programme were entirely shifted to the first trimester.  There would also be benefits to staff in terms of extending the current scope of practice which limits fetal anomaly scanning to just the second trimester.  Overall, professional satisfaction would prevail in terms of competence and confidence in clinical practice and in turn, promote a positive pregnancy experience for expectant women.

 

References

[1] UK National Screening Committee. Antenatal Ultrasound Screening – Ultrasound Survey of England: 2002.  2005 NHS England

[2] Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists Routine Ultrasound Screening in Pregnancy: Protocol, Standards and Training 2000 RCOG Press

[3] West Midlands Perinatal Institute Soft Markers: A guide for professionals version 2. 2007.

[4] NHS Fetal Anomaly Screening Programme Consent Standards for Screening Fetal Anomalies During Pregnancy 2007 UK NSC

[5] Department of Health NHS Fetal Anomaly Screening Programme – Screening for Down’s Syndrome: UK NSC Policy Recommendations 2007-2010: Model of Best Practice 2008

 

 

Information to support parents and health professionals once a diagnosis of a congenital abnormality has been confirmed

The remit and aim of the NHS National Fetal Anomaly Screening Programme is to set standards and oversee the implementation of a screening programme which conforms to an agreed level of quality for all pregnant women in England. The screen is for certain chromosomal and structural abnormalities in their unborn babies. This includes the offer of an ultrasound scan and biochemical testing during the early stages of pregnancy.

The NHS Fetal Anomaly Screening Programme aims to offer all pregnant women in England a minimum of two ultrasound scans. The first is an early scan, undertaken after 8 weeks gestation and used mainly for dating the pregnancy and confirming viability. The second is undertaken between 18+0 - 20 weeks 6 days of the pregnancy and screens for major structural anomalies.

 

The objectives of the 18+0 to 20+6 weeks ultrasound scan is to:

 

  1. offer choice to women and their partners about their screening options and pregnancy management
  2. identify abnormalities associated with morbidity incompatible with life at a time when choice can operate about continuation of the pregnancy or termination
  3. identify abnormalities that require early intervention following delivery
  4. identify abnormalities that may benefit from interactive treatment.

 

The NHS Fetal Anomaly Screening Programme has agreed that only 11 conditions may be detected by a scan and these have limited detection rates (DR). The detection rates are derived from a number of major reference sources.

 

Detection Rates:

  1. Anencephaly 98%
  2. Open spina bifida 90%
  3. Cleft lip 75%
  4. Diaphragmatic hernia 60%
  5. Gastroschisis 98%
  6. Exomphalos 80%
  7. Serious cardiac abnormalities 50%
  8. Bilateral renal agenesis 84%
  9. Lethal skeletal dysplasia 60%
  10. Edwards’ syndrome 90%
  11. Patau’s syndrome 90%
  12. Alobar holoprosencephaly 80%

 

The following leaflets have been developed by the NHS Fetal Anomaly Screening Programme to help health professional and parents understand more about the conditions that can be scanned for at the ultrasound stage.

  • Anencephaly information for parents
  • Anencephaly information for health professionals

  • Open Spina Bifida information for parents
  • Open Spina Bifida information for health professionals

  • Holoprosencephaly alobar information for parents
  • Holoprosencephaly alobar information for health professionals

  • Diaphramatic Hernia information for parents
  • Diaphramatic Hernia information for health professionals

  • Gastrochisis information for parents
  • Gastrochisis information for health professionals

  • Exomphalos information for parents
  • Exomphalos information for health professionals

  • Bilateral Renal Agenesis information for parents
  • Bilateral Renal Agenesis information for health professionals

  • Lethal Skeletal Dysplasia information for parents
  • Lethal Skeletal Dysplasia information for health professionals

  • T13 information for parents
  • T13 information for health professionals

  • T18 information for parents
  • T18 information for health professionals

 

These booklets will be printed in limited supply and two copies will be sent to each trust in a binder with the 3 chorionic villus sampling (CVS) and amniocentesis leaflets that the NHS FASP have just developed. The binders will also include an introduction to genetics, a list of support groups and a list of publications available from the NHS FASP.

 

The idea is that ultrasound departments will be able to photocopy the leaflets for the parents to take home and also point them in the direction of our website if they wish to download them themselves.  These binders will be posted to all trusts in the New Year to support the publication of the ultrasound standards. All of the contents of the pack are available on the website at: http://fetalanomaly.screening.nhs.uk/publication. Please feel free to download a copy and print it out for your own records.

 

 

Serious cardiac heart abnormalities leaflets provided by the British Heart Foundation (BHF). 

These leaflets have been kindly provided to us by the British Heart Foundation. They form part of a series of booklets about congenital heart diseases. They are meant for parents of children with congenital heart disease and health professionals. It is intended to write 24-30 booklets in total. The estimated date of completion is 2010.

  • Hypoplastic left heart (available Winter 2009)
  • Aortic stenosis
  • Coarctation of the aorta
  • Large ventricular septal defect
  • Pulmonary stenosis
  • Tetralogy of Fallot
  • Transposition of the great arteries 

 

Additional copies of these leaflets can be ordered from the BHF website at www.bhf.org.uk

 

 

These leaflets have been kindly provided to us by the Cleft Lip and Palate Association (CLAPA).

 

  • Antenatal Diagnosis of Cleft Lip and Palate is an 8-page booklet for parents of babies antenatally diagnosed with a cleft.
  • Cleft Lip and Palate – A guide for sonographers is a 20-page booklet for sonographers, with information on cleft lip and palate, how to diagnose the condition, and how to break the news to parents.

 

Illustrated and produced by CLAPA and the Fetal Medicine Unit, St George’s Hospital, London. Additional copies of these leaflets and further information about cleft lip and palate can be obtained from the CLAPA website at www.clapa.com
 

 

 

Further information 

Annual evidence update: antenatal screening for neural tube defects

Annual evidence update: antenatal ultrasound screening for fetal anomalies

 

UK NSC policy on neural tube defects screening in pregnancy

UK NSC policy on fetal anomaly screening in pregnancy

 

NHS Fetal Anomaly Screening Programme website

 

NHS Fetal Anomaly Screening Programme annual report 2006-2008

 

 

Further information for professionals

National Collaborating Centre for Women’s and Children’s Health. Commissioned by the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence. Antenatal care: routine care for the healthy pregnant woman. CG62: full guidance. March 2008 (corrected June 2008). 

 

The NHS Fetal Anomaly Screening Programme has produced a number of pathways which will illustrate the screening process for fetal anomaly and Down's syndrome screening and also the governance responsibilities for health professionals.

 

NHS Fetal Anomaly Screening Programme Pathways

document.topics: <![CDATA[ 18-20 WEEKS,STAFF USE,SPECIALTIES,NEONATAL,CONGENITAL ABNORMALITIES,FETAL MEDICINE,FETAL ANOMALY,NEURAL TUBE DEFECTS,CHILD HEALTH,SCREENING,SCREENING,ANTENATAL,KNOWLEDGE UPDATES]]>
document.body:
111-1Screening for Fetal Anomalies (National Knowledge Week)

     

Back to Contents page

Evidence Update

 

This section has been compiled using text and reports provided by: Pat Ward (Programme Director, National Fetal Anomaly Screening Programme), Lyn  Bryant,  Adam  Fisher  &  Fiona  Vicente (all from the Social Research  &  Regeneration  Unit, University of Plymouth)

 

Fetal anomaly screening programme

Screening for fetal anomalies by an ultrasound scan was introduced on an ad hoc basis in many maternity hospitals in the late 1970s, and by 2002 only 3% did not offer a routine 18-20 week ultrasound scan to all women. In 2003, the National Institute for Clinical Excellence (NICE) guideline Antenatal care: Routine care for the healthy pregnant woman [1]  stated that:

 

"pregnant women should be offered an ultrasound scan to screen for structural anomalies, ideally between 18 to 20 weeks gestation by an appropriately trained sonographer, and with equipment of an appropriate standard" (p15)

 

This has been underpinned by the National Services Framework for Children in 2004 [2]. To take this work forward, a funded programme of work has been set in place by the Department of Health [3].


The main aim of the NHS screening programme for Fetal Anomaly is to offer all pregnant women in England a minimum of 2 ultrasound scans. The first is an early scan, undertaken after 8 weeks gestation and used mainly for dating the pregnancy and confirming viability. The second ultrasound scan is undertaken between 18 – 20 weeks of the pregnancy and screens for major structural anomalies.

 

The objectives of the 18 to 20 weeks ultrasound scan are to:-

1. offer choice to women and their partners about their screening options and pregnancy management.

 

2. identify abnormalities associated with morbidity incompatible with life at a time when choice can operate about continuation of the pregnancy or termination.

 

3. identify abnormalities which require early intervention following delivery

 

4. identify abnormalities which may benefit from interactive treatment.

 

In 2007, the  Social  Research  &  Regeneration  Unit  at  the  University  of  Plymouth  was  commissioned  by  the  Fetal  Anomalies  Steering  Group  to  undertake  a  literature survey related  to  routine  second  trimester  ultrasound  screening. Their search covered the period between January 1996 and 30th April 2007. Detection  rates and  frequencies  for a  specified  list  of  anomalies  diagnosed  at  the  time window of 18 – 22 weeks gestation from the report are summarised below. For the methods and full details of the results and evidence, see the main report [4].

 

Central Nervous System (CNS)

  • Anencephaly  has a  high  prenatal  rate  of  detection, from 96%-100%.

 

  • Encephalocele  is  reported  as  having  frequency  rates  in  the  UK  of  between  1.2  per  10,000  and  2.1  per  10,000  Frequencies  of  as  low  as  0.7  per  10,000  have  also  been  reported. Detection rates vary between 66.6% and 100%.

 

  • Spina bifida - increased  uptake  of  folic  acid  has  decreased  the  incidence  of  spina  bifida  and  more  widesread  use  could  decrease  the  rates  still  further. Overall  frequency  in  16  States  in  the  USA  was  found  to  be  around 4.6  cases  per  10,000  births.

 

  • Hydrocephalus - this  condition  is  frequently  found in conjunction  with  other  conditions,  and  relatively  few  research  papers  dealing  with  isolated  hydrocephalus  were  located.   In the UK,  frequency  rates were  from  5.1  in  10,000  births. Detection  rates  are  variable,  from  100%  to  as  low  as  33%. 

 

  • Holoprosencephaly - the  birth  prevalence  of  holoprosencephaly  is estimated to  be  about 1 per  10,000. Ultrasound  is  seen  as  being  fairly  effective  in  detecting  isolated  holoprosencephaly,  although  some  claim  that  MRI  imaging  may  provide  better  characterisation  of  the  malformations  in  later  pregnancy. 

 

  • Dandy Walker malformation (DWM) and Dandy Walker Variant (DWV) - the birth  prevalence of  Dandy Walker  malformation  is about  1  per  30,000.  Both  the  reported  frequencies  and  detection  rates  show  wide  variations  between  research  studies,  for  example a  rate  of  42% in one study,  compared  with  that  of  91.6% in another.

 

Cardio Vascular System (CVS): Heart

  • Hypoplastic - the  majority  of  cases  diagnosed  during  pregnancy  refer  specifically  to Hypoplastic  Left  Heart/Ventricle.    Varying  detection  rates  for  this  particular  anomaly have been shown,  ranging  from  44.4%  to  88%.   Varying  frequency  figures  for  the  anomaly have also been shown,  ranging  from  1 in 4,856  to  7 in 10,000.     

 

  • AV  Canal – no specific  studies  on  the  prenatal  detection  and  diagnosis  of  the  AV  canal  anomaly  through  ultrasound  scanning  during  the  mid  trimester  of  pregnancy were located.    

 

  • Transposition – prenatal detection rates of between 50 and 53% in Western Europe.

 

  • Fallot - tetralogy  of  the Fallot  condition  involves  the  presence  of  four  heart  malformations:  ventricular  septal  defect,  pulmonary  stenosis,  overriding  aorta  and  right  ventricular  hypertrophy.   Studies from Western  Europe  reveal  two  varying  detection  rates  of  0%  and  49%.  

 

  • Double  Outlets   - no studies  on  the  prenatal  detection  and  diagnosis  of  the  Double  Outlets  anomly  through  ultrasound  scanning  during  the  mid  trimester  of  pregnancy were located.    

 

  • Valve  Atresia  - no studies  on  the  prenatal  detection  and  diagnosis  of  the  Valve  Atresia  anomaly  through ultrasound  scanning  during  the  mid  trimester  of  pregnancy were located.

 

Chest

  • Cystic  Lung  Lesions  - routine  ultrasonograpy  has  enabled  the  prenatal  detection  of  “cystic  lung  disease”.  In  terms  of  frequency  an  incidence  of  1  in  25,000  live  births  has  been  suggested  in  previous  studies, and  and  in  Canada  an  incidence  of  between  1  in  25,000  to  1  in  35,000  pregnancies.  The  lack  of  specific  accuracy  of  the  diagnoses  and  the  fact  that  the  outcomes  may  vary  widely  in  different  cases  has  been emphasised  in studies.

 

  • Diaphragmatic  Hernia  - congenital  diaphragmatic  hernia  is  reported as  having  an  incidence  of  between 3 to 5 per  10,000  live  births,  and  accounts  for  about  8%  of  all  major  congenital  abnormalities.

 

Abdomen

  • Gastroschisis  - detection  rates  reported  in  the  literature  tended  to  be  relatively  high.  In  the  UK,   a  six  year  study  of  fetal  abnormality  in  six  Scottish  health  boards  found  that  100%  of  fetuses  with  gastroschisis  were  identified  by  prenatal  ultrasound.   Other  studies  in  Western  Europe  support  these  findings,  and  detection  rates  range  from  86.6%  to  100%.  

 

  • Exomphalos  - prenatal  detection  rates  for  exomphalos  are relatively  high, and range  from  67.6%  to  100%.  

 

  • Oesophageal  Atresia   - detection  rates  for  oesophageal  atresia  tend  to  be  low  and  the sensitivity of detecting it  in  utero  is  low. There  is  a  need  to  undertake  scans  at  >18  weeks  since  low  detection  rates  have  been  reported  for  this  anomaly  below  24  weeks -  the  mean  time  of  first  detection  was  at  28.5  weeks  with  a  range  of  24-35  weeks. The few studies that were  located  gave detection  rates from  0%  to  50%.  

 

Renal

  • Renal  Agenesis  -  detection rates for the  Renal  Agenesis  anomalies  (unilateral  and  bilateral)  ranged  from  50%  to  100%. 

 

  • Bilateral Renal  Agenesis  is  a  rare  condition  which  occurs  in about  1.8  per  10,000  live  births.

 

  • Renal  Cystic  Disease  - the  accuracy  and  efficiency  of  prenatal  diagnoses  of  recessive  and  dominant  polycystic  renal  disease  (ARPKD  and  ADPKD),  and  multicystic  kidney  disease  (bilateral  and  unilateral),  by  early  to  mid  pregnancy  ultrasound  screening  is  debatable.  Studies revealed a number  of  frequencies  for  renal  cystic  disease anomalies,  but only  one  detection  rate  of  52.3%  for  unilateral  multicystic  kidney  disease  (31.1%  false  positive  rate).

 

  • Upper  Renal  Tract:  Hydronephrosis - hydronephrosis  has  been  described  as  the  most  common  genitourinary  tract  anomaly  identified  in  prenatal  ultrasound  studies.   The  diagnosis  levels  have been put at  between  1%  and  5%  of  all  pregnancies. Mild  or  moderate antenatal  hydronephrosis  can result  in  postnatal  pathology   being  relatively  low - mild  hydronephrosis was shown to improve  or  disappear  spontaneously  in  82%  of  cases.  

 

  • Bladder  Outflow: Posterior  Urethral  Valves (PUV) -   prenatal  detection  of  PUV  is   important  as  surgical  correction  is  required  in  the  early  postnatl  period  to  improve  survival  rates, but most  renal  valve  related  anomalies  are  difficult  to  diagnose  accurately  prenatally.  Prenatal  sonographic  findings  also vary  depending  on  the  gestational  age  of  the  fetus  and  severity  of  obstruction.   Detection  rates  are relatively  high, in France for  example,  a  detection  rate  of  83.3% was reported. Frequencies  have been reported ranging  from  1 in 4000  to  1 in 25,000.   

 

Limbs

  • Lethal  Skeletal  Dysplasia   - the prevalence of skeletal dysplasias is low, about 3.2 per 10,000 live births. Lethal  skeletal  dysplasias  are described as  rare,  with  an  estimated  frequency  of  1  per  10,000  live  births. Ultrasound  is  an  excellent  method  for  discovering  lethal  skeletal  dysplasias  overall,  but other  methods  may  be  necessary  for  making  specific  diagnoses.

 

Face

  • Cleft  Lip - Cleft  lip  with  or  without  cleft  palate  is  most  likely  to  occur  as  an  isolated  anomaly,  with  the  presence  of  other  congenital  anomalies  reported  as  varying  between  different  studies (from  62%  to  79%  of  isolated  cleft  lip/palate).   Detection  rates  of  isolated  cleft  lip  by  ultrasound  also  vary   widely  and  have  tended  to  be relatively  low.  In  the  UK a study found that 48%  of  fetuses  with  cleft  lip,  with  or  without  cleft  palate,  were  identified  by  prenatal  ultrasound,  with  no  false  positives.   Other studies  in  the  USA  show detection  rates  of  between  22  and  30%  by  ultrasound  carried  out  prior  to  22  weeks. The  UK  studies  show  detection  rates  of  between  17.5%  and  88%.

 

References 

[1] National Institute for Clinical Excellence (NICE). Antenatal care: Routine care for the healthy pregnant woman. 2003

 

[2] Department of Health. National Service Framework for children, young people and maternity services. 2004.

 

 

[3] National Fetal Anomaly Ultrasound Screening Programme for England. First Annual Report 2005/2006.

 

 

[4]  Bryant L, Fisher A  and  Vicente  F. Draft Report. Fetal  Anomaly  Ultrasound  Screening Programme  Study: Literature  Survey. June  2007

 

 

Annual evidence update on antenatal screening for fetal anomalies

The Fetal Anomaly Screening Report above [4] included a literature search from Jan 1996 to 30th April 2007, so an additional evidence update was not conducted by the Screening Specialist Library.

 

 

National Screening Committee policy, July 2006

Fetal anomaly screening

 

 

Antenatal ultrasound surveys - national and regional

 

Antenatal ultrasound screening - ultrasound survey of England 2002

 

 

Antenatal Ultrasound Screening: Report of ultrasound service provision in the East of England 2005

 

 

East Midlands - Review of Antenatal Ultrasound Screening Services 2005

 

 

Antenatal Ultrasound Screening: Ultrasound Survey of London 2002

 

 

Ultrasound Survey: an Evaluation of Service Provision in the North East of England 2004

 

 

Antenatal Ultrasound Screening: report of ultrasound service provision in the South East region 2004

 

 

Ultrasound Survey: an Evaluation of Service Provision in the South West of England 2004

 

 

Antenatal Screening in the West Midlands. Second Report - Ultrasound 2004

 

 

Additional information for health professionals

NICE Guidance currently being reviewed: Antenatal Care: routine care for the healthy pregnant woman (Oct 2003). See review details. Consultation period: 4 September - 29 October 2007.

 

British Medical Association (BMA). Abortion time limits: a briefing paper from the BMA. Part 2: diagnosing fetal abnormality. May 2005.

 

Continuous professional development - resources to support the Antenatal and Newborn Screening Programmes: Fetal Anomaly

 

Economic modelling of antenatal screening and ultrasound scanning programmes for identification of fetal abnormalities. Feb 2006 [NHS EED abstract]

 

Fetal Anomaly Screening Programme (FaSP) website

 

National Down’s Syndrome Screening Programme for England. Antenatal screening – working standards. March 2004.

 

 

Information to give pregnant women

Fetal Anomaly Screening Programme. Having a mid-pregnancy ultrasound scan? May 2007. Booklet providing information about the purpose of the ultrasound scan in mid-pregnancy.

 

National Screening Committee (Jan 2007). Screening tests for you and your baby - booklet explaining the screening tests offered to pregnant women and their newborn babies.

 


 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Screening for Fragile-X Syndrome
document.body:
Screening for Fragile X Syndrome

See the review in Bandolier**

Bandolier writes:

"The recommendations made in the report are:-

  1. Cascade screening (ie in affected families) should be regarded as of proven benefit, but national audit of current practice is needed
  2. Paediatric screening - studies are needed to assess current practice
  3. Antenatal screening - the practicality, acceptability and cost of routine antenatal screening should be assessed
  4. The psychosocial consequences of being identified as a 'carrier' should be studied
  5. A central register for all diagnoses should be established.

These recommendations reflect the dilemmas faced by almost all new genetic screening programmes. While we now have the technology to undertake sophisticated DNA screening and we know that the incidence of new cases can be reduced, we have little sound information on the human costs of population screening programmes or the real cost/benefits to the NHS. It is critically important that these questions are addressed".

Reference:

  1. Murray J, Cuckle H, Taylor G, Hewison J. Screening for Fragile X syndrome. Health Technology Assessment 1997; 1(4).

** Note that this review is > 10 years old

]]>

The National Screening Committee convened a workshop on antenatal screening for streptococcus B, in November 2003. The policy not to screen was reaffirmed, but issues requiring further work were identified relating to the current level of knowledge of Group B streptococcus.

This presentation from the workshop is on the implications of midwifery in antenatal screening for streptococcus B.
