document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Screening for infectious diseases in pregnancy (Annual Update 2009)
document.body:
111-1Screening for infectious diseases in pregnancy (Annual Update 2009)

 

Back to contents page

 

 

Since 2007 the Infectious Diseases in Pregnancy Screening Programme has been working on a range of projects aiming to address issues arising from the implementation of the Department of Health’s ‘Standards to support the antenatal screening programme’ (2003).

This work is summarised in the Programme’s annual report along with data on the uptake of screening and the number of positive test results between 2005 and 2007.

An important task has been the review and revision of the current programme standards and the development of recommended standards and algorithms for screening laboratories.  Consultation on these standards will begin in mid October. 

If you wish to be contacted when the consultation begins please contact John Marshall (john.marshall@imperial.nhs.uk).

 

 

Further information 

UK NSC policy on Hepatitis B screening in pregnancy

UK NSC policy on HIV screening in pregnancy

UK NSC policy on rubella susceptibility screening in pregnancy

UK NSC policy on syphilis screening in pregnancy

 

NHS Infectious Diseases in Pregnancy Screening Programme website 

 

NHS Infectious Diseases in Pregnancy Screening Programme Annual Report 2007-08

 

 

Further information for professionals

National Collaborating Centre for Women’s and Children’s Health. Commissioned by the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence. Antenatal care: routine care for the healthy pregnant woman. CG62: full guidance. March 2008 (corrected June 2008).

 

Hepatitis B

BVHG consensus statement - UK guidelines for the management of babies born to women who are HBsAg positive

 

HIV

British HIV Association. Management of HIV infection in pregnant women. 2008

2007 UK guidelines for the management of sexual and reproductive health (SRH) of people living with HIV infection

 

Syphilis

Kingston et al. UK National Guidelines in the management of syphilis. International Journal of STD and AIDS 2008; 19:729-40

 

 

Patient information

Antenatal and Newborn Screening Programmes. Screening tests for you and your baby. 2007

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Screening for Infectious Diseases in Pregnancy (National Knowledge Week)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ BEFORE 16 WEEKS,OUTCOMES,FEMALE,LIVER DISORDERS,HEPATITIS,GENITOURINARY DISEASES,SEXUALLY TRANSMITTED INFECTIONS,COMMUNICABLE DISEASES,RUBELLA,HIV INFECTION,SCREENING,POPULATION BASED & PREVENTATIVE SERVICES,HIV,HEPATITIS B,SYPHILIS,RUBELLA,ANTENATAL,SCREENING,PUBLIC HEALTH,DETERMINANTS,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,INDIVIDUAL BEHAVIOUR,SEXUAL HEALTH,SERVICES,GENDER,POPULATIONS]]>
document.body:
111-1Screening for Infectious Diseases in Pregnancy (National Knowledge Week)

     

Back to Contents page

Annual Evidence Updates: Hepatitis B, HIV, Rubella, Syphilis

 

This section has been written by Professor Catherine Peckham, Institute of Child Health and John Marshall, Programme Manager, Fetal, Maternal and Child Health Coordinating Group

 

The Infectious Diseases in Pregnancy Screening Programme is a collaboration between the Health Protection Agency (HPA), the UK National Screening Committee (NSC) and the Department of Health

 

Screening for infectious diseases in pregnancy has been undertaken for many years and the current programme standards were published in 2003 by the Department of Health to consolidate and extend this practice [1].

 

Screening and treatment recommendations are also reflected in the relevant NICE guidance [2]. Note that this guidance is currently being reviewed - see review details.

 

The standards recommend that all pregnant women should be offered screening, early in each pregnancy, for:

  • Hepatitis B
  • HIV
  • Rubella
  • Syphilis

Screening is offered to help protect the health of both mother and baby.  Early screening is recommended for reasons of clinical effectiveness but it should be offered no matter when booking takes place.

 

In 2004 collaborative work was undertaken by the HPA and NSC to develop tools to support programme implementation and to identify an information standard and data collection process to support programme monitoring.  On October 31st 2007, a small workshop will be held to review progress, consider current policies and identify work streams which would help develop the programme further.

 

Hepatitis B

Hepatitis B is an infection of the liver caused by a virus which can be transmitted, for example, from mother to child at birth, during unprotected sex with an infected partner or via injections using non-sterile needles.  Although 90% of infected adults recover fully from the infection, 10% do become chronic carriers of the virus.  However where infection was acquired from mother to child transmission a much higher proportion, sometimes up to 90%, will become chronic carriers.  About 25% of these will develop liver problems such as cirrhosis or cancer in later life. 

 

Appropriate treatment, either vaccination or a combination of vaccination and immunoglobulin in cases where there is a higher risk of newborn infection, is very effective in preventing transmission of Hepatitis B. 

 

The purpose of screening for Hepatitis B in pregnancy is to identify carriers of the virus as these are at risk of transmitting the infection and their babies will require an appropriate course of treatment following birth to prevent infection.  Identifying mothers with the infection also provides an opportunity for referral for specialist follow up and care.

 

An evidence update has been reviewed and there is no evidence to indicate a change of the current screening policy.  Indeed antenatal screening for Hepatitis B is an important element in efforts to reduce the burden of chronic disease in the UK.

 

However a significant review of current treatment recommendations was produced by the Cochrane Collaboration in 2006 [3]. This suggests that a combination of vaccination and immunoglobulin may be of value in babies born to all carriers rather than just those in the higher risk categories.  The results of the review will be presented at the above mentioned Programme Development Workshop.

 

Syphilis

Syphilis is a bacterial infection which can be transmitted from mother to baby, either across the placenta during pregnancy or during birth from contact with lesions in the birth canal.  It can also be transmitted during unprotected sex with an infected partner.  During pregnancy, infectious syphilis can cause miscarriage or stillbirth and can have serious health consequences for live born children.  The risk of mother to baby transmission is linked to the stage of infection with the highest risk associated with primary infection.  Risk is also linked to gestation as transmission across the placenta can take place from the 18th week of pregnancy. 

 

The purpose of screening is to identify women who have a syphilis infection, early in pregnancy, and who can be referred to specialist services.  Antibiotics are effective in treating maternal infection and, if administered before 18 weeks gestation, are also effective in reducing the risk of transmission to the baby.  Babies of women who have a syphilis infection should also be treated with antibiotics following the birth.

 

An evidence update has been reviewed and there is no evidence to indicate a change of the current screening policy.  As syphilis facilitates HIV transmission and as surveillance reports have highlighted an increasing number of syphilis cases, both in the general population and in the pregnant population [4] [4a] [5], the importance of antenatal screening may be enhanced.

 

Syphilis remains rare in the UK but in the context of a rising rate of infection an important review, published in 2006, highlighted the need to review and monitor local assessment and management practices for syphilis infection in pregnancy [6].  The need for robust national surveillance was also identified as a priority by the review.  The review will be discussed at the above mentioned workshop.

 

The knowledge update also included a range of references which point to the increasing effectiveness of rapid screening tests for syphilis.  These articles mainly refer to poorly resourced contexts but, assuming all four tests could be undertaken in this way, the impact of rapid testing on the patient experience and the cost of screening in the UK could prove valuable to programme’s development.

 

HIV

Pregnant women are offered screening for HIV infection so that interventions can be given to reduce the risk of mother-to-child transmission of infection as well as to improve the woman’s own health. Antiretroviral therapy, the avoidance of breast feeding and appropriate management of delivery can reduce the risk of mother-to-child transmission from around 25% to less than 2%.

 

Since the introduction of antenatal screening for HIV there has been a dramatic reduction in paediatric HIV infections among children whose mothers were diagnosed in pregnancy, despite the marked increase in the number of women with HIV infection [7]  

 

Pregnant women identified in pregnancy are reported to the National Study of HIV in Pregnancy and Childhood (NSHPC), a collaboration between the Institute of Child Health (London) the Health Protection Agency and Health Protection Scotland [8].   The NSHPC is an active and confidential national reporting scheme for pregnancies in HIV-infected women, babies born to HIV-infected women and children with HIV infection. Through the NSHPC it is possible to monitor the prevalence of diagnosed HIV infection in pregnant women and children, evaluate antenatal HIV screening programmes, track changes in the management of HIV in pregnancy and transmission of infection from mother to child and monitor the effects of treatment in pregnancy on children born to HIV-infected women [9] [10].  

 

The NSHPC’s ability to connect information on screening with health outcomes in this way provides a model of best practice for data collection and monitoring of the other three infections within the Infectious Diseases in Pregnancy Screening Programme.  The NSHPC’s value in this regard will be discussed at the programme development workshop.

 

Between 1990 and 2006 about 8000 pregnancies complicated by HIV were reported.  The annual number has exceeded 1000 every year since 2003, and was about 1200 in 2005 and 2006. Over 8600 children born to infected women were reported by the end of 2006, of whom about 10% were born abroad, and 1600 are HIV-infected.

 

An evidence update has been reviewed and there is no evidence to indicate a change in the current screening policy. The update highlights the importance of screening pregnant women for HIV infection, achieving high uptake and monitoring the impact of the screening programme.  The current programme standards recommend that all women should be counselled on the possibility of acquiring HIV infection in the current pregnancy and the update raises the issue of repeat screening for women at increased risk of infection [11].  

 

Several references also point to the importance of rapid tests both for screening women who book late pregnancy or who arrive unscreened in labour and, more generally, as a potential means of improving the screening process [12] [13] [14] [15].   Research in this latter area may be of benefit to the future development of the Infectious Diseases in Pregnancy Screening Programme.

 

Rubella

Rubella is caused by an airborne virus that is passed from person-to-person, for example, by coughs and sneezes. Women who have had rubella or have received the vaccination produce an antibody in the blood that will usually prevent them getting the infection. This protection is called immunity.

 

Rubella infection is usually mild and often unrecognised but when it occurs during the first three months of pregnancy the baby is at risk of having serious defects, particularly heart defects, vision defects and impaired hearing.  Rubella infection, acquired after this stage of pregnancy is unlikely to affect the baby. 

 

The purpose of screening is to identify women who do not have a sufficient amount of antibody to prevent the mother acquiring rubella infection.  Women who are, in this way, susceptible to infection are offered MMR vaccine after the birth of the child to protect subsequent pregnancies from complications arising from a rubella infection.  A standardised approach to rubella vaccination is required and the recent NICE postnatal care guideline recommended that it should be offered prior to discharge from the maternity unit.  Rubella vaccine is contraindicated in pregnancy.

 

Rubella screening in pregnancy supplements the UK childhood immunisation programme in which all children are offered two doses of MMR and as a result of these two approaches congenital rubella is now rare in the UK.  Indeed, by the time women reach childbearing age only about 3% overall are found to be susceptible to rubella infection.  However, women living in the UK who were born abroad are much more likely to be susceptible to rubella that those born in the UK [16]

 

An evidence update has been reviewed and there is no evidence to indicate a change in the current screening policy.  The evidence update highlights the importance of surveillance in assessing the success of screening and vaccination programmes [17].   The UK is fortunate to have a congenital rubella surveillance system organised through the BPSU [17a] to which only 13 cases of confirmed congenital rubella were reported between 1997 and 2005. 

 

However, a combination of demographic change and several years’ sub-optimal uptake of the MMR vaccine emphasises the need to maintain and strengthen the vaccination and screening programmes.  Other European [17b] countries, such as Italy [18] , Romania [19]  and Holland [20] , have reported periodic rubella epidemics and clusters of congenital rubella cases.  The possibility of rubella once again starting to circulate in the UK cannot be excluded and this would put pregnant women at risk of acquiring infection.  This is particularly the case for women living in the UK who were born abroad.

 

The evidence update includes references which point to the importance of preconception care in the prevention of congenital rubella syndrome [21] [22] [23]  and any future plans to develop these services in the UK might consider the case for including rubella in the panel of issues discussed with women planning a pregnancy.

 

References

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Screening for lung cancer with low-dose computed tomography: a systematic review and meta-analysisof the baseline findings of randomized controlled trials
document.publisher: Journal of Thoracic Oncology, Lippincott Williams & Wilkins
document.body:
Authors' conclusions: This systematic review and meta-analysis found insufficient evidence in favour or against screening for lung cancer using low-dose computed tomography.

 

Method: The results of a Medline search were evaluated, and studies were selected on the basis of preset criteria for inclusion and exclusion. The data was collected and analysed for statistical significance.

 

Results: Six RCTs, incorporating 14,000 patients, were included.

 

Citation: Gopal M, Abdullah SE, Grady JJ et al. Screening for lung cancer with low-dose computed tomography: a systematic review and meta-analysisof the baseline findings of randomized controlled trials. Journal of Thoracic Oncology 2010; 5(8):1233-9

 

Access: PubMed abstract available

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Screening for neural tube defects
document.publisher: Agency for Health Care Policy and Research, USA
document.body:
This is the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommendation on screening for neural tube defects**.

'Screening for neural tube defects during pregnancy is currently considered part of standard prenatal care.  The USPSTF knows of no reason at the present time to update its 1996 recommendation. However, the USPSTF has decided to update its recommendation on folic acid supplementation. This work is in progress.' 

**Please note that this recommendation and the evidence on which it is based is >5 years old

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Screening for obesity in adults
document.publisher: Agency for Health Care Policy and Research, USA
document.topics: <![CDATA[ NOT ROUTINELY OFFERED,BIOLOGICAL COMPOSITION,OBESITY,ADULTS,GUIDELINES,POPULATION BASED & PREVENTATIVE SERVICES,SCREENING,ADULT,SCREENING,PUBLIC HEALTH,DETERMINANTS,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,SERVICES,FRAMES OF REFERENCE,MANAGEMENT & POLICY,POPULATIONS,GROUPS,AGE GROUPS]]>
document.body:
This is the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommendation on screening for obesity in adults. The USPSTF recommends "that clinicians screen all adult patients for obesity and offer intensive counseling and behavioral interventions to promote sustained weight loss for obese adults" and concludes that "the evidence is insufficient to recommend for or against the use of moderate- or low-intensity counseling together with behavioral interventions to promote sustained weight loss in obese adults" and "the evidence is insufficient to recommend for or against the use of counseling of any intensity and behavioral interventions to promote sustained weight loss in overweight adults".

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Screening for osteoporosis in postmenopausal women
document.publisher: Agency for Health Care Policy and Research, USA
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SCREENING,OSTEOPOROSIS,BONE DISORDERS,CONDITIONS,MUSCULOSKELETAL,ADULT,OSTEOPOROSIS,SCREENING AND SURVEILLANCE,LATER LIFE,NOT ROUTINELY OFFERED,SCREENING,OLD AGE,OSTEOPOROSIS]]>
document.body:
This is the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommendation on screening for postmenopausal osteoporosis. The USPSTF recommends that "women aged 65 and older be screened routinely for osteoporosis" and that "routine screening begin at age 60 for women at increased risk for osteoporotic fractures". The USPSTF makes "no recommendation for or against routine osteoporosis screening in postmenopausal women who are younger than 60 or in women aged 60-64 who are not at increased risk for osteoporotic fractures".

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Screening for prostate cancer
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SCREENING,CANCER,ADULT,PROSTATE,NOT ROUTINELY OFFERED,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,PROSTATE CANCER,PROSTATE DISORDERS,MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS]]>
document.body:
Screening for prostate cancer

See the review in Bandolier**

Bandolier write:

"Bandolier is impressed with the results of the two [reviews] on prostate cancer. The reviews, while covering similar territory, were done by different teams. Importantly, they reach the same conclusion, that screening for prostate cancer is unproven, and is unlikely to be of any benefit.

References:

  1. DM Richards, JJ Deeks, TA Sheldon, JL Shaffer. Home parenteral nutrition. Health Technology Assessment 1997 1: no1.
  2. S Selley, J Donovan, A Faulkner, J Coast, D Gillatt. Diagnosis, management and screening of early localised prostate cancer. Health Technology Assessment 1997 1: no2.
  3. J Chamberlain, J Melia, S Moss, J Brown. The diagnosis, management, treatment and costs of prostate cancer in England and Wales. Health Technology Assessment 1997 1: no3.
  4. RA Moore. Prostate-Specific Antigen. Kaleidescope 4: 1-55 (1994).

** Note that this review is >5 years old

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Screening for prostate cancer: systematic review and meta-analysis of randomised controlled trials
document.body:
Authors' conclusions: Routine screening for prostate cancer with prostate specific antigen (PSA) with or without digital rectal examination is not supported by the existing evidence from randomised controlled trials.

Method: Medline, Embase, CENTRAL , abstract proceedings and reference lists up to July 2010 were searched. Randomised controlled trials comparing screening by PSA with or without digital rectal examination were included.

Results: Six randomised controlled trials (including 387,286 participants) met the inclusion criteria and  were analysed. 

Citation: Djulbegovic M, Beyth RJ, Neuberger MN, et al. Screening for prostate cancer: systematic review and meta-analysis of randomised controlled trials. BMJ 2010; 341:c4543


Access: Full text freely available

]]>

document.body:
This is the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommendation on screening for Rh(D) blood typing. The USPSTF strongly recommends "Rh (D) blood typing and antibody testing for all pregnant women during their first visit for pregnancy-related care". The USPSTF also recommends "repeated Rh (D) antibody testing for all unsensitized Rh (D)-negative women at 24-28 weeks' gestation, unless the biological father is known to be Rh (D)-negative".

document.body:
111-1Screening for sickle cell and thalassaemia (Annual Evidence Update 2009)

 

 

Back to contents page

 

 

Screening for sickle cell and thalassaemia evidence update

 

 

In September 2008, the NHS Sickle cell and Thalassaemia Screening Programme created an evidence update and summary on antenatal screening for sickle cell and thalassaemia and newborn screening for sickle cell.

 

Further information

 

[Annual evidence update]

 

UK NSC policy on sickle cell and thalassaemia screening in pregnancy

UK NSC policy on sickle cell screening in newborns

 

NHS Sickle Cell and Thalassaemia Screening Programme website

 

NHS Sickle Cell and Thalassaemia Screening Programme annual report 2007-2008

 

Further information for professionals

National Collaborating Centre for Women’s and Children’s Health. Commissioned by the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence. Antenatal care: routine care for the healthy pregnant woman. CG62: full guidance. March 2008 (corrected June 2008).

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Screening for Sickle Cell and Thalassaemia (National Knowledge Week)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ NEWBORN,BLOODSPOT (<1WK),SICKLE CELL DISEASE,ANTENATAL,SCREENING,8-10 WEEKS,SICKLE CELL & THALASSAEMIA]]>
document.body:
111-1Screening for Sickle Cell and Thalassaemia (National Knowledge Week)

Back to Contents page           

Annual Evidence Update

 

This section has been written by Dr. Sandra Anglin (Programme Implementation Manager) and Dr. Allison Streetly (Programme Director), NHS Sickle Cell & Thalassaemia Screening Programme, King's College of London, School of Medicine

 

Section contents:

NHS Sickle Cell & Thalassaemia Screening Programme

Symptoms and Management of Sickle Cell & Thalassaemia

Genetic transmission and prevalence in the UK

1. Newborn screening

2. Antenatal screening

 

NHS Sickle Cell & Thalassaemia Screening Programme
The NHS Plan [1] made commitments to improve the provision of screening services. The NHS Sickle Cell & Thalassaemia Screening Programme was set up to deliver the following:

 

• The newborn sickle cell screening programme, to achieve the lowest possible childhood mortality and morbidity rates from sickle cell disease through offering screening for sickle cell disease in newborns.

 

• The antenatal sickle cell & thalassaemia screening programme, to offer effective and appropriate sickle cell and thalassaemia screening to all eligible women and couples in a timely manner in pregnancy.

 

Further information about the Programme is available from the following website: www.sct.screening.nhs.uk/

 

Back to section contents


Symptoms and Management of Sickle Cell & Thalassaemia
Sickle cell disease and thalassaemia are common recessively inherited genetic blood conditions.


 
Sickle cell disease changes the biochemistry of haemoglobin in red blood cells and makes the cells sickle-shaped. These blood cells are less able to carry oxygen around the body. The symptoms of sickle cell disease can include:

 

  • severe anaemia
  • intense pain
  • damage to major organs
  • infections

Proper management and early detection in newborns can improve quality of life, including enabling parents/guardians  to learn to recognise certain risk factors in their child and avoid the factors that can trigger painful ‘crisis’ attacks and giving antibiotics each day to prevent infections.

 

Thalassaemia major (the most severe form of thalassaemia) reduces the amount of haemoglobin made by the body. Those with the condition require blood transfusions every four to six weeks and can suffer from chronic diseases (such as diabetes), growth or puberty failure.

 

Because both conditions can restrict a child’s or an adult’s ability to conduct normal daily activities, they can also have profound psychosocial effects on individuals and their families.

 

Back to section contents

 

Genetic transmission and prevalence in the UK
The highest prevalence of these conditions is present in people whose descendants lived in malarial areas. If two healthy carriers of the sickle cell or thalassaemia gene variant have a child, there is a 1 in 4 chance with each pregnancy that the child will have a sickle cell disease or thalassaemia.

 

In the UK, it is estimated that 240,000 people are healthy carriers of the sickle cell gene variant and over 12,500 people have a sickle cell disease. The highest prevalence of sickle cell disease is found amongst Black Caribbeans, Black Africans and Black British.

 

Sickle cell disease presently affect more than 1 in every 2400 births in the UK. It is vital to identify babies with the condition as soon as possible. There is a high risk of sudden death in the early years of life and prophylactic treatment must be administered early.  All newborn babies are now being offered screening for sickle cell disease.

 

Thalassaemias are less common. 214,000 people are healthy carriers of the thalassaemia gene variant and over 700 people have thalassaemia. Those with the highest prevalence of thalassaemia are Cypriots, Indians, Pakistanis, Bangladeshis, Chinese, and other Asian groups.

 

Both gene variants are also (less commonly) found in the northern European population. Modell B et al, 2007 report that with population movement sickle cell and thalassaemia are increasingly common in countries of Northern and Western Europe [1a].

 

In general there are a very limited number of high quality trials in the areas of haemoglobinopathies.  There is also a lack of accurate information about the size of the population affected, and evidence on the most effective way to manage the disease in the UK, most of which comes from the USA and the Medical Research Council Unit in Jamaica.

 

The National Institute of Clinical Guidance will be consulting on a revised guideline for all routine care for the pregnant woman from 4 September 2007 to 29 October 2007, including revised guidance on screening for sickle cell and thalassaemia, we therefore urge that you look at this consultation [2]

 

Back to section contents

 

1. Newborn screening:

 

Current Policy
The newborn screening programme for sickle cell disease aim is to offer screening to all infants as an integral part of the newborn bloodspot screening programme identifying all those affected so as to ensure that early treatment reduces mortality and morbidity rates. 

 

1.1 Carrier identification in newborn screening:

The current technology used to screen also identifies those that are genetic carriers of sickle and other haemoglobin variants, but whose health is not affected.  The issue for carriers is distinct from the health problems of affected babies as there is no need for treatment and therefore no immediate benefit for health from the screening programme, but there are a variety of possible psychosocial consequences of disclosing carrier status: such as increasing anxiety for families, impacting on parental behaviour towards child, impacting on parental relationship, impacting on reproductive planning, highlighting non paternity etc.  Unfortunately there is little evidence and no trials about the impact or effects of disclosing newborn carrier status and/or the best way to inform the parents of those affected. 

 

In the past year the Human Genetic Commission (HGC) has provided a clear view on the issue of newborn carrier identification, which supports the general approach taken by the NSC and the programme. That is, given carriers are identified as a by-product of newborn screening, parents should be informed of these results and they should not be with held.

 

The HGC recommend that efforts are made to develop methods that will not identify carriers. Information on new technologies under development are covered further on in this review. Finally the HGC suggests an approach to resolution of the unidentified variants issue, which is relevant to both newborn and antenatal screening and about which there is currently no consensus – how this recommendation is actioned is under consideration. Details from letters from the HGC to the UK National Screening Committee and text in their recent report Making Babies [2b] are given below:

 

Human Genetics commission:

The Making Babies report states that the Commission strongly support sharing information about genetic status from screening (paragraph 3.48). 

 

“The extension of the neonatal screening programme to cystic fibrosis (CF) highlights the issue of detecting carriers for these recessive conditions. Screening for this condition with the current testing technique identifies only a very small proportion of carriers, and they require clinical assessment to ensure that they are not affected by the disease. The numbers of CF carrier infants identified in this way is similar to the number of affected infants likely to benefit from early diagnosis. Whilst some would say this information ought not to be divulged, others, including patient representatives, argue strongly that the result of the tests, once generated, should be given to the parents. We support this latter position and this information should not be withheld from parents who indicate that they wish to have it when agreeing to have their child tested. "

 

The Commission strongly believe that in principle carriers should be notified of their status and the implications of this.  However, there may be situations where a medical judgement needs to be made about what genetic information is clinically significant, and should therefore be shared with the patient, and what is not.  Such a decision may need to be made about non-sickle haemoglobin variants that are detected that have unknown clinical significance. Exercising such medical judgement is part of normal medical practice.  To determine a consistent approach and make an informed policy decision, the National Screening Committee should seek expert opinion on this matter from professionals involved in this specific field. 

 

Also in the Making Babies report at paragraph 3.50, the Commission recommended that efforts be made to develop accurate screening techniques that do not reveal carrier status (where this information is not clinically relevant).  Through this recommendation, the Commission would like to see tests developed that reveal the disease phenotype only, as this would enable children to make decisions about whether they should be tested for carrier status when they were able to make this decision for themselves, perhaps before starting a family. 


Further to this the programme would support research in the form of a clinical trial to determine the best way to inform parents of results. Currently research funded by the NHS Health Technology Assessment (HTA) is underway to describe current approaches to information giving, and review the literature [3].  The aim of the study is to describe, explore and synthesise current practice, methods and experience of communicating carrier status information following newborn screening to inform practice and the need for further research. 

 

The study will use postal questionnaires to a sample of relevant stakeholders in the UK to look at current practice and methods for communicating carrier status how and by whom parents are informed, and a qualitative study with parents, using face to face interviews from a sample of parents that have had carrier results.  The study aims to report on the challenges and suggest how current practice could be improved.

 

1.2  New methods

Two new methods of newborn screening are under development and evaluation. Potentially, both these methods offer more cost-effective methods of screening and would also limit the number of carriers identified.

Tandem mass-spectrometry (MS-MS):
Earlier work by a group at Guy’s Hospital identified that MS-MS was potentially a useful, cost-effective method for newborn screening [4]. Their work demonstrated that consumable costs are minimal and that metabolite and sickle screening can be performed serially on the same MSMS instrument.

 

More recently this group have had a paper published explaining the use of MSMS to estimate the amount of HbA2 present in a blood specimen [5].

 

The main findings reported are that the delta/beta globin chain ratio, measured using trypsin digestion and electro-spray MSMS, can be used as an alternative to the measurement of HbA2. The delta/beta ratio, unlike HbA2, is stable on blood spots for at least 1 month. The authors suggest that MSMS could be used for both newborn and antenatal haemoglobinopathy screening. As a result of this exciting development, a pilot service evaluation of this method is being undertaken by the Guy’s group in collaboration with Leeds. Results from this work are due in 2008.

 

Immunoassay method:
A recent paper from Belgium has evaluated an enzyme linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) method for sickle cell disease on 27,000 newborn babies [6]. The method appeared to work well although they report that “..this antibody cross reacts with HbA. Better specificity is achieved if the test is performed not later than day 5”. Given the timing of tests in England of 5-8 days, this may affect the performance of this test unless the timing of the bloodspot was shifted to earlier. Overall 130 samples were positive and there were 17 false positives.  A pilot project is due start in London later this summer.


1.3 Developments of newborn screening programmes in Europe and North America.

There continue to be reports of pilot projects for newborn screening in other countries which are following the approach adopted in England. As yet Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland have not made a decision as to their approach to newborn sickle cell screening. The most recent reports in Europe are from Madrid and Catalonia in Spain [7] [8] [9]

 

Programmes also appear to be developing in Canada. The findings of a cord blood testing programme offered to “black” babies demonstrated that such a programme will miss about 10% of affected infants. On the basis of this pilot newborn screening is recommended in Canada. Informally the programme understands that other Canadian States such as British Columbia are now considering the approach to be adopted [10]


1.4 Evidence of outcomes from newborn screening programmes:

A report on the outcome of newborn screening from Connecticut in the USA found no deaths in infants identified in the 11 and a half years since the programme was introduced compared to 13 deaths in the preceding 13 years. However they also reported that five affected infants missed since newborn screening were identified at death. This emphasises the importance of adequate failsafe systems being established for the newborn programme in England and effective follow-up and clinical care following identification [11]

 

1.5 Evidence of clinical outcomes and guidance on clinical management:

The introduction of the new pneumococcal vaccine into the general immunisation schedule in England has been a welcome development. For sickle cell babies there is now evidence from the USA of the significant benefit that will be achieved from this programme where the rate of invasive pneumococcal disease decreased by about 90% in children under 2 years from 3.6 to 0.3 per 1000 person years of follow up. However babies and children with sickle cell disease have a reduced immunity and require extra immunisations as well as penicillin on a continious basis until age 5 as not all infections are prevented by these measures [12]

 

A key finding since the HTAs [13] [14] that informed the introduction of newborn screening in England is the potential for stroke prevention as demonstrated in the STOP trial in the USA. This is an additional benefit of early identification of affected infants, especially as the morbidity, mortality and costs associated with stroke in childhood are highly significant.

 

Sickle cell disease is the commonest cause of stroke in childhood in the UK, with an incidence of 0.6/100 patient years. The peak incidence is between the ages of 2 and 7 years, and by the age of 10 about 6% children have suffered clinical strokes. These are associated with both physical and cognitive problems and generally have a large effect on the quality of life. Children can be screened for narrowing of intracerebral blood vessels from the age of 2 years by transcranial Doppler (TCD) scanning. Children with abnormalities are at increased risk of stroke and the STOP study showed that giving these children regular blood transfusions reduces the risk of stroke by 90%. Stroke is therefore a partly preventable complication making the identification of all children with sickle cell disease more important.

 

Epidemiological studies from California suggest that the stroke rate is declining following the introduction of TCD scanning, although there is currently limited access to appropriate scans both in the UK and USA - clinical services need to be developed to incorporate these findings. This intervention to prevent stroke should also be incorporated into the stroke strategy (currently under consultation)

 

The final results of this trial are now published [15]

 

The findings from this study have been incorporated in Clinical Guidelines produced in this country [16]

 

Proposals to establish a clinical network to support the ultrasound screening and follow-up required are supported by the Department of Health but not yet developed. The key requirements for stroke prevention are annual quality-assured ultrasound screening for all children from the age of three. Those at high risk of stroke require ongoing transfusion and iron chelation. A new oral iron chelator (Exjade) has recently received a licence. The HTA programme are undertaking a review of this against other iron chelators, including looking at the wider clinical perspective, a report forming part of the HTA monograph series is due to be published early 2008. [17]

 

A useful review of recent trials in sickle cell is available by Kirkham et al [18]. Interestingly it appears that rates of stroke are as common in children in Cameroon, West Africa as in the Western Countries [19].

 

Guidelines from the USA on the prevention of stroke that incorporate recommendations about sickle cell have recently been published and may be useful in the development of relevant guidance in the national stroke strategy [20]

 

1.6 Information to support parents

 

A useful reference for information on newborn screening from the USA is available [21]. This development is also discussed by Kaye et al in a recent publication [22].

 

The SC and T Programme has produced information for newborn carriers, which is available on the programmes website [22a].  The leaflets will be  ‘market tested’ at a later stage.  More detailed information will be produced in 2008.


Back to section contents

 

2. Antenatal screening:

 

Current Policy
The Programme recommends that the offer of screening includes uptake of and reporting of results of pre natal diagnosis and any subsequent action by the end of 12 weeks of pregnancy:

  • In areas of high prevalence (where the fetal prevalence of sickle cell disease is >1.5 per 10,000 births) all women are offered screening for sickle cell including other haemoglobin variants and thalassaemia irrespective of family origins.

 

  • In areas of low prevalence (sickle cell disease prevalence is <1.5 per 10,000 births) women are offered screening for thalassaemia and a family origin questionnaire is used to assess the risk of being a carrier for sickle cell and other haemoglobin variants.  If the questionnaire reveals family origins of either the woman or baby’s father in the high risk groups, the woman is offered screening for sickle cell.

 

  • The Family Origin Questionnaire is  available on the Programme website [23]

 

The timing and organisational requirements for the delivery of the main aims and objectives presents a considerable challenge to health care professional, however, there is evidence to support this approach:

 

2. 1. Evidence supporting the antenatal programmes approach to screening.

2.1.1. Information about professional knowledge and attitudes:

Early screening for sickle cell and thalassaemia in pregnancy or before pregnancy are one of the key aims and objectives of the programme.  Practically this means early enough in pregnancy to allow a vacuum suction termination if wished and for decisions on prenatal diagnosis and termination to be made before pregnancy is public knowledge amongst families. Studies have shown that the usual system for antenatal screening for haemoglobinopathies permits termination only after 12 weeks of pregnancy.  The study by Wright et al [24] and the study by Thomas et al [25], shows that primary care based screening programme where pregnant women are screened in general practice (including counselling and follow-up) allows earlier detection of carrier status.  The overriding conclusion was that antenatal screening for haemoglobinopathies in general practice lowers the gestational age at which an at-risk pregnancy can be identified.

 

A study 'Screening for Haemoglobinopathies In First Trimester ( SHIFT) to assess and compare the feasibility, acceptability, effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of offering antenatal screening for sickle cell and thalassaemia in one of three ways model' is currently underway, due to report in 2008:

 

1. In primary care, when women first report their pregnancies with parallel partner testing


2. In primary care, when women first report their pregnancies with sequential partner testing; (i.e. partners of women are only offered screening if the pregnant woman is found to be a carrier)


3. In community-based secondary care, when women are booked by midwives with sequential partner testing

 

Initial findings show that women generally present early as pregnant irrespective of family or ethnic origin, but there is a considerable delay in referral for the first booking appointment with a midwife.  Further information is available on the study website [26]


A recent study from the UK suggest that GPs perceive that they lack the confidence to provide basic prenatal genetic advice to women at risk of the commonest recessive disorders, with particularly low confidence where the couple both carry thalassaemia [27]. A significant knowledge gap was demonstrated by the poor awareness of the importance of rapid referral to prenatal diagnostic services. These findings support much anecdotal evidence and emphasise the challenge that raising professional awareness amongst primary care. This area requires action if the screening programme is to achieve its objectives and emphasises the importance of including primary care in antenatal screening education.


2.1.2 Information about Users Attitudes to screening:

Previous research identified that women are not receiving counselling and testing in time to allow reproductive choice. Women should ideally be offered testing by 10 weeks of pregnancy and as soon as possible after they make first contact with the NHS [28].

 

A descriptive qualitative study [29] to explore 43 Pakistani women’s views about antenatal screening for thalassaemia and termination of pregnancy for thalassaemia major concluded that Pakistani women’s attitudes toward prenatal diagnosis and termination of pregnancy are influenced by various factors, and therefore their religion should not be taken as a proxy for their attitudes for or against screening. Women’s responses suggested that the more severe the perception of thalassaemia major, the more likely the woman was to be in favour of antenatal diagnosis and termination of pregnancy. Some women also expressed the view that termination of pregnancy was only acceptable early in pregnancy, although women’s definitions of early ranged from 5-6 weeks to “before people know you are pregnant”.


 

One descriptive study aimed to examine the acceptability of pre-natal diagnosis as a means of controlling the number of babies born with sickle cell disease [30].  This interview survey was conducted in Nigeria, targeting well-educated, city-dwelling adults (n=433).

 

The survey respondents were aged 15-50, approximately half of whom were women. 90% of the sample attended school up to secondary and post-secondary level, 67% were in professional occupations (eg. medicine, law and teaching). Two-thirds of the sample knew their Hb phenotype. Most respondents (88%) perceived sickle cell disease as a serious disease, although 19% thought it was curable. Only 4% of those interviewed had received sickle cell counselling, although 15% reported themselves to be sickle cell trait. 78% of respondents felt prenatal sickle cell diagnosis should be available and 45% reported that they would decide to terminate a baby affected with sickle cell disease. Cross-tabulations showed that neither religion nor educational level significantly affected a person’s decision whether or not to terminate an affected pregnancy.

2.1.3. Assessment of Risk for Haemoglobinopathies

Background
The SC & T Programme commissioned some work to develop, pilot and evaluate an evidence-based ethnic question to establish its effectiveness as a screening tool to identify individuals at higher risk from specific haemoglobinopathies [30a]. This paper followed on from earlier research that the programme had commissioned [31].

 

However, the study has had a number of difficulties and conflicts and as a result, there was considerable delay in the publication of the final report, which may have contributed to the lack of directive information in the NICE Antenatal care guideline produced in 2003 [32].

 

The EQUANS study in which this paper has been derived provided limited information in relation to the original intended purpose of informing national policy, and therefore the Programme commissioned a further study as part of the first phase of implementation of antenatal screening in seven maternity units to inform the antenatal policy process.

Integration into Routine Care
One of the main criticisms of the study led by Simon Dyson is that it did not link well with all staff involved in the programme. In more than one of the sites, they were disappointed and did not think the training delivered by the research team had engaged all key stakeholders, and that offers of help had not been taken up. This makes interpretation of information on uptake of the family origin question in a routine antenatal setting and the offer of the test difficult. This is compounded by the very different results in the four sites suggesting that site specific issues are relevant.

 

The important point is that the precision of the estimates are reduced.  Our findings from the evaluation of the family origin questionnaire from the seven maternity sites involved in the first phase of implementation of antenatal screening, have a considerably higher uptake (completion rates for 6 sites were 97%, as opposed to 25% in this study). We are aware this does not completely invalidate the findings, but does not reflect well and has been superceded by the implementation of the programme.

 

Analysis of Data
It is important to clarify the areas of concern overall and their likely importance including the source and type of errors.  It is possible (personal correspondence –Aspinall co- applicant) to estimate the rates for each carrier state, for each site, for both question A and B and identify where the problems lie with the question. This has not been done and makes the presentation of the results limited.

 

Other areas of concern highlighted by the report was the low level of completion of the questionnaire, and the failure to integrate the questionnaire and consequent follow up of it into routine antenatal booking, which may have resulted from issues of training and staff time available rather than the performance of the questions.

 

As for the precision of the estimates - there is evidence of between-centre variation in time taken.  Under these circumstances, estimates of the average time taken, sensitivity and specificity should have been derived from ‘random effect’ (multi-level) models, and not ruled out.  The use of only four centres will result in estimates with much greater uncertainty than is implied by the ‘fixed effect’ model assumed in the analyses reported.  As a result of this the Programme is unable to come to the same conclusions, as it is hard to know whether the time taken for questions A and B are realistic.

 

With respect to whether the missed cases, the paper reports that 7/122 carriers for question A and 10/103 carriers for question B were not picked up. We learn that of the 7/122 carriers missed; 2 had missing information (would be tested if they consented or counted as refusals but this is not known so probably were not offered screening), 3 were not offered screening, 1 declined and 1 was tested due to findings of routine indices, so was in effect missed by the question but detected by the screening protocol as a whole.

 

No information of the types of carriers by these 7/10 cases is given, analysis should have been presented in this report to clarify the missed cases and the types of errors concerned. The analysis should also have described how the question is used in practice in terms of MCH cut-offs to enhance the understanding of how the question works but this is not covered.

 

For example as all women have routine blood indices inspected, Beta Thalassaemia carriers should be identified and therefore the key carrier states to be identified by the family origin question are most importantly S C, D & E.  The paper gives none of this analysis, which is what is really needed to understand what the likely implications of the findings would be. In  addition, there is no comparison of the completeness of missing information rates as a total, refusal rates as a total, or incomplete rates for the two questions simply missing rates for the carrier results.  Inclusion of ‘don’t knows’ in the error was misguided as many are not aware of ethnic origins and would be advised to “opt in” to screening.


 

Conclusions:
The main conclusion to be drawn from the study as reported was that ensuring the test was offered is the most important indicator of whether this type of screening tool would work. Due to the limitations described above it is not possible to conclude that the question did not work as there were significant problems in the implementation of the study and engagement of staff.  Due to conflicts between the researchers and refusal to share information, as well as the editors of the journal concerned who did not to allow the Programme to write a letter in reply to this article – as the journal does not publish letters-  we remain concerned that the true information about these findings are not available.

 

In particular of the 7 clinically relevant haemoglobinopathies our impression is that this definition is loose and includes a number of results which the programme would not consider to be “clinically significant” – mainly alpha thalassaemia + results. As far as we are aware only one HbS result was missed.

 

The sensitivity of question A appears at least as good as the estimates made by Zeuner et al [13], but the paper does not report the detail required to comment further.

 

A useful finding from the paper was that the first question A performed better than the intuitively more attractive question B. This information has been used by the programme in developing the format of the final family origin questionnaire [23].


 

Our subsequent first phase of implementation using the family origin question adapted from Aspinalls original publication suggest that the study uptake findings are not representative of what can be expected in the NHS service situation which is considerable higher than that reported in the paper published [33]

We have also commissioned an independent study of the family origin questionnaire (FOQ) which gives a huge amount of useful detail, which has since been used in the implementation and used to further modify the FOQ [34]

More information about the first phase of implementation in low prevalence areas will be available on the programme website shortly.

 

Experience from elsewhere also developing such a questionnaire

 

The findings from the study by Lakeman et al supports the SC & T Programme policy for screening in low prevalence areas [35]. The questionnaire uses a similar methodology to that adopted in England whereby the couples are asked to report their known origins, although our initial study had ruled out the use of maps as an effective way to identify origins [33].


2.2 New technology:

Daniel et al have described the potential to do antenatal, as well as newborn screening on a dried bloodspot, this would be a useful technique, allowing for further centralisation of antenatal screening, and could potentially reduce the cost of laboratory screening especially in low prevalence areas [5].

 


2.3 Information for parents:

There is a mass of information about haemoglobinopathy screening available of varying quality and accuracy.  Involvement of users is a key elelment of the development of policy and implementation of all the screening services including the development of materials for the SC & T Programme.  The Programme intends to develop materials for users along the whole care pathway for screening, from pre-conception to antenatal and newborn screening.  Some material is already available on the Programme website, and we have also worked with other organisations to develop materials. 

 

The SC & T Programme commissioned DIPEx to find and post a number of a personal experiences of antenatal screening in text, audio and video formats. These are available on the DipEX website to be used by women and families going through a similar process and / or for training of health care professionals [37]

[33]  ETHOS. EQUANS (Ethnic Question and Antenatal Screening for Sickle Cell/Thalassaemia) Interim Report 3. Use of maps in antenatal screening for SCD/Thalassaemia. 2002.

 

[34] ETHNOS. Evaluation of the "family origin questionnaire". March 2006.

 

[35] Lakeman P, Henneman L, Bezemer PD, Cornel MC, ten Kate LP. Developing and optimizing a decisional instrument using self-reported ancestry for carrier screening in a multi-ethnic society. Genetics in Medicine 2006, 8(8):502-9. [PubMed abstract]

 

[37] DIPEX. Screening for sickle cell and beta-thalassaemia. Personal experiences of health and illness – patient information module. May 2006.

 

 

Annual evidence updates on antenatal screening for sickle cell and thalassaemia, and newborn screening for sickle cell disease 2006/07

 

The Screening Library has identified the new evidence published over the last year, and the results of our search are classified and presented as an evidence update below.

 

Sickle cell and thalassaemia

 

 

National Screening Committee policies, July 2006

 

Sickle cell and thalassaemia screening (in pregnancy)

 

Sickle cell disorders screening (in newborns)

 

 

Other information for health professionals

Information to give pregnant women and parents

NHS Sickle Cell and Thalassaemia Screening Programme. Factsheets. Sept 2007.

 

Lab tests online - searchable website designed to help consumers understand the many clinical lab tests that are part of routine care. See pregnancy screening (Aug 2006).

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Screening for testicular cancer: and evidence review for the US Preventive Services Task Force
document.publisher: Annals of Internal Medicine, American College of Physicians
document.body:
Author's conclusions: No new evidence was found that would change the US Preventive Services Task Force's 2004 recommendation against screening for testicular cancer.

 

Method: PubMed and the Cochrane Library were searched between 1 January 2001 and 11 November 2009. Randomized controlled trials, meta-analyses, systematic reviews, cohort studies and case-control studies were included to determine benefits. Randomized controlled trials, meta-analyses, systematic reviews, cohort studies, case-control studies and case series of large multisite databases were included to determine harms. Both autors reviewed titles, abstracts and full-text for inclusion and one author carried out data extraction.

 

Results: Three studies were considered for inclusion.

 

Citation: Lin K and Sharangpani R. Screening for testicular cancer: an evidence review for the US Preventive Services Task Force. Annals of Internal Medicine 2010; 153(6):396-9

 

Access: Full text also available via the US Preventive Services Task Force website

]]>

The USPSTF "recommends screening for type 2 diabetes in asymptomatic adults with sustained blood pressure (either treated or untreated) greater than 135/80 mm Hg." but concludes "that the current evidence is insufficient to assess the balance of benefits and harms of screening for type 2 diabetes in asymptomatic adults with blood pressure of 135/80 mm Hg or lower."

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Screening for Type 2 Diabetes: literature review and economic modelling
document.topics: <![CDATA[ NOT ROUTINELY OFFERED,OUTCOMES,ENDOCRINE DISORDERS,DIABETES,SCREENING,POPULATION BASED & PREVENTATIVE SERVICES,ADULT,DIABETES,SCREENING,PUBLIC HEALTH,VASCULAR RISK,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,SERVICES,2008-NOVEMBER,MONTHLY ADDITIONS]]>
document.body:
Screening for Type 2 Diabetes: literature review and economic modelling (Waugh) Health Technology Assessment 2007; Volume 11, number 17.

This HTA report concluded that:

"The case for screening for undiagnosed diabetes is probably somewhat stronger than it was at the last review, because of the greater options for reduction of cardiovascular disease, principally through the use of statins, and because of the rising prevalence of overweight and hence type 2 diabetes. However, there is also a good case for screening for IGT, with the aim of preventing some future diabetes and reducing cardiovascular disease."

]]>

document.title: Screening for visual impairment in children
document.body:
Bibliographic details of the original research
Institut fuer Qualitaet und Wirtschaftlichkeit im Gesundheitswesen. Screening for visual impairment in children. Institut fuer Qualitaet und Wirtschaftlichkeit im Gesundheitswesen (IQWiG). 2008
 
The main aim of this review was the benefit assessment (i.e. the assessment of patient-relevant outcomes) of screening for visual impairment (universal vision screening) in children up to the age of 6. By diagnosing and treating amblyopia or amblyogenic risk factors as early as possible, paediatric developmental delay and its potentially lifelong consequences should be prevented, or at least ameliorated.
]]>

document.title: Screening HIV-infected individuals for anal cancer precursor lesions: a systematic review
document.description: Systematic review published in Clin Infect Dis.
document.body:
Clin Infect Dis. 2006 Jul 15;43(2):223-33.

Note: This reference is indexed in Medline, and has been established as a systematic review using specific criteria. It does not yet appear in any pre-appraised source and so the quality of the research has not been assessed.

OBJECTIVE: to conduct a systematic review of the indirect evidence in the literature regarding the utility of anal Papanicolau (Pap) smear screening of HIV-infected individuals in the highly active antiretroviral therapy era.

CONCLUSION: the available evidence demonstrates that HIV-infected individuals have an increased risk for squamous cell cancer of the anus and anal intraepithelial neoplasia.

]]>

document.description: Systematic review published in BMJ
document.body:
BMJ. 2003 September 6; 327(7414): 536–542.

OBJECTIVE: to determine the effectiveness of programmes of screening in general practice for excessive alcohol use and providing brief interventions

CONCLUSIONS: Although even brief advice can reduce excessive drinking, screening in general practice does not seem to be an effective precursor to brief interventions targeting excessive alcohol use.

 

This reference has been critically appraised by reviewers from the Centre for Reviews and Dissemination (CRD). Click here to read this review.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Screening to prevent spontaneous preterm birth: systematic reviews of accuracy and effectiveness literature with economic modelling
document.body:
Honest H, Forbes CA, Durée KH, Norman G, Duffy SB, Tsourapas A, et al. Screening to prevent spontaneous preterm birth: systematic reviews of accuracy and effectiveness literature with economic modelling. Health Technology Assessment 2009;13(43).

 

Objectives: To identify combinations of tests and treatments to predict and prevent spontaneous preterm birth.

Data sources: Searches were run on the following databases up to September 2005 inclusive: MEDLINE, EMBASE, DARE, the Cochrane Library (CENTRAL and Cochrane Pregnancy and Childbirth Group trials register) and MEDION. We also contacted experts including the Cochrane Pregnancy and Childbirth Group and checked reference lists of review articles and papers that were eligible for inclusion.

Review methods: Two series of systematic reviews were performed: (1) accuracy of tests for the prediction of spontaneous preterm birth in asymptomatic women in early pregnancy and in women symptomatic with threatened preterm labour in later pregnancy; (2) effectiveness of interventions with potential to reduce cases of spontaneous preterm birth in asymptomatic women in early pregnancy and to reduce spontaneous preterm birth or improve neonatal outcome in women with a viable pregnancy symptomatic of threatened preterm labour. For the health economic evaluation, a model-based analysis incorporated the combined effect of tests and treatments and their cost-effectiveness.

Results: Of the 22 tests reviewed for accuracy, the quality of studies and accuracy of tests was generally poor. Only a few tests had LR+ > 5. In asymptomatic women these were ultrasonographic cervical length measurement and cervicovaginal prolactin and fetal fibronectin screening for predicting spontaneous preterm birth before 34 weeks. In this group, tests with LR– < 0.2 were detection of uterine contraction by home uterine monitoring and amniotic fluid C-reactive protein (CRP) measurement. In symptomatic women with threatened preterm labour, tests with LR+ > 5 were absence of fetal breathing movements, cervical length and funnelling, amniotic fluid interleukin-6 (IL-6), serum CRP for predicting birth within 2–7 days of testing, and matrix metalloprotease-9, amniotic fluid IL-6, cervicovaginal fetal fibronectin and cervicovaginal human chorionic gonadotrophin (hCG) for predicting birth before 34 or 37 weeks. In this group, tests with LR– < 0.2 included measurement of cervicovaginal IL-8, cervicovaginal hCG, cervical length measurement, absence of fetal breathing movement, amniotic fluid IL-6 and serum CRP, for predicting birth within 2–7 days of testing, and cervicovaginal fetal fibronectin and amniotic fluid IL-6 for predicting birth before 34 or 37 weeks. The overall quality of the trials included in the 40 interventional topics reviewed for effectiveness was also poor. Antibiotic treatment was generally not beneficial but when used to treat bacterial vaginosis in women with intermediate flora it significantly reduced the incidence of spontaneous preterm birth. Smoking cessation programmes, progesterone, periodontal therapy and fish oil appeared promising as preventative interventions in asymptomatic women. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agents were the most effective tocolytic agent for reducing spontaneous preterm birth and prolonging pregnancy in symptomatic women. Antenatal corticosteroids had a beneficial effect on the incidence of respiratory distress syndrome and the risk of intraventricular haemorrhage (28–34 weeks), but the effects of repeat courses were unclear. For asymptomatic women, costs ranged from £1.08 for vitamin C to £1219 for cervical cerclage, whereas costs for symptomatic women were more significant and varied little, ranging from £1645 for nitric oxide donors to £2555 for terbutaline; this was because the cost of hospitalisation was included. The best estimate of additional average cost associated with a case of spontaneous preterm birth was approximately £15,688 for up to 34 weeks and £12,104 for up to 37 weeks. Among symptomatic women there was insufficient evidence to draw firm conclusions for preventing birth at 34 weeks. Hydration given to women testing positive for amniotic fluid IL-6 was the most costeffective test–treatment combination. Indomethacin given to all women without any initial testing was the most cost-effective option for preventing birth before 37 weeks among symptomatic women. For a symptomatic woman, the most cost-effective test–treatment combination for postponing delivery by at least 48 h was the cervical length (15 mm) measurement test with treatment with indomethacin for all those testing positive. This combination was also the most

cost-effective option for postponing delivery by at least 7 days. Antibiotic treatment for asymptomatic bacteriuria of all women without any initial testing was the most cost-effective option for preventing birth before 37 weeks among asymptomatic women but this does not take into account the potential side effects of antibiotics or issues such as increased resistance.

Conclusions: For primary prevention, an effective, affordable and safe intervention applied to all mothers without preceding testing is likely to be the most cost-effective approach in asymptomatic women in early pregnancy. For secondary prevention among women at risk of preterm labour in later pregnancy, a management strategy based on the results of testing is likely to be more cost-effective. Implementation of a treat-all strategy with simple interventions, such as fish oils, would be premature for asymptomatic women.

Universal provision of high-quality ultrasound machines in labour wards is more strongly indicated for predicting spontaneous preterm birth among symptomatic women than direct management, although staffing issues and the feasibility and acceptability to mothers and health providers of such strategies need to be explored. Further research should include investigations of lowcost and effective tests and treatments to reduce and delay spontaneous preterm birth and reduce the risk of perinatal mortality arising from preterm birth.

]]>

document.title: Screening tools assessing risk of suicide and self-harm in adult offenders: a systematic review.
document.publisher: International Journal of Offender Therapy & Comparative Criminology
document.body:
Author's conclusions: Standards of reporting were varied. Suicidal Concerns for Offenders in Prison (SCOPE) and Suicide Potential Scale both demonstrated promising levels of sensitivity and specificity. Further research is needed to assess validity of these tools to identify those at risk, particularly those on probation and in the community.

 

Method: Eleven electronic databases were searched for studies assessing the validity of screening instruments to identify the risk of suicide and self-harm in offenders.

 

Results: Five studies were included, assessing four screening tools.

 

Citation: Perry AE, Marandos R, Coulton S et al. Screening tools assessing risk of suicide and self-harm in adult offenders: a systematic review. International Journal of Offender Therapy & Comparative Criminology 2010; 54(5):803-28

 

Access: Abstract freely available

]]>

document.body:

Method: Systematic search of Medline, Cinahl and Web of Science for short screening tools.

 

Results: Six screening tools were identified and reviewed as screening instruments that could be incorporated in to a primary care assessment.

 

Citation: Philp I, Hoyle E, O'Brien E, Parker C. Screening tools for older people at risk of adverse outcomes. Geriatric Medicine 2007;37(8):10-4.

 

Access: Full text freely available

 

This systematic review has not been critically appraised.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Screenwatch - Ovarian Cancer
document.body:
Ovarian Cancer Screening

See the review in Bandolier**

Bandolier write:

"A major drawback is the lack of a randomised controlled trial to show a reduction in mortality from screening. The European Randomised Trial of Ovarian Cancer (ERTOC) is about to start, and should provide evidence in this area. Ovarian cancer is a high profile media issue. This often results in women requesting advice. Thus a decision must be made on what can be identified as best practice based on the available evidence.

There is no evidence to support screening asymptomatic women in the general population for ovarian cancer.

Screening asymptomatic women with one affected relative should be confined to recognised research studies [3].

Women with two or more first (mother/daughter/sister) or second (grandmother/aunt) degree affected relatives with the disease are at a markedly increased risk. There is no evidence as yet to support actively seeking these women out in the community, as due to the lack of RCT evidence on reduction in mortality, benefit cannot be guaranteed. If a woman with this history presents requesting screening, she should be referred for further advice. This might be to a Gynaecologist or to the UKCCCR Familial Ovarian Cancer Study. Any decision to undergo screening must be based on a fully informed choice.

The current criterion for the UKCCCR study is two first or second degree relatives living or dead with (epithelial) ovarian cancer. The protocol suggests yearly screening from the age of 25 or 30 with a method such as trans-vaginal or trans-abdominal ultrasound".

References

 

  1. HT Lynch, P Watson, C Bewtra, et al. Hereditary ovarian cancer - Heterogeneity in age at diagnosis. Cancer 1991; 67: 1460-6.
  2. HT Lynch, W Kimberly, WA Albano, et al, Hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer (Lynch syndrome I and II). Cancer 1988; 56: 934-8.
  3. Non-surgical aspects of ovarian cancer. Report of a meeting of Physicians and Scientists, Institute of Cancer Research and the Royal Marsden Hospital, London. Lancet 1994. 343: 335-40.
  4. BAJ Ponder, DF Easton, J Peto. Risk of ovarian cancer associated with a family history. In: Sharp F, Mason W D, Leake R, eds. Ovarian cancer. London: Chapman and Hall, 1990. 3-6.
  5. UK Familial Ovarian Cancer Study, Box 238, Addenbrookes' Hospital, Hills Road, Cambridge, CB2 2QQ.

**Note that this review is >5 years old

]]>

document.title: Secondary analysis of economic data: a review of cost-benefit studies of neonatal screening for phenylketonuria
document.body:
Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health 1999; 53:179-86**.

Note: This reference is indexed in Medline, and has been established as a systematic review using specific criteria. It does not yet appear in any pre-appraised source and so the quality of the research has not been assessed

This article is provided in free full text by BMJ publishing from the link given above (requires registration).

Objective: this systematic literature review aimed to estimate the financial benefit of neonatal screening for phenylketonuria.

Conclusions: this review concluded that the economic literature on phenylketonuria screening is of variable quality. Their analysis of the data showed that neonatal PKU screening is worthwhile in financial terms alone in the UK, and that it justifies the infrastructure for collecting and testing neonatal blood samples.

** Please note that this article is >5 years old.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Selective chest radiography: guidelines review
document.publisher: Health Services Utilization and Research Commission
document.body:
Health Services Utilization and Research Commission (HSURC), Canada is an independent agency that reports on quality of care.

The HSURC selective chest radiography guideline was released in September 1997. This is an update of the evidence on selective chest radiography, and includes a discussion of new technologies and research that may have implications for the guideline.

The report concludes that "screening for lung cancer continues to be widely debated, with much of the research focus on the use of computed tomography to improve the detection rate of resectable tumours before the presence of symptoms. The HSURC guideline remains current on the use of chest radiography for lung cancer screening".

See the 1997 HSURC guideline: Chest Radiography: A Summary of the Evidence Supporting Selective Clinical Practice Guidelines and Recommendation for Implementation

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Smear test 'no benefit' in early 20s
document.body:
Behind the headlines provides an unbiased and evidence-based analysis of health stories that make the news. the service is intended for both the public and health professionals

 

"The British Medical Journal recently published research that looked at the effectiveness of smear tests across different age groups of women. This large and well-designed case-control study analysed the impact of cervical screening on the risk of cancer in more than 4,000 diagnosed cases and nearly 8,000 age-matched controls without cancer.

It found that screening reduced the risk of developing cervical cancer in all age groups except the youngest. As women got older, the more their risk was reduced in the five years after screening. Screening women between the ages of 20 and 24 had no detectable impact on cervical cancer rates at ages 25 to 29. These are important findings, which support the NHS approach of only inviting women for cervical screening once they reach the age of 25."

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Social and ethnic inequalities in the offer and uptake of prenatal screening and diagnosis in the UK: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SCREENING,ANTENATAL,HIV,DOWN'S SYNDROME (NUCHAL TRANSLUCENCY),NEURAL TUBE DEFECTS,INFORMED DECISION-MAKING,11-14 WEEKS,BEFORE 16 WEEKS,18-20 WEEKS,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,MANAGEMENT AND POLICY,SERVICE DELIVERY,CLINICAL PROFESSIONS,NURSES,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE,CLIENT GROUPS,WOMEN,HEALTH PROMOTION AND PREVENTIVE SERVICES,RACE EQUALITY,8-10 WEEKS,SICKLE CELL & THALASSAEMIA,PUBLIC HEALTH,DETERMINANTS,OUTCOMES,SOCIAL DETERMINANTS,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,POPULATIONS,GROUPS,ETHNIC GROUPS,WOMEN,SERVICES,POPULATION BASED & PREVENTATIVE SERVICES,SCREENING,MONTHLY ADDITIONS,NOVEMBER 2010]]>
document.body:
Social and ethnic inequalities in the offer and uptake of prenatal screening and diagnosis in the UK: a systematic review. Rowe RE, Garcia J, Davidson LL. Public Health. 2004 Apr;118(3):177-89.

Note: This reference is indexed in Medline, and has been established as a systematic review using specific criteria. It does not yet appear in any pre-appraised source and so the quality of the research has not been assessed.

"Objective: To review studies addressing the question of whether there are social inequalities in either the offer or the uptake of prenatal testing in the UK.

Conclusion: This review provides some evidence of ethnic inequalities in access to prenatal testing. Further research is required to improve our understanding of why testing may not be offered, the reasons for failure to take up testing when offered, and to identify whether there are other social inequalities in access to prenatal testing".

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Surveillance of screening-detected cancers (colon and rectum, breast, and cervix - United States, 2004-2006
document.publisher: Morbidity & Mortality Weekly Report. Surveillance Summaries
document.body:
Authors' conclusions: This report emphasizes the need for ongoing population-based surveillance and reporting to monitor trends in late cancer incidence. Colorectal, cervical and breast cancers are identifiable at earlier and more treatable stages through screening but multiple factors account for why certain populations are underscreened.

 

Method: Data were obtained from cancer registries affiliated with the Center for Disease Control's National Program of Cancer Registries and the National Cancer Institute's Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) program. Data on screening were obtained from the Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System.

 

Results: Around half of all colorectal and cervical cancers and one third of breast cancers were diagnosed at a late stage of disease. Incidence rates of late cancers differed by age, race/ethnicity and state, as did the percentage of people who received recommended screening.

 

Citation: Henley SJ, King JB, German RR et al. Surveillance of screening-detected cancers (colon and rectum, breast, and cervix - United States, 2004-2006. Morbidity & Mortality Weekly Report. Surveillance Summaries 2010; 59(9):1-25

 

Access: Full text freely available

]]>

document.body:

Note: This reference is indexed in Medline, and has been established as a systematic review using specific criteria. It does not yet appear in any pre-appraised source and so the quality of the research has not been assessed.

 

"Objective: The authors sought to determine the diagnostic accuracy of 99mTc-HMPAO-SPECT in discriminating between Alzheimer disease (AD) and other dementias.

 

Conclusion: SPECT may be helpful in the differential diagnosis of AD. Clinical follow-up studies are urgently required to establish its predictive validity with regard to natural history and treatment response."
