document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Testing a Screening Test
document.body:
Testing a Screening Test

See the review in Bandolier**

J A Muir Gray writes:

"When testing a new test against an established diagnostic test or procedure, improvements in sensitivity, specificity and predictive value are sought, as well as cost and patient acceptability. These simple criteria need to be applied to all new screening tests, and to many screening tests presently in use.

** Note that this review is > 10 years old

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Testing a Test
document.body:
Testing a Test

See the review in Bandolier**

J A Muir Gray writes:

"The evaluation of a treatment is often difficult, but at least there is a clear outcome - either the patient gets better or does not.

When assessing a new diagnostic test, however, the situation may not be so simple. The successful "outcome" for a test may be either a positive or a negative result, depending upon whether a doctor wishes to confirm or exclude a diagnosis. Another possible way of assessing outcome is by whether the test affects the management of the patient: some test results, both positive and negative, will lead to a change in management, whereas in other circumstances a positive or negative result will lead the doctor to continue with the same management plan."

**Note that this review is > 10 years old

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Time-trend of melanoma screening practice by primary care physicians: a meta regression analysis
document.body:
Authors' conclusions: The increase in melanoma and other skin malignancies together with the decreased use over time of the full body skin examination (FBSE) to screen for melanoma should be cause for concern.

 

Method: Medline, ISI, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled trials were searched and meta-regression analyses of the fifteen included studies was carried out.

 

Results: Fifteen studies including 10336 physicians were included. 15-82% of physicians surveyed performed FBSE to screen for melanoma. Overall, this proportion decreased each year.

 

Citation: Valachis A, Mauri D, Karampoiki V et al. Time-trend of melanoma screening practice by primary care physicians: a meta-regression analysis. Upsala Journal of Medical Sciences 2009; 114(1):32-40

 

Access: Full text pdf freely available

]]>

document.title: Timing of group B streptococcus screening in pregnancy: a systematic
document.publisher: Gynecologic & Obstetric Investigation, S. Karger AG
document.body:
Authors' conclusions: Despite the limitations of the screening test for group B streptococcus in pregnancy (where 6% of carriers remain undetected) the results of this review support screening at 35-37 weeks gestation.

 

Method: PubMed and Embase were searched from 1966 to February 2009.

 

Results: Study features and predictive values of antenatal cultures were abstracted from the nine articles included.

 

Citation: Valkenburg-van den Berg AW.  Houtman-Roelofsen RL.  Oostvogel PM. et al.  Timing of group B streptococcus screening in pregnancy: a systematic review. Gynecologic & Obstetric Investigation 2010; 69(3):174-83

 

Access: Abstract freely available.

]]>

document.title: Transcutaneous bilirubinometry in the context of early postnatal discharge
document.publisher: Agence d'Evaluation des Technologies et des Modes d'Intervention en Sante
document.body:
The Agence d’évaluation des technologies et des modes d’intervention en santé (AETMIS) is a government agency in Quebec, Canada. It assesses the introduction, acquisition and use of health technologies.

This report is based on a review of the scientific literature on transcutaneous bilirubinometry, a noninvasive technology that can provide an estimate of the blood bilirubin level of newborns. The report concludes that "in healthy term newborns, transcutaneous bilirubinometry is an effective technology for screening for cases where a serum bilirubin determination is required".

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Ultrasonographic screening for the detection of abdominal aortic aneurysms
document.body:
Authors' conclusions: Screening for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) using ultrasound is technically simple and associated with a major reduction in AAA-related mortality. Systematic screening for AAA is recommended in all men aged 65 and over and women with a family history. A national screening programme should be introduced in Germany.

 

Method: A selective literature review was carried out and four population-based, randomized  studies of ultarsonographic screening for the detection of AAA were evaluated.

 

Results: A meta-analysis of four randomized controlled studies showed ultrasonographic screening was associated with a signifcant lowering of AAA-related mortality in men aged 65-80 years. Overall mortality was also lowered significantly after 7-15 years but not after 5 years. The number of elective AAA operations significantly increased and the number of emergency operations reduced by 50%

 

Citation: Eckstein HH, Bockler D, Flessenkamper I, et al. Ultrasonographic screening for the detection of abdominal aortic aneurysms. Deutsches Arzteblatt International 2009; 106(41):657-63

 

Access: Full text pdf freely available

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Ultrasonography in screening for developmental dysplasia of the hip in newborns: systematic review
document.body:
Ultrasonography in screening for developmental dysplasia of the hip in newborns: systematic review. Woolacott N, Puhan M et al. BMJ  2005;330:1413 (18 June).

Note: This reference is indexed in Medline, and has been established as a systematic review using specific criteria. It does not yet appear in any pre-appraised source and so the quality of the research has not been assessed.

This article is available in free full text from the BMJ website.

"Objective: To assess the accuracy and effectiveness of the screening of all newborn infants for developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) using ultrasound imaging, as is standard practice in some European countries but not in the United Kingdom, the United States, or Scandinavia.

Conclusions: Clear evidence is lacking either for or against general ultrasound screening of newborn infants for DDH. Studies that investigate the natural course of the disorder, the optimal treatment for DDH, and the best strategy for ultrasound screening are needed."

This article appears to be based on a Centre for Reviews and Dissemination (CRD) report (no. 28) by the same authors, which was published later: Systematic review of the clinical and cost effectiveness of ultrasound in screening for developmental dysplasia of the hip in newborns (Aug 2005).

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Ultrasound cervical length for the prediction of preterm labor
document.body:
Institute for Clinical Systems Improvement (ICSI) Technology Assessment Reports are designed to provide a scientific assessment, through review and analysis of medical literature, of the safety and efficacy of medical technologies.

This report looks at the use of ultrasound cervical length as a tool in predicting preterm labor. The Technology Assessment Committee summarised by stating that: "ultrasound measurement of cervical length is not recommended as a screening test for preterm labor in the general obstetric population....although cervical length measurement between 28-35 weeks’ gestation may be clinically helpful, its usefulness has not been supported in the literature. Ultrasound measurement of cervical length is not recommended before 14 weeks or after 35 weeks’ gestation".

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ SCREENING,ANTENATAL,IMPLEMENTATION,DOWN'S SYNDROME (NUCHAL TRANSLUCENCY),FETAL ANOMALY,WOMEN'S HEALTH,NORMAL PREGNANCY,ANTENATAL CARE,SCREENING,ULTRASOUND,QUALITY ASSURANCE,MANAGEMENT,11-14 WEEKS,BEFORE 16 WEEKS,18-20 WEEKS,DOWN'S SYNDROME]]>
document.body:
2002 survey clearly demonstrate that although routine fetal screening forms a standard part of most antenatal screening packages its application is variable.
The NHS FASP is committed to ensuring all pregnant women in England have access to safe, evidence-based, high-quality, uniform fetal screening services. This study maps local service delivery against current national policy and standards. This will assist in identifying where extra support and guidance is required to improve services to meet the standards.']]>

document.publisher: Swedish Council on Technology Assessment in Health Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SCREENING,HEARING,ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,CONDITIONS,HEARING DISORDERS/ DEAFNESS,GENERAL EAR & AUDITORY,EAR & AUDITORY SYSTEM DISORDERS,PHYSICAL (<72HRS),NEWBORN,NEONATAL SCREENING,SPECIALTIES,AUDIOLOGY]]>
document.body:
Alert is a system for identification and early assessment concerning new methods in health care. The Alert reports are produced by the Swedish Council on Technology Assessment in Health Care, and describe the new methods and their effects.

This report summarises the methods and effects of universal newborn hearing screening. It concludes that "there is scientific evidence that newborn screening, using either Otoacoustic Emissions (OAEs) or automated Auditory Brainstem Response (aABR), results in earlier detection of congenital hearing impairment and commencement of habilitation".

]]>

This bulletin looks at the use of a new spectral reflectance device to meaure bilirubin levels in neonates, and summarises by stating that "as a screening technique for the healthy neonate population, these devices provide instantaneous information, may reduce the need of heel-pricks on neonates, and indicate which neonates will need serum bilirubin measurement".

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Value of quantitative analysis of circulating cell free DNA as a screening tool for lung cancer: a meta-analysis
document.body:
Authors' conclusions: Circulating cell free DNA is not recommended for lung cancer screening alone although its use in combination with conventional markers warrants further investigation.

 

Method: A systematic review of English language studies on sensitivity, specificity and othe accuracy measures for the circulating cell free DNA assay in the diagnosis of lung cancer.

 

Results: 10 studies were included.

 

Citation: Zhang R, Shao F, Wu X et al. Value of quantitative analysis of circulating cell free DNA as a screening tool for lung cancer: a meta-analysis. Lung Cancer 2010; 69(2):225-31

 

Access: PubMed abstract available

]]>

document.title: Virtual colonoscopy
document.body:
The Medical Services Advisory Committee (MSAC) has undertaken an Horizon Scanning Briefing to provide advice on use of virtualcolonoscopy. This briefing provides an assessment of the current state of development of virtual colonoscopy, its present use, the potential application of the technology and the likely impact on the Australian healthcare system.

The MSAC concluded that "based on the available evidence, VC appears to be safe when used for diagnosing CRC in individual patients. However, its safety as a population-based screening tool has yet to be evaluated."

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: What are the pros and cons of screening high risk populations for anal cancer? (project)
document.body:
This is a Health Technology Assessment (HTA) project in progress.

HTA project abstract: "The evaluation of the likely cost-effectiveness of a screening programme for screening anal cancer will consist of five broad sections. Firstly, a systematic literature review will be undertaken covering the following aspects: the epidemiology and natural history of anal cancer; the effectiveness of LBC as a screening test and alternative screening tests, the acceptability of screening tests in general, and for anal cancer in particular; and estimates of health related quality of life and patient utilities relating to anal cancer and screening; and the clinical and cost effectiveness of alternative treatment options. The data derived from the review will be analysed to formulate prior distributions for unknown parameters. Secondly, following the analysis of the data identified in the literature review, a decision analytic model structure describing the natural history of anal cancer in high risk groups will be develop. This will facilitate the evaluation of alternative forms of screening and treatment options. Thirdly, areas of the developed model for which no useable data are available will be specified and Bayesian methods for eliciting information from experts in these fields will be used to obtain relevant estimates. Finally, a full ‘expected value of information’ (EVI) analysis will be undertaken using a decision analytic framework to estimate the costs of uncertainty associated with the decision to implement screening for anal cancer in high risk groups, as well as to prioritise research by costing the individual (or joint) uncertainty attached to all parameters affecting the cost-effectiveness of screening."

It is due to be published in October 2010.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: What is the most appropriate breast-cancer screening interval for women aged 45 to 49 years in New Zealand?
document.description: Systematic review published in NZ Medical Journal
document.body:
New Zealand Medical Journal 2005; 118(1221): U1636

Note: This reference is indexed in Medline, and has been established as a systematic review using specific criteria. It does not yet appear in any pre-appraised source and so the quality of the research has not been assessed

Objective: to review the international evidence on the benefits and harms of different screening intervals for women aged 45 to 49 years

Conclusions: there is no robust trial evidence on which to base a decision on the most appropriate breast-cancer screening interval for women aged 45 to 49 years

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: When to measure bone density
document.topics: <![CDATA[ MUSCULOSKELETAL,CONDITIONS,BONE DISORDERS,OSTEOPOROSIS,SCREENING,ADULT,LATER LIFE,SCREENING AND SURVEILLANCE,OSTEOPOROSIS,OSTEOPOROSIS,OLD AGE,SCREENING,NOT ROUTINELY OFFERED]]>
document.body:
When to measure bone density.  

See the review in Bandolier

Bandolier write:

"It is rare to find an example where a single clinical decision aid has been tested in an independent sample. To find a study that systematically compares all the available decision aids is remarkable. There are several ways in which this information might be used. Many women have bone density measured whatever decision system was used, and some will argue for mass screening. This study is the essential aid to decision making".

References:

  1. SM Cadarette et al. Evaluation of decision rules for referring women for bone densitometry by dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry. JAMA 2001 286: 57-63.
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Whole-Body Computed Tomography as a Screening Test
document.body:
Institute for Clinical Systems Improvement (ICSI) Technology Assessment Reports are designed to provide a scientific assessment, through review and analysis of medical literature, of the safety and efficacy of medical technologies.

This report looks at the use of whole-body computed tomography (CT) as a screening test for various diseases. The Technology Assessment Committee summarised by stating that "whole-body CT should not be considered as a screening tool at this time. Whole-body CT screening is not specific enough or tailored appropriately to detect coronary artery calcification, lung cancer, or colon polyps or masses"

]]>

document.body: <![CDATA[ This document summarises the reasons for having a newborn hearing screen, and includes details about the acceptability of screening, the prevalence of newborn deafness, risk factors for hearing loss and the benefits of early identification.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Woman to Woman: Promoting cervical screening amongst minority ethnic women in primary care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SCREENING,ADULT,CERVICAL CANCER,INFORMED DECISION-MAKING,MANAGEMENT,PRIMARY CARE,ETHNICITY AND HEALTH,DISEASES AND CONDITIONS,CANCER,SERVICE DELIVERY,SERVICE SECTORS,PRIMARY CARE,CLIENT GROUPS,WOMEN,PUBLIC HEALTH,OUTCOMES,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,POPULATIONS,GROUPS,CANCER,CERVICAL CANCER,ETHNIC GROUPS,WOMEN,SERVICES,POPULATION BASED & PREVENTATIVE SERVICES,PRIMARY CARE SERVICES,SCREENING,MONTHLY ADDITIONS,NOVEMBER 2010]]>
document.body:
This report aimed to explore issues involved in promoting cervical screening amongst minority ethnic women in primary care, to construct a health promotion programme to address issues identified, and to implement the health promotion programme and to evaluate the relative successes and limitations of the programme.

The report looked at lay and professional views to barriers of screening and found that "there was a divergence in perceptions held by both smear takers and minority ethnic women regarding cervical screening, which contributed to negative experiences on both sides. There is also clear evidence of dysfunctional clinical communication arising from these differing perceptions".

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: Workshop on screening for late onset genetic disorders - heritable thrombophila
document.description: A report of a National Screening Committee workshop to discuss the likely value of population screening in relation to heritable thrombophilia.
document.body:
111-1Workshop on screening for late onset genetic disorders - heritable thrombophila

A report of a National Screening Committee workshop to discuss the likely value of population screening in relation to heritable thrombophilia.

One of the conclusions of this report was that "it was unanimously agreed that there is no clear benefit from testing for heritable thrombophilia in the individual with venous thrombosis, from the point of view of the clinical management of that individual"

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Screening]]>
document.title: World Health Organization systematic review of screening tests for preeclampsia
document.body:
World Health Organization systematic review of screening tests for preeclampsia. A Conde-Agudelo, J Villar, Lindheimer M. Obstet Gynecol 2004 Dec; 104(6): 1367-91

Note: This reference is indexed in Medline, and has been established as a systematic review using specific criteria. It does not yet appear in any pre-appraised source and so the quality of the research has not been assessed.

Objectives: This systematic review aims to assess the usefulness of clinical, biophysical and biochemical tests in the prediction of preeclampsia.

Conclusions: As of 2004, there is no clinically useful screening test to predict the development of preeclampsia.

]]>
